[h1] Turn-based deep strategy, A+ gameplay, intense story/atmo [/h1]
[b] 5/5 [/b] 👽👽👽👽👽
XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a gaming gem that [b] redefined turn-based strategy, [/b] a title that blends tactical brilliance with heart-pounding (close-up) action and suspense seamlessly. From the moment you're tasked with defending Earth against an extraterrestrial invasion, the weight of command rests squarely on your shoulders.
[h3] Makes you a true tactician 😎 [/h3]
The depth of strategic decision-making in XCOM is unparalleled. Every move matters, every decision carries consequences. Whether it's [b] managing your base, researching new technologies, or engaging in turn-based combat, [/b] every aspect is finely tuned to keep you engaged and challenged. The tension of not knowing what lurks around the corner, combined with the satisfaction of executing a flawless plan, creates an addictive gameplay loop that's hard to put down.
[h3] Some words about your Adversaries and your Allies 👿😇[/h3]
The variety of alien adversaries keeps you on your toes, each requiring a unique approach to overcome. [b] The first time you see a new type of alien is always a stress- and fearful moment because you don't know yet what they can do and how to fight it. [/b] And the progression system, as you develop your squad members and unlock new abilities, adds a layer of personal investment that makes every soldier's fate feel significant.
[h3] Graphics - pretty decent and lovely zoomed-in action 🌄🔫 [/h3] 
Graphically, while not groundbreaking by today's standards, the [b] aesthetic holds up well, [/b] and the [b] atmosphere is brilliantly crafted, [/b] immersing you in a world on the brink of destruction.
[h3] Are there any CONs? 😥[/h3]
However, XCOM isn't without its challenges. The [b]difficulty curve can be punishing, [/b] especially for newcomers to the genre. Losing beloved squad members to a single wrong move can be devastating, but it also adds to the game's intensity and makes each victory all the sweeter.
[h3] Buy it! Especially on Sale:) [/h3]
Enemy Unknown is a timeless classic that deserves its place among the (turn-based) strategy gaming greats. Its blend of [h3] deep strategy, compelling gameplay, and intense atmosphere [/h3] make it a must-play for any fan of the genre. Whether you're a seasoned commander or a rookie recruit, prepare for a thrilling ride that will test your wits and keep you coming back for more - there is a [b] NewGame+ option and great DLCs... [/b]

I, strangely, don't see any reviews from people with more than 200 hours on the game- not that there's anything wrong with that, it just feels like an oversight. I'm not sure if I want to write this, because it's probably going to take like half an hour off my life, but here we go.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown, or, more specifically, Enemy within, or, EVEN MORE specifically, Long War is the finest tactical and strategy game to ever exist. First of all, I'm not going to talk about the Enemy Unknown base game (as opposed to Enemy Within) because I'm not sure if I've ever played it. In my extremely biased opinion, Enemy Within is just objectively better because you get giant freaking MECs. So I'm going to talk about EW, and then I'm going to talk about the single greatest strategy game ever made.

I'm probably not going to go over the basics of XCOM because I have other things to say and plenty of people have already done that well enough in these reviews. (This is a fancy way of saying I don't feel like it.) Suffice it to say, vanilla XCOM is: Go on whatever missions the game hands you, get up as many satellites as possible, defend them/shoot down UFOs. There's of course more to this incredible game, but I want to talk about something even more interesting. Enemy Within is: Try to balance haste and caution during missions as you attempt to track down two special resource canisters, randomly spawned throughout most standard mission types, without dying horribly. You then use this resource to commit war crimes against your fellow man for betraying his genome... You can just as well use it against aliens but I had to make a joke about the fact that you can just make actual walking warcrimes in this game. There's also a few new enemy types and I think probably some other stuff too. (Again, never really played the base game because I picked up the game when Enemy Within was released and why would you ever go back) If it sounds like I'm rushing, it's just because I want to get to the good part.

Now to tell you about the greatest strategy game ever made! Long War. Long War is a total overhaul mod for XCOM that adds such an unspeakable amount of depth to the game that I'm genuinely unsure if you could master it in only 10,000 hours. Don't believe me? I'll give you an example. The aliens have resources. No, you don't need to reread that. The aliens straight up have tech and resources just like you do, and they have to do missions in order to further their goals. Want to attempt taking on a landed large UFO in March? (first month of the game) Sure! Just so we're clear, large UFOs have a high crew count and are extremely difficult and risky to take on, even in March, when the aliens are just starting their progression. Nevertheless, there are people who will successfully pull this off. On the hardest difficulty. These people are also known for being very unhinged and named Beaglerush. I'm getting off track. Here's the best part: Do you think you merely get loads of resources for taking the UFO, just because it was a large? No. Long War would never, COULD never be that shallow. That UFO was gathering resources... (presuming that was its mission type) And no one was ever counting on XCOM storming the UFO and taking out its entire crew compliment. If you pull this off, it will cripple the aliens- (temporarily, although considering that XCOM also gains from this, and that I'm pretty sure aliens need resources in order to do their progression, I think it would have some form of snowballing effect, possibly even a significant one.) Forcing them to send mediocre units into battle, as well as inhibiting really anything that they need resources to accomplish. This should make your life easier in almost every way, except for EXALT. EXALT is cringe. We do not like EXALT. But remember, that's what warcrimes are for. Oh, also if you cripple the aliens they might not send out units you want/need so I guess that could make your life a little harder, but the aliens get screwed over far more than you do. (Editors nots: EXALT is the human terrorists who are trying to side with the aliens. They're from Enemy Within.)

That was just one example of Long War's depth and brilliance. There are surely countless others, and lots and lots of details that I didn't mention. Sorry if this is a little disjointed, I'm a bit tired. Honestly just kind of shocked that I've never written any form of review for this game. Maybe I wanted to wait 'til I had 1000 hours or something. Felt that Long War was more in need of reviewing than the base game. I'm barely even qualified to review it. I don't have that many hours on Long War. And I hope it wasn't too technical, I tried to make things sound as straightforward as I could.

Also, the game is stupendously buggy. Long War seems to... Exaggerate this. But if you've read this far you probably already know that :P


Anyway, I suppose I should give my summarized review of this game. I think the description of Impossible difficulty in the base game does it best:

"For those who find joy in suffering." This game is shit. I love it. You're going to get attached to your soldiers, and they're going to die. They're going to die even after you've learned all your lessons the hard way. You're going to be sad and discouraged and maybe even quit; and then you're going to go back and keep playing. Because Earth needs you, because war crimes I mean MECs are cool, but most importantly...

Because you've finally found an experience worth a damn. No other tactical or strategy game will ever hold a candle to this one... Even if they have a better airgame. And you know why? I can tell you why. It's because you missed that one 99% shot. Your best laid plans will be laid to ruin, and honestly? I've never known another game-- Hell, another experience that can consistently leave a pit in my stomach like this one does. And I don't think I'm the only one.


May you find joy in suffering... And good luck, Commander.

xcom: enemy unknown is a 2012 turn-based tactics game developed by firaxis games, an american developer best known for developing the civilization & xcom franchises, as well as many games bearing sid meier's name. it was published by 2K, who purchased firaxis in 2005 (firaxis was founded in 1996). this is a 'reimagined' & 'rebooted' version of the classic 90s x-com games, namely the 1994 classic x-com: ufo defense. the player controls a worldwide military organization called 'xcom' during an alien invasion of earth. you control troops in the field during tactical turn-based missions, but between missions, you direct the research and development of technology using things you recover during missions in the field. after a failed reboot attempt in 2003,  development of what eventually became this began in 2008 and lasted over four years. while it was initially envisioned as an exact remake of the 1994 game, the dev team streamlined various gameplay mechanics and introduced improvements to modernize the franchise for a new audience. it was revealed/announced in january 2012, and ended up releaseing in october of that same year for pc, ps3, and xbox 360. mobile ports came at various points between 2013 & 2014, and a ps vita port released in march 2016.

this 2012 reboot stands as a monumental achievement in the turn-based strategy genre. firaxis masterfully blended intense tactical action, deep strategic gameplay (in multiple ways), & and a genuinely gripping narrative. aesthetically, the game is way more polished and stylized compared to the 90s games, using way more realistic graphics overall (going from the 90s pixel graphics to early 2010s animations was a huge jump in quality obviously), and the isometric view gives a good vantage point to view all the detailed environments. the audio design further elevates things, as the soundtrack complements the ambiance, whether you're in the middle of tense combat or in eerie calm moments exploring the map.

the biggest strength however lies in the turn based tactical combat. the game strikes a delicate balance between accessibility for newcomers and depth for strategy enthusiasts like myself, especially given difficulty variance. the isometric grid-based maps provide ample opportunity for tactical maneuvering and strategic tactics. the variety in soldier classes allows for diverse squad compositions and personalized playstyle(s) no matter what. the macro-management experience of the geoscape offers further strategic elements of the game. making critical decisions on research priorities, engineering projects, and more adds an interconnectedness to missions and keep players engaged throughout the entire campaign. it would be remiss if i didn't mention permadeath, which heightens the stakes in every way during every mission. mis-clicks, mis-judgments, and any kind of (even minor) mistake can lead to losing a soldier, which can be genuinely heart-wrenching and helps emphasize to players the importance of careful planning and keen decision-making. 

the narrative is slightly generic, as a rehashing of the 1994 classic nit still does an amazing job introducing new players as well as veterans to the rich lore, conveyed through a combination of in-game events, research discoveries, and character interactions. the urgency of the alien threat is effectively conveyed, and the player's emotional investment in the fate of humanity grows as the narrative unfolds. the simplicity of the plot and quickness in which it can be completed leads to the game offering substantial replay value. the dynamic nature of the campaign ensures no two playthroughs are exactly alike, encouraging exploration with different soldier classes, strategies, and research paths. there is also ironman mode, which disables save scumming, enhancing the challenge and replayability for those seeking an even more hardcore experience. there's also a ton of mods, but as i played the entirety of my playtime in vanilla, i can't speak much more to it than i know there's a solid modding community compared to most games. 

xcom: enemy unknown stands as a testament to firaxis games' ability to revive a classic franchise while maintaining its core essence. the immersive presentation cements its status as an early 2010s classic not even just in the turn based strategy genre, but in gaming in general. regardless of whether you're a fan of the original x-com series or a newcomer to the xcom games or the genre as a whole, this is a must-play title that should continuously be celebrated for the depth of strategic gameplay.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a strategic triumph that captivates from start to finish. Firaxis Games weaves a compelling narrative of Earth's invasion, placing you at the helm of the XCOM resistance. The turn-based tactical combat is a highlight, demanding thoughtful planning and rewarding strategic prowess. Managing your base and resources adds a layer of complexity, enhancing the overall experience. The difficulty, notorious for its unforgiving nature, heightens the stakes, with permadeath adding emotional weight to each decision. Visually engaging and complemented by a haunting soundtrack, the game stands the test of time. Having thoroughly enjoyed my time with XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I can confidently say it's a must-play for strategy enthusiasts, delivering a challenging and deeply satisfying gaming experience.

[h1]The whole is less than the sum of its parts[/h1]

I really did try to enjoy this game. It is a rare occasion of finding a game which ticks many boxes that good games share - good art direction, a good music score and when the combat works, it works well. That being said, I can never relax playing this game as every move has the potential to completely destroy your team. On harder difficulties, this typically necessitates restarting if your high ranking soldiers die because you fall behind the curve and cannot catch up. You can save-scum, but this really goes against the spirit of the game as it clearly wants you to try and continue in these situations.

What truly sours the experience is the weak marriage between the meta game and the in-mission battles. Ideally, you would have been able to choose exactly where to launch your missions and select the rewards according to a long-term strategy. Instead, XCOM is essentially just a game of tactics, responding to events as they pop up and never really feeling like you're on top of what the game is throwing at you. Why can't I manage several squads at once and send them on multiple missions? Why are classes assigned to soldiers automatically instead of allowing me to choose? Why can't I station some soldiers in a particular country to respond quickly to panic? These are just a selection of controls that you don't have access to, thereby severely restricting the strategic aspect of this game.

Then, of course, is the actual squad management in mission. When you spot a bunch of enemies, they all immediately take cover whilst your soldiers do not. Full cover is not cover. Enemies hit my soldiers so consistently as if they were standing out in the open. Damage is variable, so your shotgun blast is not a reliable way of killing the enemy. Hit chance is variable, so a shotgun blast at point blank range is not a reliable way of killing the enemy. Panic sets in so easily that your hardened marines are not a reliable means of killing the enemy. To the game's credit, it [i]does[/i] have some interesting features: suppressing fire, elevation bonuses, breakable cover, etc. But many of these are accessible/useful only at a certain rank where it should have been a default feature for all your marines. 

The point of the game is fairly clear - war is completely unfair. You can do everything right and still end up with a poor outcome. However, it is a game after all. Would anyone want to play a game where [b]you[/b] are an XCOM marine, given their life-expectancy? In order to make that idea workable, many features would need to be changed so that you can be the `hero'. Making something realistic simply for the sake of being realistic is a better design philosophy for a simulation than a video game. XCOM thrives when the 'realistic' elements intersect with what the player understands as being fair. For instance, a marine caught out-of-cover is dead meat whilst a marine behind full cover is safe. Suppressing an enemy and/or flanking them is the best method of attack. Instead of building on these rules, XCOM focuses on features which obfuscate them. "Your guys are getting hit constantly behind full cover? Best to camp in a corner of the map until they decide to come to you". "You're not on the exact tile line of the enemy when trying to flank? Tough luck then, you have exactly the same chance to hit as if you were in front of them." 

It's not a bad game by any means, but it's a very frustrating experience that I do not recommend to the casual player. Each component of the game is well done but interact with each other poorly, making for an inconsistent experience. I quit and came back several times, remembering one or two good experiences from earlier sessions but always finding it just wasn't worth the time. However, if you are okay with probability-based games then it may be worth picking up on a sale.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown stands tall as a strategic triumph, seamlessly merging turn-based tactics with an enthralling storyline. The game's strategic depth is commendable, immersing players in a global defense against an alien invasion. While its difficulty spikes may challenge some players, they add a layer of intensity to the overall experience.

The game excels in creating an immersive atmosphere, skillfully blending sci-fi elements with tactical gameplay. Visually and narratively cohesive, it draws players into the intense fight against extraterrestrial threats. However, occasional graphical glitches and mission environment repetitiveness slightly diminish the overall immersion.

XCOM introduces an innovative character customization and perma-death system, injecting personal stakes into each soldier's journey. The emotional investment is significant, yet the perma-death feature may discourage some from taking risks and experimenting with strategies.

So right off the bat - Turn on Auto-Save, it appears to be disabled by default, or at least mine was. This will save you a lot of headache.
[quote][b]Base Management[/b][/quote]
[list]
[*]Almost everything you do requires many days to complete, almost to excess
[*]You're always playing catch up with money, materials, research, panic levels -- and there's really not much you can do about it. You're required to be exhaustingly deliberate with the tiny budget you're given.
[*]I noticed gear would still be on an injured soldier, and I couldn't find a way to get into that soldiers inventory to swap their things onto a fresh one.
[*]For someone like me, the constraint on doing much of anything in the base for so long was unenjoyable. After every mission you come back to base, nothing has changed and there are no more actions that can be taken until the next in-game month.
[/list]

[quote][b]Field Operations[/b][/quote]
[list]
[*]Controls take a little getting used to but aren't terrible
[*]Accuracy is either hit or miss, even if the weapon being used fires multiple shots. I'd have liked to see something more like Valkyria Chronicles, where each individual shot can be a hit or a miss.
[*]I found in a majority of missions that stacking mostly Assault classes on the team was the way to go. They're fast, can still shoot after dashing, and can avoid overwatch shots, letting you get right in the enemies faces and unload on them with very little risk.
[*]There are objectively correct decisions to make on the skill trees for your soldiers. I feel it would have been better if both decisions were tactically sound choices, rather than one clearly outshining the other.
[*]I'd have liked a different method of ranking up soldiers. Not only is losing your high ranking soldiers a setback, but to then have to hand hold a new recruit through a few missions is tedious. Perhaps a buildable training facility that unlocks later on, that you could throw a few soldiers at a time into.
[/list]

[quote][b]Final Thoughts 7/10[/b][/quote]
[list]
[*]The game crashed on me a few times but no major bugs. 
[*]Default difficulty seemed appropriate, perhaps a bit too easy with a little bit of planning. 
[*]I'd have liked a campaign from the Aliens as well, like Starcraft where there are story campaigns for each race. I took a glance and it looks like you can play as the aliens in multiplayer, but that's not really the same.
[*]In the end it's a decent way to kill a little time, and I'm intrigued enough to look into the other entries of this IP at some point.
[/list]

[h1] Ah, Yes! The only game where you can miss shooting the enemy at point blank range. That said it's still a great RTS game. [/h1]

[b] The Positives [/b]

+ Smooth Turn Base Game Mechanics
+ Excellent Voice Acting/Soundtrack
+ Wide Range Of Unit Customization 

[b] The Negatives [/b]

- Awful roll of the dice chances of your characters attacking successfully majority of the time.
- Awful Autosaving feature.
- No Microphone Online Voice Setting For Multiplayer.

[b] Singleplayer Aspect [/b]

You play the commander for the secretive global military force called the "Extraterrestrial Combat Force" otherwise known as XCOM which is ran by an elite society of shadowy figures that run the world which are only known as "The Council". You start with a handful of weak units that get progressively stronger the more you play through the game. After you complete or fail a mission you will be brought back to your underground secret base will you be given some time to improve your units fighting capability's as well as expanding your base of operations. The longer you play the harder it gets as the enemy's eventually fade out from being easy to kill to hard to destroy tank like beings that eat up your soldiers like an appetizer. 

[b] Multiplayer Aspect [/b]

The only multiplayer aspect of this game is a 1v1 with another friend because trying to queue for a 1v1 with a random just isn't going to happen since the game's multiplayer part is dead. If you can find a friend to play with you will be given the choice to fully customize your units and what they are. You are given a set of points which you are allowed to spend a certain amount creating your team. You are not limited to just humans you can also buy aliens as well to spice up the gameplay a little bit. After you both select what units you will be battling with you will select a map and start the match. If you are lucky you should be able to fight your friend till only team remains standing. If you are unlucky like my however some match's will never be finished on account of how the turn screen just freezes and never continues.

[b] The Games Value [/b]

This game is a must buy for any RTS lovers out there looking to waste 30+ hours of there life fighting an opponent using loaded dice. Certainly give it a buy if it goes on sale.

[h1] Final Score 90/100 Ranking A- Tier [/h1]

This game is actually two games: Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within.

Enemy Unknown, I give a thumbs up. On easy mode, it's not so STUPIDLY IMPOSSIBLE as to be unenjoyable. In fact, I liked it a lot, and the way it turned out ending for me was incredible (a guy that I had arbitrarily nicknamed "Hero" some 40 hours prior ended up shaking off mind control just in time to kill the enemy boss and save the planet!). 

After that fun experience, I eagerly started Enemy Within.  Up to a point, it was even BETTER. There were new objectives that added some variety: gather "Meld" from the landing sites, use it to augment your troops either with bio-upgrades or mech upgrades. Do anti-terrorism missions against some human alien sympathizers.  Other than the fact that research seemed to be A MILLION TIMES SLOWER than in Enemy Unknown, it was all good.  Then came the base infiltration, and within a couple of hours, I uninstalled the goddamn game.

The base infiltration is not a mission you can skip.  The way it goes down is this: after some cutscenes of seeming humans sabotaging stuff and attacking the people next to them in XCOM HQ, you find about three of your normal troops and a couple of low-level NPCs taking on a formidable but not unbeatable alien force.  You lose the NPCs in the process, but you defeat the first wave.  Some reinforcements arrive, including some more NPCs and one of your main troops.  But now the alien attack is RIDICULOUS.  It's three of those floater discs and the drones that repair them, plus some other crap.  After the first fiasco, I reloaded a prior save and started the whole scenario over again, fought my way cleanly to this round (still lost the NPCs, oh well) and set my troops up in cover with overwatch on.  Here come the aliens... EVERY ONE OF MY DAMN TROOPS MISSED THEIR REACTION SHOT.  Got one of the floaters down to 1 HP, then EVERY TROOP MISSED THEIR SHOT AFTER THAT, even with 85% and up chance to hit.  Meanwhile, all my troops are taking MASSIVE damage, up to 16 HP down on my tank.  OK, well I'll keep going.  Next round, I'm gonna start by taking down that floater with 1 HP.  NOPE!  Everyone missed, again in spite of 85-97% hit chances.  Are you kidding me?  

And I already knew from the last failed attempt that this was only round 2 of about 5 or 6, and the last round was going to include multiple commanders who can put huge HP shields EVERY TURN on the enemy and can mind-control (i.e. steal from me) my own troops.  It's absurd.  

At it's best, this game is an action-management game where you are -- except on the easiest difficulty setting -- always at a pretty severe disadvantage.  But at its worst, including in this HQ invasion scenario, it's just frustrating and the opposite of fun.  Watch your troops miss every shot, nullifying all your best-laid tactical plans, while the enemy gets 7 extra HP per turn from shields and your own troops get turned into enemy zombies or mind-controlled to fight against you.

Screw this.

[h3]XCOM Enemy Unknown Review[/h3]

[h2]Pros:[/h2]
[list]
[*]Thankfully the game allowed me to play around with base expansions and side missions while ignoring the main quest.This allowed me to level up the base without getting too stressed. This sort of freedom is always appreciated.
[*]I gave all my soldiers pawn star names. It was entertaining to see some of them gain nicknames and climb the ranks to become Colonel. 
[*]The game offered a research path called Shivs which I never used. Additionally, it also provided a path to using laser weaponry. Multiple progression paths like these were most appreciated, even though I never used some of them.
[*]Gameplay options to reduce difficulty were welcome.
[/list]
[h2]Cons:[/h2]
[list]
[*]There was an issue with the manual save system. After about 20 manual saves, new save files were not being created. I had to overwrite my older manual saves.
[*]Autosaves did not function correctly, loading them would load a point several hours prior to the current mission and so ultimately they were unreliable.
[*]The concept that XCoM is strapped for cash is ridiculous. If humanity loses the war, it will be due to meagre funding.
[*]Useful camera rotation feature. However, it has only 4 angles and in internal spaces it failed to display positioning clearly.
[*]The game did not allow deciding the squaddie’s class. That is assigned automatically and based on a ruleset that is never revealed.
[*]There is only one way of playing this game: edge forward meticulously about 6 tiles at a time (on overwatch, which incidentally always misses). Don’t dash forward as enemies will randomly spawn at the most inconvenient places every single time.
[*]So many UFO shootings and forced landings; so many panic reduction missions and so many extraction missions. The game is grindy, probably to pad out the length of the game.
[*]The mystery surrounding the story is what kept me progressing. The gameplay was frustrating and I was glad each encounter was over.
[*]There is never any satisfaction of a well executed plan. All plans fail, every single  mission.
[*]There is no scouting information on the location of the mission to decide what squad mates and equipment to bring. All those XCoM satellites are just idling in orbit.
[*]Snipers and Heavies not being able to shoot or fire rockets after moving to cover is a trash implementation. Only serves to pad out the length of the game.
[*]None of the reaction shots or overwatch shots hit; all of that strategy and careful positioning felt pointless.
[*]I took a break from this game years ago (at the 40% mark) as it was so painful to play. I resumed playing recently to see if I could at least finish it to get my money’s worth.
[*]The final mission does not match the rest of the game. The other missions are shorter in length. The final mission is simply a challenge gauntlet of all the previous enemies encountered. My squad was severely weakened at the end allowing only a slim opportunity to achieve victory.
[*]Why is it that 3D action games with sci-fi guns work so well, but turn-based games with sci-fi guns fail so hard? Perhaps it's because guns are too powerful to balance in a turn based setting.
[*]Turns out that the 2nd game renders all the player effort in this game obsolete.
[*]There are specific builds and upgrades that are essential, e.g if you get stuck in a level, all the online advice will be to use a particular set of builds as if they are obvious; they are not.
[*]I was able to push through the game with my squad builds but they were suddenly not good enough for the final battle.
[*]There are certainly entertaining concepts here such as: base management, research management, procurement, squad customization, but this game is so frustrating. I have read that the 2nd game adds timers on top of these frustrations! I held off on buying XCoM 2 as I had a bad hunch about this game; turns out that was well founded. I can’t envision going through these frustrations all over again under the guillotine of a timer.
[/list]
[h2]Advice:[/h2]
[list]
[*]Seek out a sleek internet guide for the game. There is a fixed way to play this game that new players wouldn’t know about. So follow the guides for the best squad builds and research paths. Play the game if you must, but avoid the slog.
[/list]

GOOD: 

The game looks great. Its armors, weapons, planes, aliens. It definitely achieved the action figure look that they were going for. Soldiers have voice lines and personality now. Ground combat is intense, far closer ranged than general combat in UFO and TFTD. 

Psychic powers are nerfed so that the user needs line of sight to the victim and they can only grab one at a time. 

UFO weapons are fixed so that your planes are always in range, no matter what weapon they have. Which makes the new Firestorm with high health much more useful against the bigger UFOs. It also helps that "fuel capacity/range" isn't a factor.

Cinematic story cutscenes effectively drive the plot along with great chemistry between the three XCOM departments. Plot is actually centered around psychic powers. Aliens are better developed compared to UFO Defense, with it being extremely clear why they came to earth.

"Ant Farm" base looks cool. Autopsies  and live interrogations all give you a benefit, in the form of new items, or research credits and intact plasma weapons. 

Alien weapons break when the user dies. You have to make the effort of tazing aliens if you want to get plasma weapons.

Tons of character customization options compared to UFO which had none except for naming. While limiting, exclusive class abilities give each soldier a defined role on the battlefield. And while limiting, class exclusive weapons mean, yes, you will need to use things other than laser rifles and heavy plasmas.

Yes, I'm talking to YOU. Reading this review.

BAD: 

The game feels somewhat limited, especially on the Geoscape or Mission Control. You can't buy scientists, you get them from missions. Engineers can be "bought" with workshops. Only one plane can attack a UFO at a time and UFOs appear according to a script. 

You can't have multiple transports that respond to simultaneous missions. Abduction missions screw you over in terms of panic. The five point panic bars means ignoring a country even once can easily have them leave the council.

Geoscape panic management is entirely dependent on getting satellites. Because Abductions happen in countries without satellites, covering most of the world with them significantly reduces your missions. The AI doesn't give you more UFO missions or Council missions to compensate.

If you are able to, you can avoid putting satellites on one continent. You can still get some abduction missions that way, and the country you don't go to won't panic. But, again, it's like the AI realizes it can't screw you over with panic now, so abduction missions become very rare.

Many, many restrictions compared to UFO, without mods or Second Wave options. 
Only 4 and then 6 soldiers. 
Weapons entirely restricted by class. 
Soldiers of the same class get the exact same stat progression and stats are capped at Colonel rank. 
Only ever one inventory slot for any unit that's not a Support. Units can need certain perks to be able to fire more than once.

Leveling up low-rank soldiers in mid/late game is very difficult. 
They have low health and aim, and few perks. 
Primary enemies at this point have small to large innate defense even before factoring flight defense bonus and cover. 
Weak enemies become scarce, save for Thin Men in Council Missions. 
Because only kills earn XP, you find yourself babying the enemies so the low rank can get the kill. 

It's a much easier time if the low-rank is a psychic, because Mindfray ignores cover/defense, and Mutons, Elites and Heavy Floaters have low Will. 

UGLY: 

I absolutely hate the panic check system. 
In UFO and TFTD, panic checks happened when morale gets low after psi attacks or losing many soldiers in a short space of time. 
Here, there is no morale bar. 
Panic checks happen when you shoot 2 out of 3 Muton types, take any damage, or a soldier dies. 
If one soldier fails a panic check, others also get a panic check. Because the Will stat starts out low, expect to see it a lot, especially on the harder difficulties. 

Combine this with the fewer soldiers, with each of them having one attack per turn without certain perks, you have a domino effect where a string of bad rolls gets your entire squad wiped because these hand-picked, elite soldiers are freaking out because one of them took 1 damage from Acid Spit. Long War doesn't make it much better.

Conclusion: Truly a fantastic game. I had never heard of XCOM until Firaxis took their crack at it. Thank you for introducing me to a fantastic series. Yes, it has problems, but even some of the limitations made some kind of sense. This is a game about following the spirit of XCOM, not the letter. Though I do still think the soldier cap is too low and the panic check system can bite me.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game that combines turn-based strategy and tactical combat in a thrilling sci-fi scenario. The game is a remake of the classic X-COM: UFO Defense, but with updated graphics, gameplay, and story. The game puts you in charge of a secret organization called XCOM, which is tasked with defending Earth from an alien invasion. You have to manage your base, research alien technology, train and equip your soldiers, and send them on missions around the world. The game is challenging and rewarding, as you have to make tough decisions and deal with the consequences of your actions. The game also has a multiplayer mode, where you can pit your squad against another player’s in a head-to-head battle.

The game’s strengths are its immersive atmosphere, its strategic depth, and its replay value. The game creates a sense of tension and urgency, as you never know when and where the aliens will strike next. The game also gives you a lot of freedom and customization options, as you can choose your base location, your research priorities, your soldier classes, and your tactics. The game has a lot of variety and randomness, as each mission is different and each alien encounter is unpredictable. The game also has a high difficulty level, which forces you to think carefully and adapt to changing situations. The game is not for the faint of heart, as you will face many losses and setbacks, and you will have to deal with the permanent death of your soldiers. The game is not linear, as you can choose different paths and outcomes, and the game has multiple endings depending on your performance. The game also has a lot of content and modes, as you can play the main campaign, the standalone expansion Enemy Within, the DLC Slingshot, or the multiplayer mode.

The game’s weaknesses are its technical issues, its interface, and its balance. The game has some bugs and glitches, such as crashes, freezes, and graphical errors. The game also has some performance problems, such as long loading times and frame rate drops. The game’s interface is not very user-friendly, as it can be confusing, cluttered, and unresponsive. The game also has some balance issues, such as some classes, skills, and items being overpowered or underpowered, some missions being too easy or too hard, and some enemies being too predictable or too unfair.

Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game that I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys strategy games, sci-fi games, or challenging games. The game is a masterpiece of game design, as it blends different genres and elements in a seamless and engaging way. The game is a tribute to the original X-COM, but also a modern and innovative game that stands on its own. The game is a game that will test your skills, your nerves, and your emotions, as you fight for the fate of humanity against a ruthless alien threat. The game is a game that will keep you hooked for hours, days, and weeks, as you explore, experiment, and experience its rich and diverse gameplay. The game is a game that you will not regret playing, as it will leave you with a sense of accomplishment, satisfaction, and awe. The game is a game that deserves a score of 9.5 out of 10.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a masterpiece that has stood the test of time. I was introduced to it by a friend, and I've never looked back. It's a game that grabs your attention and doesn't let go, making you say, "I ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ love this game." That's the kind of affection players develop for XCOM: Enemy Unknown.

This game is a must-play for anyone who appreciates strategy and tactics. It's a profound experience that keeps you engaged for hours on end. The gameplay is compelling, offering choices and customisation that make each playthrough feel unique. You can delve as deep as you want, immersing yourself in a modern twist on the X-Com legacy.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown captures the essence of probability. It's a game that teaches you that probability is just a number, and in this world, probability is anything but predictable. You'll quickly learn that God doesn't play dice, but XCOM does.

The game may appear as a simple turn-based strategy, but it's so much more. Whether you're a rookie or a seasoned player, XCOM: Enemy Unknown offers challenging and satisfying gameplay. While it might have some quirks and a few bugs, its allure remains intact, even after all these years.

The game is as good as ever, and its graphical style, though slightly cartoonish, still holds up well. And, for those looking to expand their experience, the "Enemy Within" DLC is a must-buy. It enriches the gameplay and fills the gaps, making the entire XCOM experience even more captivating.

Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is still fun, even years later. If you're into turn-based strategy games, this should be on your list.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a shining example of how a series can be freshened up, but still be as good as the classics. Many games have changed their core principles in order to earn an extra buck with a different audience, but XCOM keeps it real. Unrelenting, cool, and satisfying (but only because of how brutal the losses are).

The game does have it's shortcomings, however. Enemies may randomly spawn during a mission, and I'm left wondering about some of their design choices. For example, the unmanned weapons platform that can replace a soldier in your squad is criminally inaccurate, and it lacks the ability to use cover. The UFO vs. XCOM aircraft system is lame. The overall experience feels humorously unbalanced.

Love it to death, though.

Greetings always!  I have loved ‘XCOM: Enemy Unknown’ since I first played it on Console so I had no doubt I’d enjoy following up on this classic.  As always though time and experience concern me and found myself with trepidation at starting this game up again.  Was my hesitance well founded?  Let’s discuss!

Welcome Back, Commander:  Anyone who doesn’t know XCOM Enemy Unknown is a turn based squad tactics game that pits your team of expendable soldier’s verses an alien invasion.  At the core there isn’t much to explain; your soldiers alternate taking turns against AI controlled opponents in a atmosphere heavy but story light world that is challenging and rewarding.  There are a number of missions with stories in them but most of the game is going to be spent shooting down UFOs and clearing out towns under attack.  The reason a lot of this doesn’t sound too exciting is that this game was kind of what launched the renaissance of the tactics genre.

Tactically Timeless:  One thing I want to touch on is the level of modding on this game.  I did not play with any mods this time around but there are pretty much mods for anything you could want, it is truly a unique experience every game you start with modding.  The game also has almost endless content, even though the core game only has 4 classes you can unlock Robot assistants, the psychic sub-class and just play around with many different builds of characters.

Brought here to Lead, not Read:  My criticisms might be a bit more than I’d like but this comes from someone who absolutely loves this game but I have to acknowledge that most, if not all, of these criticisms probably have been addressed through mods of some kind.  If I had to settle on the one biggest issue is the customization of characters, there are effectively 3 things you cannot change (or determine, outside of re-rolling); Nationality, Sex and Class.  I get the intent to giving the characters a since of self but you let me change their voice, name and racial background…but changing their nationality is too much?  The second biggest issue I had was the inverted difficulty, I’m sure this isn’t the case on harder difficulties or for someone who doesn’t spend a dozen hours getting their soldiers exactly where I wanted them but it was kind of annoying that the beginning missions were the hardest.  You also can’t customize your SHIV and that would have been a nice addition.  Finally, movement placement can be a big pain, especially around ledges and when you accidently misclick a move it can be a death sentence for that soldier.

Overall, this game still holds up very well, though admittedly not as polished and effective as XCOM2 is but I still very much enjoyed the game.  I’d recommend it to anyone who (for some reason) has never played it and likes tactics style games.  Highly recommended, enjoy!

I played this to death and got all the achievements on Xbox back when it came out. It was a lot of fun to play again all these years later. In some ways this is actually better than XCom 2. It's more straightforward. Streamlined.

It's a very good game.  If you're familiar with the original, it's a re-imagining not a remake.  It's a lot more "gamey" as opposed to the sim-like original.  The campaign is more story driven.  The game is more simple overall.  You're encourage to build up a small elite squad as opposed to a large roster of cannon fodder like the original.  The bad thing about that is you simply can't afford to lose a high level trooper so there's a big incentive to save-scum.  This is especially true of harder difficulties and the Long War mod, which is much harder than the base game.  

One other thing I don't really like is the tendency for many different alien types on the same map.  The original was more thematic - for instance a given UFO would contain only sectoids or mutons rather than a menagerie of like 6 aliens.  I think they missed an opportunity to allow you to bring different weapons and tactics to different fights where the aliens would be fielding different combinations of units.  Instead, it's common for them to field EVERY type of alien in the same battle.    

However, in spite of everything being changed, I think they did a great job of staying true to the spirit of the original X-com.  Just dumbed down in every way for the masses.

Kill aliens, suffer for being a fool or in a hurry. Adapt and thrive or get probed.. Classic on Ironman, perfect balance! Tough, but if you keep your cool and adapt to changing circumstances, and make the most of your resources- you can stage a comeback!

Xcom is an utter master class in turn-based tactical squad command and has become a genre in and of itself.

Where the game shines: 
1)The story is generally interesting and has been mostly copied 1-to-1 in almost all other games made within the genre. I'll go into more detail on the story toward the end with spoilers 
2) mechanics are smooth and deeply enjoyable
3) customisation option cause you to form bonds with those under your command. 
4) interesting base building elements mean you can play slightly differently every time!
5) maintaining public order is of importance! If the people start to panic your mysterious benefactor may loose faith in the project and pull support
6) Difficulty is enjoyable and well scaled with time!
7) game environments are unique and well designed! From open rural areas to the hearts of cities or even inside UFOs! 
8) the Game concept is fantastic and perfectly well executed. You're a commander looking down on your people, during your turn you issue commands. Move here! Shoot this! Keep a look out and shoot anything that moves (called overwatch)! The map is shrouded in a fog of war, if your people can't see it, you can't see it! 
9) it has an interesting mechanic where you have to scramble aircraft of your own to intercept and crash hostile UFOs. You then have to mobilise your team to kill the UFOs occupants and claim the tech for the project. 
10) multiple objectives! In some missions you have to:
- Just kill all the hostiles
- in some you have to protect and evacuate civilians from a war zone. The aliens may engage in terrorism in an attempt to break humanities spirit (because if recent history is anything to go by that always works so well on humans *sarcastic eye roll*)
- Protect and escort people of interest back to HQ
- Capture grounded UFOs and their tech. Its similar to just killing hostiles but you have to be careful not to damage the valuable tech you plan to capture
- side quests: taking an alien back to base alive for further testing

Where the game falls short:
1) as joked about by other reviews, 99% accuracy isn't as certain as it may seem! It sometimes feels like you get unlucky more than just chance should allow. 
2) There are a variety of awesome environments to play in but the UFO assaults specifically can get kind of tedious. This is causes by two factors:

Before this game, I only had experience with real-time strategy games. XCOM was my first foray into the world of turn-based strategy, and thus I certainly don't have the knowledge to claim it as the best in its genre. However, I can confidently state that my experience with this game has been exceptional.

The sci-fi plot revolves around an alien invasion threatening life on Earth. We assume the role of XCOM, a secret military organization tasked with countering these alien incursions. While the game doesn't prioritize narrative as its core focus, the storyline, though straightforward, unfolds in an engaging manner, presenting intriguing elements that demand constant reflection. The narrative build-up also leads to a pleasantly surprising twist at the end.

XCOM sets itself apart with its depth of gameplay, offering management mechanics as well. We can expand our base by digging underground and constructing new structures, hiring scientists and engineers to conduct research and develop weapons, armor, vehicles, and more. Managing global panic is crucial to secure monthly funding for our project. Refusing to intervene in alien attacks can lead to losing support from allied nations, reducing our available resources. This aspect of the game requires careful planning to ensure long-term success.

The control room, represented by an enormous globe, stands out as one of the most intriguing features. Activating it initiates monitoring of alien activity on Earth, with every second representing a day of research. Managing time wisely becomes crucial for completing projects and research since they require real-time progress. The presence of alien activities necessitates our immediate intervention, which is carried out through captivating turn-based battles.

The combat system, while turn-based, offers a variety of challenges and strategic opportunities. Instead of commanding large armies, we lead a group of up to six soldiers. Customizing equipment, including weapons, armor, and accessories, adds an additional layer of tactical involvement.

The post-combat reward system is well-structured: by recovering alien corpses and weapons, we can exploit alien technology to our advantage, reproducing advanced weapons or developing new devices. The ability to engage UFOs in flight adds an exciting component, with vehicle and weapon choices being crucial for mission success.

While XCOM is an outstanding title, some technical imperfections are evident. Occasionally, soldiers may aim at an alien but shoot in the opposite direction, still hitting the target. These moments can be amusing but are clearly flaws in the game.

Another issue lies with the BERSERKER, a type of enemy that causes game slowdowns while walking. Fortunately, this bug does not affect missions.

In conclusion, XCOM proves to be an exceptional experience and comes highly recommended for turn-based strategy enthusiasts and even those with experience only in real-time strategy games. The title is equally perfect for newcomers to the genre. The depth of gameplay, management mechanics, and thrilling battles make XCOM an engaging and captivating gaming experience.

[h1] XCOM Enemy Unknown: A Great Foundation for Future Adventures [/h1]

Rating: ★★★½

XCOM Enemy Unknown is a game that stands as a remarkable testament to the enduring legacy of turn-based strategy games. With its intricate gameplay mechanics, engaging story, and immersive atmosphere, it successfully reignites the excitement of classic alien invasion narratives while delivering a solid foundation for the franchise's future installments.

One of the most commendable aspects of XCOM Enemy Unknown is its strategic depth. As the commander of an elite paramilitary organization tasked with defending Earth from extraterrestrial threats, players must carefully manage resources, deploy troops, and make difficult decisions that have far-reaching consequences. The blend of base management, research, and tactical combat creates a sense of urgency and tension that keeps players on the edge of their seats.

The game's combat mechanics are particularly noteworthy. The turn-based battles provide a satisfying balance between strategic planning and unpredictable outcomes. Each encounter presents players with tough choices and tactical dilemmas, forcing them to consider cover positions, flanking opportunities, and the effective use of various soldier classes. The sense of satisfaction that comes from executing a well-coordinated assault or narrowly escaping a deadly ambush is truly unmatched.

While XCOM Enemy Unknown excels in many areas, it falls just short of perfection. The graphics, while functional and serviceable, lack the visual polish and detail that would elevate the game to the next level. Additionally, the occasional technical hiccups and AI quirks can occasionally disrupt the immersion, albeit to a minor extent.

Nonetheless, XCOM Enemy Unknown lays the groundwork for an exceptional gaming experience. Its success in revitalizing the turn-based strategy genre is undeniable, and it paves the way for even greater adventures in subsequent titles. With its addictive gameplay loop, compelling narrative, and engaging mechanics, this game stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of strategic decision-making and tactical combat.

In summary, XCOM Enemy Unknown is a great base for things to come. While it may have a few minor shortcomings, its overall package is undeniably captivating. Fans of the genre will find themselves engrossed in the challenging battles, tense decision-making, and captivating narrative. With three and a half stars, it's a strong recommendation for both strategy enthusiasts and alien invasion aficionados alike.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown, developed by Firaxis Games, is a strategic masterpiece that revitalizes the iconic XCOM franchise. With its deep tactical gameplay, challenging strategic choices, and immersive atmosphere, Enemy Unknown stands as a true gem in the realm of turn-based strategy games.

One of the standout features of XCOM: Enemy Unknown is its addictive and engaging tactical gameplay. Players assume the role of the commander of XCOM, a global defense organization tasked with defending Earth against a mysterious alien threat. The game seamlessly combines turn-based combat with strategic base management, creating a dynamic and rewarding experience. Each mission presents players with strategic choices, such as positioning their squad members, utilizing cover, and selecting the most effective abilities to counter the alien forces. The depth of tactical options and the ever-present risk-reward decisions keep players on the edge of their seat, making every encounter a thrilling and strategic endeavor.

The strategic layer of XCOM: Enemy Unknown adds another layer of depth and immersion to the gameplay. As the commander, players are responsible for managing the XCOM headquarters, researching new technologies, developing weapons and armor, and training their soldiers. The ability to customize and level up squad members, as well as build and expand the base, provides a sense of progression and personal investment. The strategic choices made outside of combat directly impact the outcome of battles, creating a cohesive and immersive gameplay loop.

Visually, XCOM: Enemy Unknown delivers a gritty and atmospheric experience. The game's environments are meticulously designed, from the desolate urban landscapes to the eerie alien structures. The attention to detail in character models, animations, and special effects adds to the immersion, capturing the intensity of the battles and the high stakes of the conflict. The sound design is equally impressive, with atmospheric soundscapes, intense combat effects, and a fitting musical score that heightens the tension and drama of the gameplay.

The narrative in XCOM: Enemy Unknown is engaging and compelling. The game combines global strategy with personal narratives of individual soldiers, creating a sense of attachment and investment in their stories. The game's well-crafted storyline unfolds through mission briefings, cutscenes, and in-game events, keeping players engaged and motivated to save humanity from the alien threat. The sense of urgency, the moral dilemmas, and the unexpected twists and turns add depth and emotional weight to the gameplay experience.

Furthermore, XCOM: Enemy Unknown offers a high level of replayability. The game features a branching campaign with multiple difficulty levels, allowing players to tailor the experience to their skill level and preferences. The procedurally generated maps, random events, and the ability to customize squads and soldiers offer endless variations and strategic possibilities. Additionally, the game's modding community provides a wealth of user-generated content, extending the longevity and enjoyment of the game even further.

In conclusion, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a strategic masterpiece that combines deep tactical gameplay, challenging choices, and an immersive atmosphere. Its addictive and engaging gameplay, alongside its visually stunning presentation and compelling narrative, make it a standout title in the turn-based strategy genre. Whether you're a fan of the XCOM franchise or a newcomer to the series, Enemy Unknown offers an unforgettable experience filled with tactical brilliance, strategic decision-making, and the thrill of defending humanity against an alien invasion. Prepare to take command, lead your squad, and save the world in the face of overwhelming odds.

I have been playing the original X-COM: UFO Defense since 1994, back on an old IBM PS/2. When this reboot game was announced, I was jazzed and hoping to snag a copy with a bonus. Imagine my surprise when I booted up Steam and my brother had gifted me a pre-order copy as a gift because he was just as jazzed about the game as I was.

11 years and many play-throughs on at least 4 different systems (PC, 360, PS3 and PS4) later, I can honestly say this is one of the best strategy games I have ever played. I am consistently presented with challenging scenarios, impossible odds, and the lure of that shiny alien tech. Every game is a mad blitz to the overseer, with the same excitement I felt as I was playing the original back in 1994 at 6 years old. Of course, I have a much firmer grasp on strategy now, but I'm still no wizard.

We all have those games where we have a special moment. For me, it was the conclusion of my first playthrough. Madeline "The Missionary" Roux, a sniper from Canada, ended up being my volunteer. The impact of the sacrifice made the game's gravity shift, and I have to say... I loved it.

The gameplay is pretty solid. Battling EXALT, aliens and public opinion in and of itself is a delicate balancing act. Strategy applies to more than mere combat maps. You have to strategize every step of the way. What continent should my base be on? Should I buy that Officer Training School upgrade? Would I be better served launching the satellite in France or Australia? Do I have enough interceptors to handle a large UFO? These are the decisions the Commander of the XCOM force must make.

Multiplayer is surprisingly fun, and surprisingly still up! (Which is weird, because XCOM 2's multiplayer servers are down for Windows, but still up for Linux and Mac.) The point-buy system of the multiplayer balances things out wonderfully and creates infinite strategy, a never-ending list of combinations to try, and a new thrill every time you match with someone in the lobby.

Graphics can be hauntingly beautiful in this game. Watch an Outsider emerge upon contact, or an Ethereal mind control your soldier with the highest will. Watch the car explode after being hit by a stray laser or plasma round. Take it in as the Muton beats its chest. Crap your pants the first time a Chryssalid gores an unsuspecting civillian and then... well, you know. Admire the craftsmanship that the graphics designers put into this game.

Sound is decent, and it got even better with the Enemy Within expansion. I really love the touches of the soldiers from various countries being able to respond to orders in their native languages, and the effects are top notch. The voice acting is superb, and all of the VAs did a fantastic job... even the one for Dr. Vahlen, though I have never quite pinned down if she's meant to be German, Austrian, Swiss, what have you (the accent varies occasionally).

Controls are pretty basic on PC. You point. You click. Keyboard shortcuts exist, but are largely not necessary. I do utilize a handful, but it's primarily because they line up perfectly with the keyboard macros from my day job. I can rest my hand in the same location of my keyboard in order to react. It doesn't get much simpler or more intuitive than this.

Overall, this game is a modern classic. Every serious gamer should have a strategy game in their library, and this is a stand-out choice in the genre. Those with tactical prowess and those without (like me!) can both appreciate a game that was crafted with a deep, obvious love by the developer. It's a hell of a challenge, but I don't want the 350 hours of my life I spent earning all 85 achievements back. That final achievement is my proudest gaming accomplishment, and I have no regrets (except the facepalming during my impossible campaign).

Note: this review has been edited from its original posting.  I have since cleared up all the achievements in the game, and I rank this game even more highly now than I did then.

BTW, this review is for both Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within, which come packaged together. And I'd recommend playing both, in that order.

Overall they're both fun though slightly flawed games. The turn based strategy is both exciting and relaxing as you can play at your own pace. 

The base building and tech research 'mini game' is a fun diversion in the game which allows another level of strategy and customization of your characters, to whom you'll get really attached. The story is servicable if not great.


Minor Gripes:
-The camera in Enemy Unknown is fixed which is a bit annoying, but there is a mod which unlocks the camera which I'd highly recommend. Enemy Within fixes this and updates the graphics. 

-The Save Game system is obtuse. It likes to overwrite your saves. See solution below.

-Sometimes the RNG can seem a bit unfair. So save manually at the start of every map, when your characters are on the ground and you have not yet moved. Do this again *every* time you reload a save game. 

-The Engineering Build/Buy menu where you buy armor and weapons and ships etc, will tell you the materials requirement to say build one plasma rifle but does not tell you how many of said materials you already have. So you'll have to do a little menu toggling. 

-Some positions appear to have line of sight to a target but don't. Use the camera mod mentioned above to move the camera to make sure you have a shot, and you'll get the hang of it pretty quickly.


Conclusion:
Overall the complaints are minor and the gameplay is fun and engaging with good enough graphics and great immersion. Often on sale at great discounts and presents a terrific value. If you haven't played this type of game, I recommend you start here.

Prepare to have your strategic prowess put to the ultimate test with the brilliantly crafted and utterly addictive game, XCOM. As the commander of a global military organization, you'll find yourself engaged in a thrilling battle against otherworldly adversaries. This game seamlessly blends turn-based combat, base management, research, and resource allocation, delivering an immersive and intellectually stimulating experience that will keep you hooked for hours.

XCOM's gameplay offers an exceptional challenge that will put your decision-making skills to the ultimate test. Each mission is a heart-pounding tactical encounter where every move you make carries tremendous weight. Whether it's calculating the perfect positioning, utilizing cover effectively, or deploying a myriad of unique abilities, you'll need to outsmart the cunning alien enemies at every turn. The difficulty level ensures that every victory is hard-fought, leaving you with an immense sense of accomplishment when you overcome seemingly insurmountable odds.

Adding an extra layer of excitement and emotional investment, XCOM introduces a permadeath system that will make you think twice about each and every decision you make. The loss of a well-trained soldier can be absolutely devastating, tugging at your heartstrings and creating a genuine attachment to your virtual comrades. But fear not! The ability to customize and upgrade your squad members allows you to forge a personal connection with your team, making every victory all the more satisfying.

XCOM's turn-based action is nothing short of genius, putting your strategic thinking to the test in the most delightful way possible. With each carefully calculated move, you'll experience a rollercoaster of emotions, from exhilaration to nail-biting tension. The game strikes the perfect balance between challenge and entertainment, keeping you engaged and invested throughout your mission to save humanity.

In summary, XCOM is an absolute triumph in the world of strategy games. Its deep and engaging tactical gameplay, combined with its challenging yet rewarding difficulty level, will keep you coming back for more. The inclusion of a permadeath system adds a layer of tension and emotional attachment rarely seen in the genre. With its smart and addictive turn-based action, XCOM is an absolute must-play for any strategy enthusiast. So grab your tactical gear, rally your troops, and get ready to command, and conquer

A very fun, though at times frustrating turn-based strategy game. It is kind of difficult in the beginning, when you don't know what you're doing and a small mistake can mean you screw yourself over permanently. But once you get the hang of it, the permanent danger keeps you on the edge of your seat! You really can never fall behind on upgrading your squad, and need to train at least a couple backup soldiers for when your main squad is hurt. Because at some point, rookies will be nothing more than a liability.

The random nature of the "dice roll attacks" will always be a source of frustration, but as a seasoned D&D player it's nothing new to me and just part of the game. There are also plenty of visual glitches, but honestly I usually thought they were more funny than annoying. It's not like the game is very immersive anyway. I do love how you can completely customize your soldiers though, and have a self-insert character etc. 

I definitely recommend it for fans of turn-based strategy and the classic alien / UFO asthetics!

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game that's heavily influenced by the book and movie LIVE DIE REPEAT. Both follow the story of a group of soldiers fighting against an overwhelming enemy. The main goal is to survive and advance, and the strategies used to do so are fairly similar.

In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, you are tasked with managing a global defense initiative against an alien threat. You have limited resources to build your base, train and equip your soldiers, and research new weapons and technologies to help keep the aliens at bay. Combat can sometimes be overwhelming, with more powerful enemies rapidly appearing out of nowhere. But focusing on efficient strategies and conserving resources can help turn the tide of battle.

The game is unforgiving; any wrong move can have dire consequences, making it easy to lose a battle. But the game rewards those who think carefully and use what they have wisely. Just like in LIVE DIE REPEAT, there’s a limited window of opportunity to make your last stand against the enemy while making the most out of the limited resources you have.

Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown provides a captivating experience that captures what made LIVE DIE REPEAT so memorable. The game not only gives you plenty of strategic depth but also offers plenty of replay value thanks to procedurally generated maps and random missions. Even after several playthroughs, the game still remains challenging and rewarding, making it one of the best tactical strategy games released in recent years.

I'm sure to some this feels really interesting, but to me it feels like whether I win or fail doesn't really matter other than the nebulous "panic levels".
> This game does not have a good tutorial. I'm generally not a fan of games where the best "tutorial" is a friend who's trying to help you out rather than the game itself. Weird unexplained mechanics galore.
> I can't really tell where the "tactics" choices are in this game. I was expecting missions that resembled more like puzzles -- there are a bunch of ways to tackle the objective, and you get to choose how you get through the mission. Instead the "tactics" seem to just be saving the game repeatedly, reloading when something doesn't go your way, and playing extremely cautious lest an alien spawn right next to your soldiers. I don't like savescumming, and it feels like you get punished hard if you don't.
> The interface and UX is terrible. It's really not that hard to have a movement spot follow your cursor, but this game seems to delight in how far off you often need to aim to hit a certain spot. Some elements that seem clickable aren't, and vice versa.
> When you're bound to fail a mission, you fail hard. And the game forces you to watch it all unfold right in front of you. I was in a "rescue civilians" mission, and it started okay, but eventually too many civilians got turned into zombies. I spent a minute watching the zombies and the walker guy just... kill my soldiers. Can't fast forward, can't skip, just watch them die in real time. Sure, really sets the dire mood the game seems to be going for. Also isn't fun.

Xcom - Enemy Unknown is a turn-based strategy game that puts you in charge of a squad of elite soldiers tasked with defending Earth against an alien invasion. As a fan of the original UFO Enemy Unknown game, I was excited to try this modern reimagining. While the game doesn't quite live up to the original, it's still a worthwhile buy for any strategy game enthusiast.

One of the strengths of Xcom - Enemy Unknown is its engaging gameplay. The turn-based combat system is intuitive and strategic, and the game offers a variety of classes and abilities to customize your soldiers and build your squad. The game also features a base-building mechanic, where you must manage resources and research new technologies to stay ahead of the alien threat.

However, Enemy Unknown does fall short of the original UFO Enemy Unknown game in some aspects. The gameplay is not quite as addictive and memorable, and the atmosphere is not as intense.

That being said, Xcom - Enemy Unknown is still a solid strategy game that offers hours of challenging and enjoyable gameplay. The game's graphics and sound design are impressive, and the strategic depth and replayability make it a worthwhile purchase for any fan of the genre.

While it did drag a bit at the end, it was a fun challenge and one that I would easily recommend... if not for the gamebreaking bugs that plague the entire series. For me, XCOM is a series about achieving a near-impossible task of overthrowing a full-scale alien invasion, which is why I enjoy the permanence of playing on ironman. But when I get hit by a bug that causes a sectopod to mow down all my experienced troops several dozen hours into a campaign, it's hard for me to enjoy the journey that is the rest. And, while I did not encounter them this time, I know that there are other bugs that can softlock the game entirely or otherwise corrupt saves during critical story missions. XCOM is not some indi game published by a small studio that can't be bothered to fix such gamebreaking issues; 2K has had ample time to fix these well-documented complaints. Even for a game I personally enjoy as much as XCOM, I cannot give it a recommendation when it's still being sold at full price by a studio with no intention of fixing such problems.

Thankfully, someone told me to buy the game on PC and I freaking loved it.  It almost felt like this game had ironed out all the problems I had with its sequel.

-Even if you make  mistake, you can recover with a good strategy.

Cons:

-Some enemies who a VERY strong enemies are thrown in at "awkward" moments (for lack of a better term)  and felt more like a difficulty spike as opposed to a natural progression.

This game can be so frustrating at times but once you understand how to play and start to get used to it, then every win will feel so rewarding (unless you lose your favourite soldier).
If you want to buy this then you need to be prepared for a lot of bs and suffering early on, and it won't go away but you will learn to overcome it and that's why this game is fun.

This is a remake of 1993 XCOM UFO Defense which is very well done yet lacks some strategic depth of the original. 

The good: 
- in many things, the game tries to stay very close to the original 
- more alient types, including heavily armored robots 
- all aliens and your soldiers have new special abilities 
- more weapon types, including shotguns 
- great music, some tracks remind Deus Ex Human Revolution 
- great graphics 
- the story is accompanied with many cutscenes and voiced comments from your staff, which helps build drama 
- great detailed tutorial 
- mind control requires the target to be in sight (no more mind controls at the very first turn) 
- you can research additional upgrades to weapons and other things in the Foundry building 

The so-so: 
- 2 action points instead of 50-70 like in the original, soldiers normally just walk once and shoot once. This takes away some depth yet makes you camp less 
- can only take 6 soldiers in a mission instead of 14 -> faster turns but fewer tactical options 
- night missions have the same visibility as daytime ones, no flares -> easier, but micromanaging flares was fun and night missions used to be real challenge 
- a strange cover system: when a mob is behind an edge of a wall, it still can be shot at, yet with a high penalty. Most battlefields are filled with tree logs, groups of stones, stairs-like elevation levels which makes the battles mostly about running from cover to cover and staying on Overwatch 
- critical hits are important -> more randomness 
- soldiers have no stats (which grew from "usage"), instead the game randomly assigns them to specializations (sniper, heavy, assault, support). Specializations offer a few special abilities though 
- after getting max rank ("Colonel"), soldiers won't improve anymore (only psi abilities, if they have psionic powers), which doesn't let you train super-ninzas and forces you to send new soldiers to let them train as well 
- a few new types of missions which are heavily scripted and linear, usually with a turn limit 
- can only build facilities in one base, no storage limit, no ammo -> less micromanagement but feels too casual 
- mobs' facing doesn't play any role: they see equally well all around them, and attacks from behind don't inflict more damage (though usually a mob won't have a covering object behind it and will be considered "flanked") 
- no arctic/desert/jungle maps but many varied urban maps
- a soldier can take just 1 extra item (e.g.1 grenade) in addition to main weapon and pistol 

The bad: 
- most battles are scripted and not randomly generated. Enemies appear when you pass trigger tiles and take a free move to get behind cover right after they appeared. Some fall directly from above (out of thin air) behind your troops, switching to Overwatch and pinning all your soldiers down. Some will run very close to you, all while you're waiting for their animation to finish. This takes away much strategic feeling as all your battle plans are trampled by script. Worse, it makes playing on higher difficulty or iron man mode pointless, as it feels unfair to lose when you didn't know in advance a scripted situation
- camera always tries to zoom in on the next selected soldiers which is very annoying if you want to keep camera zoomed out for a tactical overwiev 
- camera sometimes fails to correctly detect the tile under the cursor -> it may take many attempts to open a door with V key (and rotate the camera for that a lot), or sometimes the solder will run to a wrong tile which is on a different floor and visually behind the one you wish to go to 
- if a soldier sees an enemy during movement he doesn't stop and can even lose sight of the enemy by the end of the move (it was the same in the original XCOM but there you could walk tile-by-tile, and in JA2 soldiers stopped when seeing a new enemy) 
- no base defense missions 
- although everything is destructible you can't shoot at objects, except if your weapon misses an alien and hits an object instead, or you throw a grenade or fire a rocket launcher

A very successful remake of the original X-COM game in 1994, this epic remake maintains the core concepts and elements while redesigning and simplifying them. The majority of excessive details and vast areas of free choice were removed, e.g. Time Units, RPG-like inventory slots, ammunition items, free selection of multiple bases, and their layouts. The player, therefore, has a limited pattern of actions and fewer choices, but it somehow became more convenient to play and less fastidious, especially suitable for non-old school fans. Some elements, like alien races, were redesigned or even reimagined.Several new mechanics introduced in this remake are considerably inventive. For instance, the cover stance and soldier classes offer a totally different experience for old X-COM fans. Unlike remastered products, this is a whole new game worth playing.The storyline is slightly altered but mainly enhanced to become more cinematic. Characters with decent names, histories, dialogues, and cutscenes bring the events of the first X-COM to life again in a more lively way. The background music is also greatly appreciable.This remake is much different from the 1994 original version, but it is well-made and still very addictive, thus becoming another pièce de résistance of the franchise itself. Extremely addictive.
