FIrstly, I want to point out that this game is enjoyable on a PC with Linux and Intel (10th Gen) integrated graphics, I wouldn't have a chance to experience it if it wasn't as optimised. This was possible only due to 2K/Feral making Linux ports, so that it can run natively, and not through emulation/Wine/Proton.

What I really like about it is the atmosphere and the ambient. Battles take place over thematically-unique areas each time, each with their own visuals that feel more like real places than playing fields, which accentuates the feeling of going all over the world to fight aliens. I'm amazed by the way the game mechanics work — even though the playing field looks two-dimensional, it is soon revealed that line-of-sight, elevation and projectile trajectories make the player consider the whole aspect of the terrain. I LOVE how the terrain is destructible, and in ways that affect the gameplay (holes in the walls offer new paths of movement, for example), this feels really ahead of its time for this game. Units gain experience over time, and become irreplaceable part of the squad, but the threat of losing a unit due to bad positioning, or merely bad luck, is ever-present, so one tries really hard to find a way to get everyone to survive. Also, "random encounter" missions pop-up every so often, with unique objectives, which makes for some unique situations which make the gameplay diverse.

There are some small things that I dislike about the game: the whole base-building part of the game feels tedious at moments, because it always feels resource-constrained, like you're on your last dollars when buying weapons and facilities, and you have to wait until the next "paycheck" to make further purchases and upgrades. I'd much prefer a system where there is no base-building aspect, but you rather get facilities by progressing through the story, and get money from every mission you successfully complete. That, and the micromanagement of the gear between soldiers are some of the aspects that need quality-of-life improvements (that are hopefully present in the next games in the series). Thankfully, nothing major or game-breaking.

XCOM is a game that I should enjoy. I love this genre of game typically. Final Fantasy Tactics (PS1) is one of my favorite games to have ever been developed. I really enjoy the theme and game play of tactical RPGs that both XCOM and FFT are designed around.

What I don't like is the extreme unexplained difficulty spike that occurs at some point during XCOM, and just about every version of it, I've played more than one of them. I do not have the patience, nor time, to waste dozens of hours researching the best way to play the game on wiki sites and trial and error involved with developing the right team. The game is simply not approachable for the average user. The game NEVER explains at ANY point why the difficulty just happens to sky rocket. You complete several missions and it's all fun, your squad is leveling up and gaining ranks, unlocking new abilities, you learn new tech and upgrade their equipment, then, randomly, the next mission you go on, the aliens absolutely wreck you. If your team makes it out alive, they are all gravely wounded. Healing them in fights doesn't matter either, even if they all leave the level with full health after getting injured, they'll be wounded on the after mission report.

The worst part is, you can't recover from mistakes.  If you hit the difficulty spikes and your team gets wiped out, you are screwed.  You likely don't have another full squad of experienced soldiers.  You can't grind up some other soldiers doing random battles either.  The game moves on.  Your next mission will be the same level of difficulty, or harder.  Only this time, you won't have your experienced soldiers anymore.  You have to load an earlier save file, or restart entirely.  THAT'S NOT FUN.

The 'get gud' crowd can ignore this review, because ya'll don't get it anyway. I'm not a stranger to difficult games. I've mastered the Souls games and Elden Ring, among others. Those games are fair, it's your fault when you lose. XCOM isn't fair, it just rapes you when it's ready to do so, without telling you what you did to trigger it.

Passed that, the game mechanics are fun, other than the difficulty; sound design is good; visuals are good, not great, but its a 7 year old game now. I know a lot of people will pick up these old games after hearing from their friends or online reviews that they are worth purchasing during a Steam sale, but I don't believe this one is. It's on sale right now for $6 USD. Knowing what I know now, I wouldn't buy it for even that price.

I know there are a lot of rabidly devoted XCOM fans out there. This is your game, enjoy it. I don't care, it's not for me.

I originally played the Microprose classic in 1994 and was instantly hooked by what is now widely regarded as one of the best games ever released. The complexity blended with comic book visuals made for a unique experience that was much tougher and deeper than the cover art on the box would have suggested. It was a delightful experience that the run of sequels and spinoffs through the late 90s and early 2000s failed to live up to. 

Along came the remake, streamlined for console play and sadly lacking in the depth and complexity of the original, I felt somewhat let down playing the more action oriented Enemy Unknown and Enemy Within updates when I finally got around to playing them.

Let down, that is, until I applied the brilliant Long War mod and was returned to the brutal struggle for survival against a mysterious alien invasion where the survival of our species hangs on every sniper bullet and panicked run across an open space while shadowy extraterrestrials with vastly superior weaponry lurk in the fog beyond the known.

Long War is the XCom that fans of the classic game wanted, and it delivers in every way that the remake did not in its attempt to be more accessible. Strategy/tactics simulators of the past didn't attempt to appeal to action gaming enthusiasts, they were the domain of history nerds and chess aficionados. The deep statistical play of the Koei franchises didn't do much for players who just wanted to pew-pew their way to victory, they brought you into a world of real warfare, where a single turn of serendipity can turn a winning campaign into an utter disaster regardless of how well planned and perfectly executed your strategy is.

No plan survives first contact with the enemy, and in Long War you'll learn that in a way that strategy players haven't often been able to experience since first booting up the ocean of spreadsheets old time war simulators were based on. In Long War no plan will see the other side of any engagement, and if you want to tear victory from the jaws of certain defeat you better have a contingency plan for your 10th contingency, because fate is a fickle adversary and the gods sit waiting to laugh as you detail your plans for victory. 

In the first XCom game brought to our bulky CRT screens in the 1990s we felt the fear of the uncertain. We watched as our star soldiers, groomed through hours of gruelling combat got butchered like plump hogs on the abattoir floor when a single moment of hubris unravelled 40 hours of meticulous preparation. Long War brings back that experience, where caution and bravado must dance the delicate ballet of warfare and heroes are born on the ashes of bellowing fools with each knuckle biting moment of unrelenting bloodshed.

Long War is indeed a long war, and one you'll be better for having fought in the event you manage to scrape victory out of the hands of fate with determination, grit and at least a little bit of sheer luck.

If you want to play XCom the way we knew it before 3D graphics and high def flat screens find Long War on Nexus and get comfortable for the beating you're about to endure. Better than the improved graphics and shiny interface Fraxis used to replace deep tactical mechanics, you'll almost smell the blood and cordite on the field of battle while you struggle to survive an invasion by a technologically superior menace that attacks you unprepared while politicians bicker over how much investment a true existential threat deserves.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is one of the best strategy games I've ever played, the game focuses on protecting the Earth from an alien threat, in this game you'll play as the commander in charge of XCOM, a multi-government funded project with the purpose of eliminating any extraterrestrial threats. When aliens invade you'll have to give orders to your troops to take back Earth, but be careful, if one of your soldiers die, they're dead for good, adding a nice big risk reward system to every move you make. There is also a base building aspect to add additional strategy for what you want to unlock. The story is compelling, graphics are great and the gameplay is excellent, and if you're worrying about the big fat M for Mature on the box, it's only really for two specific instenses during the beginning tutorial mission, the rest of the game is pretty similar in gore to the sequel, XCOM 2 which is rated T for Teen. Also according to IMDb, your soldiers can say "f*ck", but I never heard it once in a whole 32.2 hours long playthrough of the game, and since 2.5 hour long PG-13 films get to use it once, I wouldn't really worry about it. Now if your thinking of getting the DLC "Enemy Within", then do it, it adds so much more to an already great game, like Gene mods and MEC troopers, with some new aliens to fight too, and for "Slingshot", it adds 3 connected missions and not much else, so that's really up to you. So, if after reading this, you wanna help save Earth, then I highly recommend this game. Also it's pretty much the same gameplay wise to Mario + Rabbids, so if you like those games, why not check out this one.

I will definitely be playing the DLC (Enemy Within) and will most likely check out its sequals (XCOM 2 and Chimera Squad) as well. I can't recommend this game. I played hundreds of hours in this game's sequel, XCOM2, and I wanted to give it's predecessor a chance, but for technical issues (I'm using a 2560x1080 monitor for this), I couldn't do more than an hour of it. While back in 2012 this game might have been fine, in 2023 the UI just doesn't seem to work with wide-screen monitors. The game gets incredibly zoomed at the XCOM base for certain menus, such as when viewing soldiers for example. In addition, I've noticed my mouse position doesn't actually match up where the game thinks my mouse is (If I hover over a tile, the game will select a tile about 3-4 tiles away instead. Also, it feels as if this game was designed to be used on controllers only (which it probably was, considering this game is also on PS3 and Xbox 360), considering due to the aforementioned mouse issues, I was forced to use the arrows on my keyboard to navigate most of the menus. There might be mods that fix these issues, but as far as the base game without mods is concerned, these issues prevent me from finishing the game.

If you really want to get into XCOM, just get XCOM 2 instead (Or even Chimera Squad if you want to get a smaller, different XCOM experience for a lower price), it's much more polished in comparison and it runs perfectly fine on modern systems (Along with modding support for both games if you want to try out mods). If you're worried about story and things getting spoiled by playing the sequel first, don't be. Due to lore reasons, almost everything that happened in XCOM: Enemy Unknown is basically irrelevant in the sequel. You're not missing anything by playing the sequel first.

Remember those childhood video games where the alien invaders were so stupid you could knock their technological heads off with a simple throw of your gun at their little rat face? Oh wait, those never existed. But they’re here now. No, that’s not right. We’re here now. Not them. I mean the alien invaders. They’re here and they’re being stupid.

XCOM Enemy Unknown doesn’t even attempt to use the former as an insult. Rather, it embraces the latter and applies it to all levels of the game. You can kill the stupid alien overlords who were sent here by God himself but they will still try to blow you up with plasma lasers. You can take out the smart alien leaders but they’ll try to outmaneuver you. And so on and so forth.

So if you’re looking for the deepest, darkest theme of ‘the good guys always win in Xcom’, then you’ll be disappointed. Instead, you get the platitudes of ‘We always win’ and the usual ‘Be the bad guy’ sentiment that other strategy games tout in their quest to sell you the same crap.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an excellent turn-based tactical RPG that's a lot of fun to play. The game has a deep and strategic combat system, with a variety of units and abilities to choose from. The controls are tight and responsive, and the game has a good difficulty curve that keeps things challenging but not frustrating.
One of the standout features of XCOM: Enemy Unknown is its character customization. The game lets you customize your soldiers with a variety of different skills and abilities, allowing you to tailor your team to your playstyle. It's a fun and innovative gameplay mechanic that adds a lot of depth to the game.
The graphics in XCOM: Enemy Unknown are excellent, with detailed character models and environments. The game's music and sound effects are also top-notch, adding to the atmosphere.
One downside to XCOM: Enemy Unknown is that the game can be a bit repetitive. You'll be doing a lot of the same actions over and over again, and the levels can start to feel a bit samey after a while. That being said, the game has a high replay value, and you'll probably find yourself coming back to it again and again.
Overall, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an excellent turn-based tactical RPG that's a lot of fun to play. Its deep combat system and character customization make it a game that's worth checking out. The occasional repetitive gameplay can be a bit of an issue, but it doesn't really impact the overall enjoyment of the game. If you're a fan of turn-based tactical RPGs, you should definitely give XCOM: Enemy Unknown a try.

It's a solid turn-based game but a terrible X-COM game. Fraxis streamlined it too much and the focus on combat balance harmed other aspects. It's a travesty that a game made in 1993 had deeper combat mechanics than a modern one. You had night missions in UFO, where aliens could see more than you so there was a need to use flares or molotovs. Action-Point system allowed for more flexibility when it came to running and shooting. Different modes of firing each weapon(Should I snap a shot at the alien then runaway? Or try to empty the entire clip?) whereas in Enemy Unknown there's only one way to use your weapons. There's also too much limitations on inventory. Soldiers having to choose between having a medkit or grenade is just dumb. One of the tactics in UFO was to use an array of smoke grenades to make way for your offense. In Enemy Unknown only a specific class can throw smoke grenades and he can only do it in limited times. I don't even want to talk about the "Fate of the world rests in your hand but you can only send 4 ppl at a time"...
Yeah it's more challenging, the older games had this problem of getting too easy in late-game, but EU with trench warfare being the only way to win has sucked the fun out of the game.

I'm an old XCOM fan.
Hell, I'm an old UFO fan. UFO: Enemy Unknown was one of the few strategy games I could run in my crappy Pentium 1 PC, back in ye olde toyme when we could still count the pixels in the screen with the fingers of the hand. 

At this point I've played... practically all the franchise, and all its weird clones and offshoots and spinoffs and, finally, the reboot. 

Firaxis did... a lot of things with the franchise. Some things I am glad to have happened, and back then when this came out, followed by XCOM 2, I was elated to finally see XCOM back in the land of the living, with all the bells and whistles, with the geoscape management and the tactical combat, with its branching research paths and punishing gameplay.

And I'm still glad that it happened, but looking back at it, I see more flaws than good. 

There was a serious attempt to streamline the old formula, but I feel a lot of the game was lost to simplicity, and what remains is a hero-tactics with horrible RNG, soulless character, forgettable music, unnecessary action scenes, slow-af animations, and generally unsatisfying mechanics.
Everything that I liked about the old UFO games is not here.

I grew up with the original X-Com, UFO Defense, Terror, Apocolypse and even that weird space shooter one.

It's always nerve wracking when a classic is reinvented for a modern audience; nostalgia is a powerful drug; as it's more common for people to remember the good parts and completely blank on the bad. However I'd say 2k and Firaxis really hit the mark with this by delivering a great experience.

First the good: This game does well to capture the high points of the original. Moving into an unknown area worried you'll hit aliens is alive and well in this game. Watching rookies grow into your favourite squad mates is another; alot of little shout outs have also been made; with the global map, council reports and so fourth. 

Now the Neutral: A major change, which I still don't know if I like it overall; is that Action points are basically a "two actions per turn" sort of deal; more like a tabletop RPG style game rather than a random number of action points. This strangely steals a bit of the character from...well the characters really; as it removes a bit of headless chicken run around more in favour of a "tactical" approach.

Now the bad: Sacrifices have been made to streamline the gameplay significantly. Where as in older games it could take a good hour or so to do a mission (or literal seconds if a damn Sectoid threw a grenade into the skyranger); most the missions in this game are no more than 20 minutes or so only really lengthening towards the end into the 1-1.5 hour mark. Next there's now tighter loadouts with the class system - you can't just throw gear on people and stuff their pockets with items and slowly learn what they are good at; instead you get pre-defined skill trees and gear preferences. Finally the base building - it's nice they kept a base building mechanic; but in all honesty I felt it was really lacking any kind of value other than a tech-tree gating mechanism.

Is it worth playing though? Yes.

The game in general is enjoyable, and even the hardest difficulty level isn't illogically difficult. 
Though, the saving system is absolutely defunct! SO A BIG NO.

More below. 

Game Saving System: 

- Save files' order is completely broken if you keep more than 50-100 save files.
- If there is more than that, game must be relaunched to access recent saves.
- Occasionally, save files are randomly deleted. 
- Sometimes, game is not saved, no matter how many times you press Save.
- Sometimes, one save file is loaded instead of any other. Game must be relaunched. 

These problems started showing in just 2 days after I started playing.
A game with so many substantial problems with its saving system wasn't worth any of the money!
..................................................

Now, to game mechanics. 

 There are a few game mechanics points that do not make sense at all, e.g., aliens are able to cut through covers like butter, their aim landing is much better than the player's forces since the beginning of the game, and they can land shots from almost every angle, and only one shot from them can almost all the time kill a soldier, while the player faces disadvantages in all of the areas all the while. In late game, a number of enemy units will ALWAYS, without exception, hit your soldiers if they are not in full cover- and this is when they are in range from the enemy and not flanked!

The difficulty levels might have to do something with this, but changing the most basic mechanics in favor of the enemy to THIS extent doesn't bend the game, it breaks the game. 
.........................................................

Game Design 

What's even more, recruiting better body armor for the soldiers takes so long, recruiting even stronger weapons that can kill the aliens in two turns and not in 6 turns or in forever takes too long, and being able to equip strong anti-UFO weapons on your birds takes forever, while the aliens bring saucers to your sky that no amount of birds can shot down before you can even finish researching the rudimentary weapons.

Game design rationale says that you should make it possible for the player to be able to achieve a rational level of countering power. On higher difficulty levels, they should be more careful in managing research and other elements so that they can achieve that faster. Making it so they face literally unbeatable enemies sooner is not a smart design, it is a lazy one.  It will make it so that they can beat those monstrous enemies at very high costs, which will lead to them lagging behind from further progress in the mid-term, and getting weaker still until they are obliterated. 

This is not a good "strategy" nor a management game design.

This game is proof that turn-based games can be more exciting than real-time when done well. The excitement or, more accurately, dread of positioning your team and hoping they don't all die (or miss their shots) on the next turn is gripping. But this only works because of the difficulty of this game and how fail states work. 

If your whole squad dies and you lose a mission...the game continues on. There is no redo (you can save scum, but that's not recommended). That squad of experienced XCOM soldiers is DEAD, and you will likely sorely miss them in your next battle as rookies break under the stress and get themselves killed. You will also lose approval with the UN and likely lose funding as well, making your path a little harder. 

And this all sounds very punishing, but that punishment is exactly what makes winning feel so amazing. Perfectly ambushing an alien party feels amazing. Winning a battle with no casualties (or even with no injuries sometimes) feels amazing. Putting together an elite alpha squad of soldiers whose names and accomplishments you remember feels amazing. I can still remember a lot of my best soldier's names and best moments in battle. 

The music is also top-notch. The pre-battle ambient SFX and music create a genuine sense of dread and anticipation as you carefully move through the map looking for the enemy. And then the battle music is bombastic and intense as you fight desperate to survive.

TL;DR
-absolutely garbage camera controls
-command a custom squad on missions in turn-based combat
-rogue-like permadeath for your soldiers
-earn funding from countries through choice of actions/missions
-manage your budget
-fund research of new tech
-build a satellite detection network and equip interceptors to shoot down UFOs
-very fun 10% of the time to build/manage your UFO defense agency
-shitty tactical game-play 90% of the time with LITERALLY fake "% chance to hit" indicators (extensive testing revealed there is no actual RNG whatsoever; some other random mystery game mechanic determines whether you hit or not*) AND very poor indicators for cover and line of sight leave you absolutely mystified as to WTF is going on - funny since this game is based mostly on its turn-based combat but a simple isometric rpg like the Shadowrun rpg series gets it right and is actually fun...
-can't ALT-F4 to ragequit, and this game needs it, BUT AT LEAST YOU CAN EASILY DELETE THE GAME...

*test this yourself if you want: enter a mission, save the game, take a shot, re-load the save, take the shot again = same result EVERY SINGLE TIME, OVER AND OVER... SO WHY HAVE AN INDICATOR FOR "% CHANCE TO HIT" AT ALL?! WTF GAME DESIGN?!

BRUH... WORST TURN-BASED COMBAT I'VE EVER SEEN ASIDE, HOW DO YOU MANAGE TO HAVE GARBAGE CAMERA CONTROLS IN AN ISOMETRIC TURN-BASED GAME?!?!

Playing the game is a chore, losing squad members to very crappy game-play mechanics where you basically rely much more on the luck of predicting where aliens will pop than any actual tactics, since the aliens literally materialize from thin-air. MOST GOOD TACTICAL TURN-BASED GAMES THE WHOLE CONCEPT OF BEING TACTICAL IS TO SEE WHERE THE ENEMY IS AND WHAT THEY'RE DOING SO YOU CAN CHOOSE WHAT TO DO ON YOUR TURN, but not only can you not figure out if you're covered properly from enemy fire, but you have no idea where the enemies are gonna be suddenly appearing in full overwatch mode so that they hit you as soon as you move = enemy pops behind you where you aren't covered, ok, then they get a free clear shot at you (and it's VERY easy to die, you can only take a couple shots max before your soldier is permanently dead). Also, their idea of "Normal" difficulty is a total joke, and you'll have to make sure to save your game every few turns and be willing to repeat the same long turn-based encounters over and over to succeed without losing any squad members. It's just not fun, and seriously, when you have 4 levels of difficulty, a seasoned gamer should not have trouble completing missions on level 2. This is just braindead game design. Ultimately, the game is not friendly to anyone who isn't an expert in how to quickly acquire all the satellites and gear they need to survive AND IT IS JUST NOT FUN.

That said, the presentation is pretty cool, and the overall feeling of running the UFO defense group is interesting. I tried to enjoy the turn-based combat equally, but it's pretty bad honestly. It's barely enjoyable enough to continue with the overall game. I understand that the game is supposed to have you losing squad members so that you are forced to replace them by recruiting more, but it doesn't seem like every mission should cost you squad members on "normal" difficulty. When the game progresses this way, and you're relatively new to it, you find yourself broke, and basically losing the game, with your resources being drained faster than you can rebuild your X-Com agency, but this isn't something you realize right away, and you only find out many phases later that you didn't take the right actions or develop the right tech to have any hope of succeeding. = NOT FUN.

The best argument for save scumming. 

Ten years after release, this game is still one of the most addicting yet punishing games I've ever played.  It's a turn based strategy game that still feels unique despite its imitators - adding the depth of base building, management and unit customization like no one else. The game has its problems but the steady drip of rewards through good plays on the field and at the home base can really make for quite a few late night "eyes locked to the screen too long" adventures. When I finally did beat the game after having it mock me in my library for far too long, it felt better than the last ten games I completed. 

That all being said, Enemy Unknown isn't prefect - at times feeling like a execution that only got through 80% of a sectoid's neck. You know that good old 99% shot missing meme? That doesn't really happen but what does is inconsistent percentages for seemingly similar situations throughout the missions. You on the other side of the door from an enemy? Like literally could smell their breath close? Sometimes its a reasonable 90% of above chance hit, other times it's only 40% - and this will be on an enemy as thick as a truck and doesn't dodge much at all. 
This is one of the many instances where it feels like the gameplay doesn't match up with the presentation - the other main one being the proto-concealment system that the sequel would utilize : it feels finicky and inconsistent, making it unclear at points what one movement of your soldier will reveal. This gets really annoying in interiors, even up to the final level which is covered in darkness, even for the most basic doors. You could go ahead blindly but that takes away from the strategic value when you're just bumbling into encounters that never stop being deadly. Another argument for save scumming.

One last gripe on the gameplay is the RNG. It is central to the game but it can lead to the difficulty and encounter rate getting kind of funky in the beginning and end of the game. The amount of attacks at the end of my recent playthrough got so low, the crew could have assumed the aliens started retreating behind our backs. RNGesus also makes some enemies appear really early, so invest in those plasma and energy weapons ASAP because you do not want ballistic based snipers in these situations. 

A minor gripe would be the story, as unimportant as it is in something like this. The dialogue could have been as artificially generated as the random soldiers for how much it matters - coming off as bland, redundant and characterless. 

Overall though, this list of gripes didn't stop me from mainlining the game for over two weeks. The DLC additions are ok - one being essentially an early difficulty spike but having worthwhile rewards (Slingshot) and the other main one being an alternative way of playing the same campaign (Enemy Within). Augmented soldiers and mechs are cool but it doesn't change enough in my opinion to warrant a playthrough right after finishing the main game. 
So buy the game when you can, build those satellites early and mourn as your soldiers perish against caustic middle managers in suits and the cost of the memorial grows ever larger...or just reload a save until you get everyone out alive every time. Hey, I'm not here to judge!

So promising, yet unplayable in the long run. I tried all known workarounds against the random crashes, black screens, dramatic drop on FPS, and nothing worked, even lowering all settings to the lowest possible (despite having a specs that far surpass such which is required by the game). A real pitty because the game seemed really great. Asked for a refund and was dennied it on the grounds I had "played beyond 2 hours" without taking into consideration I was actually testing the game stability, the workarounds and that game crashes totally at random (meaning I had to replay the tutorial mission 4 times). So much for quality service...

UPDATE 1: I managed, after tinkering a lot, to make the base game playable by setting the NVIDIA Control Pannel V-Sync to "Adaptive" and can run the game even at full settings (sans the own game's Framerate Smoothing and V-Sync). Unfortunatelly, this all is for naught as soon as the "Enemy Within" expansion is installed, as the game will randomly crash, no matter how low the settings. A real pitty because, like I said, the game is really cinematic on it's approach to missions and everything.

UPDATE 2: I found out that disconnecting all non-critical USB devices (mainly a gamepad controller in my case), helped a lot with the stability and completely solved the FPS drop that, otherwise, happens around 1 or 2 hours of continuous game with the expansion installed. The game still crashes, randomly, but is relatively rare in comparison.

I can recommend this game to avid SLG players, with some caveats. Firstly, the negatives.

Compared with DOS-era XCOM titles, this one is way more restrictive. In the older titles, not only did you have a lot more macro level play options, there was also some sort of RPG experience mixed in. As you grind your rookies to level up many varied attributes and give them better equipment, they go from die-of-heart-attack-at-seeing-the-first-alien, to superheros who bring death to enemies casually with confidence. In this installment, the enemy's HP/abilities are more or less scaled to your own levels/game progress. You barely have any chance to feel elated with your superiority before the game ends. And indeed if you do, the next instant you will regret it, when your ass is handed to you with multiple of your best guys dying left and right. Cautious, cautious, and always be cautious in this game.

This game can be viewed as a very carefully crafted cinematic experience. You have very little actual freedom to play creatively or at your own terms. There's always some sort of imminent danger here and there, and you are always on your toes.

So, the pro of the game is also exactly that. Cinematic, tense, a gripping experience from start to finish. Except some similarity at the tactical layer, this game cannot be too different from its predecessors. You can treat this for what it is, and you can learn to appreciate its own merits.

This is a pretty good game overall, but playing XCOM 2 and coming back to this, it's flaws become glaringly awful. 

No auto save during mission turns can cause some rather frustrating replays when your 95%, 82%, and 75% chances to hit all miss. The panic system just seems designed to punish you. If not for the randomness of where abductions and terror missions pop up, one could strategize around this, but the RNG is all that ends up mattering. 

Also, having to individually make every weapon and piece of armor and then individually swap them around on soldiers each mission is a huge pain that simply doesn't exist in XCOM 2, as it allows you to make "squad upgrades" rather than going through the painstaking process of individual gear swaps constantly. Going back to this system is awful.

It is also far too easy to get a flanking angle in XCOM 1. Also, you're not able to jump over or drop down nearly as fluidly as in XCOM 2. 

On the flip side, XCOM 1 and Enemy Within does a better job of having fighter craft down UFO's, and with Enemy Within, you can train up and launch covert ops, which makes the "Gunslinger" path of the sniper a legitimate choice, unlike in XCOM 2. 

This is a fun game, I just can't completely recommend it when XCOM 2 does it better.

Let me tell you a story about a man named Sam Song.

Sam Song was just a regular recruit at XCOM HQ. His first mission was to go help with data retrieval on an EXALT cell. "It's going to be an easy mission", Central thought, they had dealt with an EXALT mission before, and the squad that was going was mostly veteran soldiers, along with a rookie to train.

As they arrived on the scene, it was very quiet for a few turns. No enemies in sight. But as soon as the squad made it to the roof of a building where the encoder for the mission was, it started to go to shit.

First, our Sergeant Sniper got dropped by an unfortunate crit. XCOM always prepares in case of a soldier death, no biggie. Every turn thereafter, more and more EXALT members rushed in, and Sam Song's squads firepower was not enough to staunch the flow of incoming enemies.

One after one, Sam's allies dropped dead trying to protect the encoder and later the transmitter to ensure that the mission would not fail. In the end it was up to Sam and the covert operative for the mission. The covert op was some form of miraclemaker, as they would not get hit by conventional fire. She dodged at least 9 shots from the enemy (including flanks) before succumbing to a grenade and a shot right next to her

Sam Song kept dropping the enemy troops like flies for those last moments. With the help of his 5 squad member's and the covert op's sacrifice the last enemy had to reload at the critical moment when they would have had a flanking shot on Sam.

Sam finished the mission alone, ranking to a sniper but it was not enough. The loss of almost all of XCOM's vets caused his death on his next mission.

A true soldier to the end. Never forget Sam Song.

The base game is fun and well designed.  Good characters, voices, story, and layout.  The only negative is the AI at the higher difficulty levels is absolutely stupid and makes the game unplayable.

Review includes the add-on "Enemy Within".

The remake of one of the golden oldies of the strategy genre. Naturally this made it quite difficult to satisfy the fans of the original as well as to attract new players in equal parts.

What Firaxis did well, was the graphical style and presentation, XCOM offers the style of the first UFO games, while bringing it in the new era. Nothing extraordinaire for sure, but fitting graphics with the one or other really nice possibility to take a screenshot or enjoy the headshot with which your sniper eliminates this pesky alien.

Regarding the gameplay they tried to keep the balance between streamlining and complexity.

The maps are handmade, offering some nice details and mostly destroyable enviroment, but since the random element is gone, they keep on repeating themselves after some playtime.

The same can be said for the progression of the game itself.. your soldiers are basically divided into classes, which have fixed perk trees to choose from on level up. Without the added options of "Second wave" and the additional possibilities from "Enemy within" to enhance your soldiers with mech or gene modifications, this brings up a similiar problem to the maps, the soldiers are very similiar to each other. As mentioned the add-on options change this in a positive way, beside the modifications you can for example enable that each soldier has different starting stats.
Still this does not reach the complexity of the original X-Com soldiers, but helps the diversity significally.

As for the base management and battles themselves.. once again it is the mix of old and new. The Action points of the old soldiers are gone, now each soldier has two actions per turn (with the right perks, it can be way more though) one for moving, the other for shooting. Again perks as well as equipment can change the possibilities of a soldiers actions.
This system together with an intelligent cover system works quite well and makes for interesting battles.
The base has fixed fields, which you have to fill during the game. Also with the add-on the possibility of the enemy invading your base returns, though as a scripted event.

If you like this game, nothing against you, but I have no clue why. I'll put my bias on the table, but still try to provide information here.

[h1]Serious UX Issues[/h1]
This game plays like an underfunded janky indie game. It's death by a thousand cuts. Every single animation takes forever, for no conceivable reason. Everything moves so slowly, the responsiveness of your cursor is low. It's genuinely a step down in control since 1994, which is impressive. Zero effort has been put into respecting the player's time or having the user experience polished in any way. You have to mod this shit and play it at 2.5x if you don't want to get bored or go insane, depending on how poorly you handle seeing the same 3 second animation for the 5000th time.

Sometimes you can't take two steps in mission without the game completely locking you in place so it can deliver a bland voiceline from a bland character that nobody could possibly like. 

If you can handle a game playing way slower than it could, then this might be OK, but for me it's torture.

[h1]Look & Feel[/h1]
The visual aspect of the game is bland and forgettable, from the design of the aliens, the look of your weapons to the sub-mediocre voice acting. The art direction is borderline lifeless. It's not incompetent, and there were many ways to mess it up worse. But I struggle to find good things to say about it.

One upside the game has is that it allows substantial visual customization of your troops, which is always a neat feature to have.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The plot outright makes the game worse compared to if it were totally absent. It would take too long to explain why and spoil it, but I felt like it added nothing to the game. Not really worth talking about. It's a forgivable sin if not for story missions blasting you with bland voicelines.

[h1]Gameplay Mechanics[/h1]
The amount of strategic and tactical depth this game has is low in vanilla. And it's not great in Long War mod either. I think XCOM: EU and EW are a fundamental step back from XCOM (1994). Instead of taking what was a good about XCOM and vastly improving the user experience and making the game more digestible for wider audiences, they created an almost minimalist turn based game with some weird game design choices.

The amount of options you have during a fight go up towards the end of the game, but they're never great.

However I can say that the core gameplay can be reasonably enjoyable when certain aspects align. Especially if you are a patient player and haven't had your expectations set by other entries in the genre, you might have fun with this.

[h2]Pod System Is Questionable Design[/h2]
XCOM: EU/EW is probably the first game I've played that actively punishes you for moving on the map to this degree. This is due to the pod system. In XCOM 1994, all aliens were active on the map at the same time. In XCOM: EU/EW enemies are distributed into groups (pods) of patrolling and stationary aliens that do not participate in a fight unless they make visual contact with your troops.

The game is balanced around you greatly limiting the number of pods active at the same time. In essence this means that you are always trying to exploit sight increasing items to avoid triggering pods in bad situations, but that's not always possible. You'll be in many situations where there's an awesome tactical opportunity to flank and you just know you can't use it because there's a 50% chance a pod will accidentally see you and make the fight from 4v3 to 4v6 which can and will absolutely kill you on harder difficulties. This encourages a slow and boring playstyle, it feels like playing with handcuffs.

The safe style of playing, which is also the correct style, is made so much worse by the aforementioned slowness in unit animations and the poor responsiveness of the game.

[h2]RNG[/h2]
The RNG of the game no longer makes me angry, but there are some serious problems here. You will see a lot of people complain about this but not manage to explain what the issue is.

In XCOM (1994) you could load 14 soldiers into the Skyranger on your first mission. In this XCOM you start with 4. While this has the benefit of making turns require less action from the user, the downside is that player agency in the face of bad luck is greatly reduced until you get your hands on certain tools.

Until you understand what those tools are, the game will seem arbitrary. This is a huge design flaw in the game, but it is surmountable by installing Long War mod and taking time to understand how to play in a way that mitigates RNG.

[h2]Geoscape aka Strategy Layer[/h2]
In this game you're supposed to go between the Geoscape -- this planetary strategic level where you control bases, interceptors, research and manufacturing -- and the Battlescape, the turn based tactical part of the game.

While the Geoscape has a few nice choices it lets you make in terms of what you're researching first, it has this persistent unpleasant feeling of being very... safe. Very controlled, like you're in a padded room.

XCOM (1994) allowed you much more freedom. Do you want 4 workshops to crank out laser weapons as fast as possible which you sell on the black market for a huge additional income stream? Go for it! Do you want to build 3 additional bases just to work as sensor outposts? No problem.

XCOM: EU/EW has none of this. There are no "crazy" things you can do. Overall, I think it has limited player expression, but it's not all bad. I just really wanted more.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
This game feels like a prototype for a better game that never existed. I resent it for failing to be bold or truly competent on any axis because the fundamental idea represented by XCOM has great potential.

I think it's highly rated because the amount of easily accessible games in the turn based tactics genre is pitiful. But, you deserve better than this. If you're not patient by nature or don't have a deep seated ability to appreciate this genre, you'll likely be wasting your time with this game.

If you want a similar but slightly improved experience try XCOM 2.
If you are okay with older games get OpenXCOM and experience the joy of the original XCOM game adapted to modern systems.
If you want an absolutely crazy and rich experience get the XPiratez mod for the original XCOM.
If you want a much (apparently) simpler turn based tactics game with more combat depth and very good UX, try Into The Breach.

I played this game at a time when I was not feeling the love for turn-based strategy games....and it manged to change my outlook, because this is how you make a tense, action-filled turn-based game! 

Perma-death for the units you recruit, customise and send out to save the world from this alien threat is such a good mechanic....even if I had to deal with the loss of many a great soldier (wiping away a tear for my boys Vinnie diesel and Nikki Cage...RIP you legends!) Watching the enemy outflank a unit you rushed forward without doing the smart thing of gathering intel is a rough ride, but you quickly learn from those mistakes and mobilise your units effectively. As with all turn-based titles, and one of the reasons I fell out of love with some, you have to deal with some promoted attacks missing wildly despite being in a good position and having a clear shot. Thankfully I didn't find many of these moments in this game and felt that most of the time it was my bad positioning that led to missed shots and damaged units. This is how it should be, not missing easy targets to drum up fake tension. The level designs make combat interesting and later levels really push your units to their maximum abilities as stronger and stronger enemy units flank, change levels and swarm your squad. The upgrades to your units also extends to your base, allowing you to gather better intel and learn more about the aliens you are fighting. 

This game offers you plenty and kept me entertained for many hours during a time when it should have been the last game I wanted to play, so if that isn't a great endorsement of this game I don't know what is! If you love turn-based tactical strategy games where you can blow apart invading aliens then you are at the right place to get your fix. Highly recommend!

Let me just start this review of by saying: This game is fantastic... It is, however, not 1993 XCOM with updated graphics. If that's what you wanted, don't buy this game and please don't bother us by giving 0 point reviews here.

As I said, this game is different from UFO: EU(X-com: UFO Defence in america) it is however not worse or dumbed down. They may have simplified the tactical combat, but simplifying is not the same as dumbing down. Dumbing down is making the game easier and losing strategic depth in the process, simpifying is making a game easier to understand while trying to maintain or improve strategical depth.

And XCOM: EU does the latter. The strategic base management is probably even more complicated than it was in the original and the tactical combat is, while streamlined and symplified, just as deep or even deeper than the original game.
It now involves units working together instead of having 14 nearly identical soldiers just scouting if every direction. Ammo is now more important unlike what many 1993 fanboys are saying. Guns still need reloading you just don't need to equip your soldiers with ammo anymore. And most of all there's the completely new cover system. Now, when you move your soldiers, you actually need to think about flanking aliens, because shooting aliens in full cover isn't going to kill them. I've come across a situation where my assault soldier tried to flank an alien but revealed another alien in the process which left him exposed. I then moved my support soldier in to throw a smoke grenade to protect my assault and used my heavy to suppress the flanking alien to avoid him shooting at my assault... Tactical situations like that would almost never occur in the original X-com so i completely disagree wit people who say this game is dumbed down.

The things that were simplified are mainly things like Time Units and i think the new system is actually better. It might kill the nostalgia a bit but this system is faster, easier and makes every decision more important and rewarding.

So, to come to a conclusion: I think this game is absolutely brilliant!

XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within is a game about aliens, RNGesus, and the unknowable panic of being outnumbered and outgunned. But you already know that. You're here for a review.
Honestly, a lot of what I can say here applies to both XCOM EU/EW and XCOM 2. They're hard, make you think, and are all about minimizing the effects of luck on your carefully laid plans that fall apart after you miss that 85% shot. Many other reviews have done a much better job of explaining this game, so I will instead help you, dear reader, choose between this and it's sequel.
[hr][/hr]
XCOM EU (as I will refer to it and it's expansion, Enemy Within, from now on) is a slower game, where timed scenarios might crop up once or twice in your entire campaign, and serve as a break from the slow and methodical missions that make up the bulk of the game. The "doom counter" (essentially, the way the game shows you how close you are to losing) is simply how many Council nations have left/surrendered to the aliens. With careful play, you can [i]heavily[/i] slow the progress of this counter. By the time I finished my first playthrough, I'd only lost a couple countries, and the counter was barely past the halfway mark. However, it [b]cannot[/b] be reduced. This led to me constantly panicking about it, and never once letting it progress when I didn't have to. Your mileage may vary, but overall, it's more of constant slow pressure forcing you to keep an eye on it.
[hr][/hr]
XCOM 2, on the other hand, just feels like a more modern sequel that tried to completely do away with the slow nature of the first game, opting for fast, aggressive combat, but ended up being [i]too[/i] fast. Other than story missions, essentially [u]every[/u] mission in XCOM 2 is timed, forcing you to make aggressive plays and take huge risks, even if you'd rather not. In this game, the doom counter is the mysterious Avatar Project, introduced early on in the game. If this completes, you lose (except that there's a small grace period to act and push it back down before your campaign is over). However, it can be reversed partially to slow it down, but never halted. This game's timer is a constant mountain of pressure - whenever you're not researching weapons technology, you [i]have[/i] to be progressing the story to slow their progress. I'm... not a fan.
XCOM 2 has one thing going for it, though. Modernization. Better soldier customization (beyond armor color, hair, helmet, and name), better graphics, better mod support that is integrated into the Steam Workshop and doesn't require crazy backwards methods to install, etc. etc. Still, I will never forgive them for replacing the badass MEC Troopers with shitty SPARK units. Or making CO Bradford sound like a cranky old man (I kid on this point).
[hr][/hr]
Overall, I would highly recommend this game, and just say try XCOM 2 on a sale/free weekend if you like this one. RNGesus will [i]not[/i] screw you over as much as the memes would make you think, and the story's even pretty good, too.

Just finished XCOM with Enemy Within expansion. Impossible difficulty I couldn't break through in about 20hrs, so I just finished this on Classic (hard mode) Ironman. What I didn't expect was my XCOM Enemy Within experience to be so similar to XCOM2. I thought they would be very different games. In fact, XCOM Enemy Within has aspects that are unique and arguably better than XCOM2, and that's coming from a big XCOM2 fan. Both are amazing games, and XCOM2 certainly has some improvements. But overall, the games are very similar, superb turn-based tactical combat with a strategical/upgrade layer. If I had to choose I would choose XCOM2, but they're very similar. Besides the cheapness of getting destroyed on Impossible difficulty, I would say that the biggest problem was the game length. I would recommend this with some reservations. The game itself is brilliantly designed... except for some of the sheer BS rage-inducing combat mechanics that you need to be aware of. For example, you can have one of your guys sneak up to the roof of a building, crouch behind obstacles, and hunker down defensively... yet somehow an enemy can shoot him from the other side of the map, from an angle that should be impossible, (through the wall/floor), with a pistol. Meanwhile another alien appears between a group of SIX of your well trained marksmen who were all sat waiting, waiting for this creature to show his face so they can blow it to kingdom come, only to see the words, 'Missed. Missed. Missed. Missed. Missed. Missed,' on your screen, before the alien insta-kills your best soldier. Sigh.

Okay, **** happens. I get that. But in this game it happens *ALL THE TIME*, often without logic or in complete defiance of physics. It seems like both aiming angles and range were simply overlooked in calculating hit percentages, or considered to be very small variables, (suggesting Jack Reacher is always more likely to hit me with a water pistol from 200m away while I'm ducking behind a barricade on a rooftop than I could hit him with flak cannon at point blank range). If you're okay with this frustrating element of the game, then the game itself is a fantastic blend of base-building, squad management, tactics and storytelling. It's a one of a kind masterpiece that could do with a serious gameplay overhaul. (Unfortunately X-Com 2 took things in the opposite direction, imo)

The missions, the story, juggling through the resources, managing the rooster, I am quite happy with the current state of the game.

The game has a lot of randomness to it, but that's where it shines.  You get to play the role of both strategist and risk manager- a typical ploy in game design.

The game is "special forces squad manager" but turn-based and versus aliens instead of real-time and against other human threats.  The aliens gave them an excuse for a technology tree, which lets your squad effectively improve throughout the game.

All in all, it's a good time and it's better than most strategy game series with a turn-based format.   Few do it right, X-COM does.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a fun turn-based action strategy game. You control multiple people in humankinds fight for their survival against an alien threat in combat scenarios. At the same time you have to build up your base and research new weapons, armor and decipher alien technology recovered from your enemies.

I had a lot of fun with this game, but I did encounter some bugs that soured the experience a bit. The physics in this game is not the best, and sometimes people or aliens would float while they moved, or their corpse would float around on the battlefield. Those visual bugs and glitches are fine. They were not too distracting, and they did not do anything else than look funny, but I did encounter one bug that was game changing in my latest playthrough. One of the special missions that you can get from the Council seemed fine at first, but whenever I finished that mission and was in the loading screen after the mission it would crash to desktop. I tried many different things to get through that hurdle, but I could not figure it out and had to skip out on that mission, which means that I both missed the reward for completing the mission and had to take the negative that came with declining a Council mission and that could have ended that playthrough if I had been doing a bit worse.

Still, with those bugs I encountered I had a good time, and if you like turn-based action strategy games this could be a good game for you.

I play a run of this game with the Long War mod once every couple of years without fail. At 500 hours played and currently downloading it all again, I figured a review was in order.

The core mechanics of tactical gameplay with strategic layer decision-making have formed the basis for many games that followed it, but it's XCOM EU/EW that I always come back to. Playing this game properly requires you to think ahead and make hard decisions. You will lose soldiers, you will have to abandon missions, you will undertake the hard task of triage over and over. It's a fantastic gaming experience that I would offer to anyone interested.

The base game holds up quite well, but if you want the full experience download the Long War mod and give it a spin. The strategic and tactical depth of the game will immediately double as will the runtime of a single campaign. There is no other mod in existence that so thoroughly completes an otherwise finished product.

While there are certainly some frustrating moments, such as the infamously dubious accuracy, I had a blast playing this game. I'm someone who really loves Fire Emblem and doing Pokemon Nuzlockes, so the potential permanent loss of a soldier provided motivation, as well as the highs of seeing them grow stronger and the lows of watching them die from my mistakes/bad RNG.

The game does drag a little bit towards the late middle/ending of the game, once you have all of the tech/armor/weapons unlocked. At that point, you've probably already figured out how to deal with every type of enemy that could appear, so that did affect the sense of tension. The final mission is fine, and provided some good challenge. The ending, however, is a little disappointing. It feels very abrupt.

Overall, the strongest points of the game are the early missions when death lurks just out of sight, and the mid-game when you're strong enough to fight back but not yet a squad of ultimate badasses.

XCOM Enemy Unknown, to me, feels like an Ameritrash dice-tossing boardgame dressed up with pretensions of being a squad-based tactical experience. Combat consists of cover that doesn't feel like it changes much, and glitchy-twitchy shooting and cutscenes that feels like it could be replaced by rolling hand-fulls of dice. There's another level of the game, your home base, that packs on the seriousness in the form of resource management  that can punish you hardcore for mistakes. The dissonance between the high randomness and high punishment for failure combines with the occasional forced-mission on an increased difficulty curve to create a potentially enjoyable cocktail for the right player. I’d advise most players to buy with caution, but then again many seem pleased with the design.

XCOM Enemy Unknown and it’s DLC Enemy Within is an incredibly immersive and brilliant game.  It’s one of those games where you can’t set it down.  Organic gameflow, tactical ground missions, and base building all blend seemlessly together.  The game presents a unique challenge as you learn to battle an unknown foe.  Very little handholding is provided as the game gives you a fair challenge, but a challenge nonetheless.  If you can bring yourself to it, I heartily recommend you turn on the ironman setting.  It prevents you from loading previous saves and forces you to overcome your mistakes and/or bad luck.  Randomness is a core mechanic of the game and can feel unforgiving at times but this also adds lots of replay value.

Unfortunately, this game is hopelessly broken. More than once I have had the game totally freeze on me with no recourse except to start over entire missions in order to keep progressing. This may be acceptable for newly released games, but this game is over 2 years old with no new patches or updates to fix this issue. Despite the internet being plastered with complaints of this very issue on all systems (pc, xbox360 and ps3), no fix or even acknowledgement from 2k exists.

I am just warning you if you buy this game make sure to save before each mission so you can start with a good save, but i wold not reward a company that leaves such a glaring hole in such a great game. It completely breaks the experience and I pretty do not care to complete this game because of how frustrating this issue becomes in the late game.

It's been almost about 6 years, since I purchased this game and I can whole heartedly tell you, to just skip it and buy the sequel. The last time, I've encountered this many gamebreaking bugs, was when I tried launching gothic 1. Sure, you can argue, that bugs are random, but I do not see myself going back to play this game.
The story is basically; defend earth for 30 hours and you get 3 gamemodes: kill aliens, defuse a bomb and extract a person of interest. The soundtrack consists of about 3 tracks. Even though, they're good, they get stale after about 10 hours. The graphics have aged pretty poorly, but that mostly stems from the artstyle. The gameplay, while engaging enough to make you want to play with strategy, falls apart through the difficulty. You can literally kill the final boss within one turn on the normal difficulty. Increasing the difficulty doesn't make it more difficult to play the game, it just messes up the chances of hitting a target. This way, you feel like playing a luck-based game instead of a strategy based one. A more difficult option would have been, fighting from a less ideal spawn, being forced into a disadvantageous position and overcoming it. Rather than fighting with soldiers, who haven't hit a shot in 6 turns, immeadiately panic and shoot their teammates.
I just wish, it had more enemy types, music and strategic difficulties. All in all 4/10.

It's Lancer but without the mechs. Everyone already knows that Lancer is a good game so instead of wasting your time going into that here's all the janky bits that I am not a huge fan of

- There is no asymmetric vision. If you spot enemies, they spot you and vice versa
- The camera controls are meh. I just want to be able to lock the camera at a certain angle but the game won't give me that.
- The economy is dumb. the worse you play (and slower you progress the main story), the stronger your soldiers end up. Research is bottlenecked by items never research time. If you have normal human levels of skill you will end up progressing the main story way too quickly and be vastly underequipped for enemies. 
- The game discourages you from playing intelligently (IE using ordinance and baiting enemies). Instead it pushes you into a playstyle where you rely heavily on luck because that's the only way to recover the aliens' corpses/hostages.

The game is almost 10 years old, so it has already been patched as much as it could. Even so, after finishing a very difficult mission I pressed "Esc" to bring up the menu and save, but then the whole GUI simply disappeared. No text, no icons, just the base on the background. I had to kill the game using the task manager. Lost the progress. And there are other bugs as well, like getting stuck in a black loading screen, for instance. Other than that, the game is hard, and in a bad sense. It is a "miss" festival. Two of your best soldiers and a sniper, all of them fully upgraded, all of them in overwatch, all of them trying to hit an enemy running in the open, no cover at all, and all of them miss. And then the enemy gets close and hits for a critical killing one of your soldiers. You'll see "miss" even when above 95%, even if it is your sniper aiming. That's ok provided it is rare, however high percentage misses are too frequent to be tolerated. In contrast, your troops will be hit even when they are in full cover and using hunker down. A miss in a turn based game means you waste your time since you have to wait till next turn to do another action with that character. A quite unlikable and outdated feature to people who have something else to do with their lives beyond playing video-games. When you search for alien activity, you're normally given three locations where difficulty vary with panic level, but we always tend to go with the one where panic is higher so we don't lose that country, this means you don't have an actual choice.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~
An ode to the best game ever made
~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I started the mission and found a small sectoid.
Threw it a flashbang and left it quite annoyed.
Its friend cast a mind merge, another cast mindfray...
Next time I hope rookies have HEs to go play.

Then came a drone, buzzing high in the sky,
The rookies took shots, might as well flung a pie.
The rounds barely made it past damage reduction...
Next time I'll bring a sniper to the abduction.

Then came a tense bomb disposal with thin men.
With motion trackers I planned everything, when
out of their mouths came a poisonous acid...
Next time more med kits will make everything placid.

Then came end of March a shiny landed scout.
Rookies asked for a chance and I gave them a shout...
...but they couldn't hit flying floaters if they tried.
Next time I'll send gunners to suppress their pride.

Then came full on terror - a chryssalid pack!
They ran at civilians, then all the way back.
I thought that my scout was sat out of their range...
Next time I will bring CCS for a change.

Then came the appearance of many a seeker.
They'll strangle, we'll alt+o, couldn't be weaker...
...except for that one hidden on overwatch.
Next time lightning reflexes prevents a botch.

Then came the outsider in shining bright orange,
One run-and-gun shotgun and he's now a lozenge.
Except that all pods then converged on the scene...
Next time activate LAST or you might lose a spleen.

Then came the green muton, hulking his great bulk,
Shot him down to one health then he raged in a sulk.
The panic check failed, soldier died the next turn.
Next time don't neglect Steadfast, so onward I learn.

Then came the majesty of a cyberdisc.
It flew high, all shots missed, we were at major risk.
One grenade, cover gone, quite tempting to resign...
Next time holo + heat leaves no reason to whine.

Then appeared the mechtoid on its overwatch.
Caught out of position, my team needs a scotch.
Now shielded by sectoids, we've not enough power..
Next time disabling prevents things turning sour.

Then came the beserker charging at full sprint,
I shot it fives times but it didn't take the hint.
So stoked with DR I just couldn't kill them.
Next time I will research and bring along chem.

Then came the high will of a sectoid commander.
Out mech mind controlled: we couldn't understand her.
Hidden back behind indestructible high cover...
Next time I will psi inspire them like a lover.

Then came the throw range of high heavy floater,
With bombard it reached our team sat by the motor.
A stray shot blew up the remainder of the truck.
Next time there's a wall further back with some luck.

Then came the red blaze of a muton elite,
Need corpses for rigging, so we're happy to meet.
Except that I can't hit through their innate defence.
Next time bring more psi, least that's my ten cents.

Then came a massive stomping black sectopod,
One disable later, I looked to the squad.
They fired and whittled it, but drones repaired...
Next time blast the drones first and mechs will be spared.

Then finally came the ethereal threat,
It was the toughest encounter I had yet.
It ran and it lanced and it rift and we died.
Next time I'll ask reddit, well, after I've cried.

Since 1997, there hasn't actually been much of any change in turn-based strategy games. Once you'd played Final Fantasy Tactics (or Tactics Ogre, which several developers who worked for Square had made before working on FFT), you'd really played them all. 

XCOM: Enemy Within is the only successful game I've seen within that specific field (excluding RTS games) that has done anything new, and it's done it well. I don't think I'd even played a turn-based strategy game since 2003, when Disgaea came out, and it was so anime-bland that I just stopped completely. Most of what's being (re)introduced in XCOM: EU, and it's expansion, Enemy Within, is so far left of the typical gist of these types of games that it usually takes a few short, sweet, and most importantly FAILED, runs to get a total grasp on the mechanics and how to use them properly to beat the game. 

There is, however, a lack of dynamic design in enemies you'll encounter. Even old games (and their ripoffs) like FFT have some differentiation because of the classic Job/Class system, whereas in XCOM there's only roughly 10 enemy types with one or more variations. Even then you'd think the maybe 16 total different potential enemies that you'd encounter would be enough, but I can assure you, it gets repetitive FAST. 

XCOM also has an RNG system like other turn-based strategy games, but seems to force you to accept whatever decision it's made about how each shot will connect. You could reload a save 20 times and always get the same result. This seems PERFECT for the genre, but let me tell you, as you get started playing, whatever methodology going on under the hood to determine if a shot misses seems pretty janky, at best. Other games (like XCOM 2) have attempted to remedy this. 

Where this game shines brightest is how each turn is laid out. Unlike so many games before it, XCOM has the player determine what each unit will do before their turn ends. You can no longer game the system so easily by improving some arbitrary stat like haste and correcting each misstep because you'll have a unit ready to prevent a troop from dying because only a single enemy unit has had the opportunity to attack. It's do or die, and really forces the player to engage on a new level of planning to win a single game. This alone, sets XCOM apart from every other turn-based strategy game on the market.

The game also lacks any sense of ambiance. You could argue that the slow nature of the game effectively acts as ambiance, but the sound board begs to differ. It honestly reminds me of an old 1990s video games where you ambiance was the accompanying battle music. 

There's also a extremely high quality mod for this game called The Long War (which members of Firaxis Studios, who made XCOM: EU/EW, helped work on) that adds a Cinematic Mode where shots miss less. I think for my next playthrough I'd just use that, because, man, with proper ability point allocation and planning, in-the-field strategies like flanking (a very basic mechanic, not nearly the meta these types of games can offer) can quickly seem completely useless.

8/10

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a remake of the original turn based strategy game UFO: Enemy Unknown. Most of the aliens are the same, there are a few additional enemies and some alterations to others. The graphics are significantly upgraded, but the gameplay is essentially the same (which isn't necessarily a bad thing). The Slingshot DLC is also included with the game, and it's highly recommended to play that.

XCOM: Enemy Within is a separate game in its own right, and is essentially an expansion of the original. The expansion introduces a few new enemies, new soldier upgrades (mecs, genetics) by way of Meld, a new enemy human faction called Exalt which is reminiscent of the "Cult of Sirius" from XCOM: Apocalypse, new environments and new government missions.

Expect to sink many hours into this. I bought this for the Xbox 360, and liked it so much that I had to buy it again on Steam!

This game is a good remake of the original from 30 years ago, however it lacks many things the original had. I miss assaulting an alien ship with multiple decks.  Boarding an alien vessel via the ground level entrance and then using the gravity lift to traverse said ship was exciting to say the least. Using the unconventional tactic breaching my way into a ship, via the blaster launcher and flight suits (to avoid Chryssalids) was fun to say the least.  Boarding an alien ship always had the foreboding fear of instant death for my soldiers; as turning a corner and coming face to face with a Chryssalid was enough to make a full grown man cry. Death was mostly inevitable at this point for the unlucky bastard who had such an encounter.  I also miss the different forms of fire (snap, auto and aimed) a soldier could take to gun down extraterrestrial enemies.  I long for the major details of arming and making sure I took enough ammo and grenades for my troops before they entered battle.  These omitted concepts made the original that much more interesting and I wish this game had that functionality.  If Firaxis had taken the original and updated it to better graphics without changing anything else, that in and of itself would have been the best avenue in reselling this old title…imho.

XCOM is advertised as a turn based strategy game. But that's only half true.

There is a focus on turn based strategy here, but luck plays a bigger role. 

I've been next to an enemy several times with a 97% hit chance and missed. I've also had 27% hit chance several times and killed the enemy.

Skill doesn't play much of a factor. Yes, increasing your hit chance by adjusting position and weapon load out can affect the outcome. But never enough that I'm not crossing my fingers before every shot.

You might like XCOM. Many play to this day. Just know that your success will largely be decided not by your ability as a player, but by a random number generator outside of your control.

Your acceptance of that fact will determine how much you enjoy this game.

WOTC is slicker, with improved graphics technology and a heftier rig requirement, but I played Enemy Unknown again for the first time in a few years, and it is still just as good as I remember it. The storyline and gaming mechanics flow nicely, and it feels "pure" unlike the fudged plotline of the sequel (which don't get me wrong is a great game with lots of wonderful mods to jazz things up).

After completing the main story line (including the Enemy Within DLC), I believe I am ready to leave a review.

This game is the greatest strategy game I have played so far. It is better even than the sequel (XCOM 2, which I am currently progressing to beat). Gameplay and story will be fascinating for any fan of sci-fi turn-based strategies. The RNG system regarding actions, like shooting, is often frustrating, but also very rewarding and satisfying equally frequently. The game in general is quite difficult and requires a lot of patience, sacrifice, and strategic and tactical skill in order to reach the end. I, personally, had problems even on the easiest difficulty. But I consider that an asset.

And the Enemy Within DLC adds lots of new and original concepts, like soldier genetic and cybernetic modification, or the new EXALT threat - an organization, which tries its strength to baffle XCOM and its plans to save the planet.

I would love to criticize this reboot based on the original series to have a more objective point of view, but unfortunately, I did not obtain those games. If I ever manage to lay my hands on the original games, I will try and update this review.

Truly a dying breed in today's generation of gaming, Xcom reinvigorates the idea of Turn based strategy. It retains the flair and nostalgia of the older Xcom titles while bringing in some refreshing graphics and enhanced streamline gameplay.

But wait there's more!
The game creates an amazing immersive perception of how someone who go about commanding a base of operations built to combat aliens threatening mankind. The missions, dialog, cutscenes... All of it come together to give you the most realistic feeling you could possibly ever get. 

Do you recognize yourself as a Tactical genius?
Do you aspire to be the saviour of humanity in it's darkest hour? 
Then Xcom: Enemy Unknown is the ticket you've been looking for!

DIsclaimer: XCOM: Enemy Unknown is definitely a game of its time and having just finished it in 2022 I'll try and give two different perspectives on this game and leave you to decide.

Firstly, from a 2022 perspective I do wish I had played this game when it originally came out. I can see how back when it was released this game was a breath of fresh air.

Graphics are decent, if outdated by 2022 and the facial animation is again definitely of its time, but the environments are crisp and the effects still hold up well. The animation of the various aliens and characters are fantastic.

The story is standard alien-invasion fare with a couple of twists and turns to keep you interested. I would definitely recommend that if you're playing this game in 2022+ to make sure to play with the Expansion content 'Enemy Within' as it adds further missions and interesting scenarios to the original's storyline.

The game-play is where XCOM continues to shine in comparison to other games. The gameplay is strategic and every move you make, unless you're a save-fantatic, can be fraught with peril as it could lead to the death of a well-loved squad member. This is especially true late-game as the enemies become tougher and deal more damage. The abilities available and the range of different soldiers you recruit lead to a huge range of different options during the scenarios. The addition of the 'Enemy Within' content further widens the tools you get to play with to the point where you can approach any scenario differently every time with different soldiers and abilities and loadouts.

You will sometimes get attacked or have the opportunity to attack UFOs which requires you to deploy your aircraft. I do wish this was a bit more strategic than just watching your plane duke it out against the UFO as it led to me rushing to get the better aircraft available mid-game. Once you've got those, the UFO problems disappear.

The base-building, research, weapon manufacturing, satelliate placement etc during the base section of the game was also interesting. During the early to mid-game, the order you build, the satelliates you place and the research you carry out can have a bearing on the difficulty of the missions in the late-game.

For my part, without given spoilers away, I did find I was able to 'cheat' the game slightly and managed to make it in to the final mission with my soldiers fully powered up, tech'd up and kitted out for most the aliens to be no trouble at all.

Which leads to me stating exactly why I would recommend this game in 2022, but with a caveat. The game is still as strategic as it was when it was released and holds up well today. The graphics and story are decent but nothing to write home about. The game was definitely enhanced for me with the additional content from 'Enemy Within'. The caveat being that the game does become very repetitive. I found myself waiting and waiting for research and manufacturing to be completed, which by the late-game began to be drawn out. I had nothing left to do but wait and run through random missions thrown at me by the game. I had no use for Invasions as I didn't require any more money or soldiers. As you can imagine, this became tedious and started to drag the latter part of the game which feels like something that probably shouldn't happen in 2022. This is a shame as until then I had enjoyed the game.

So I recommend that if you haven't yet, play this game at least once! The gameplay holds up, but be aware the late-game can drag if you're like me and, as a RPGamer, I want everything I can find. Missions can become repetitive but the strategic options open to you can keep it from becoming entirely stale. That being said make sure you do purchase/play with the 'Enemy Within' content.
