Operation Burning Sword- just another routine UFO sweep; armed with Fusion Lances, Firestorm interceptors in the United States downed a large alien battleship.. a squad of elite operatives was sent in to secure the crash site, but none of them returned... this is their story. 

XCOM was going through some changes, BIG things; the Psionics Lab was working overtime to assess all high-ranking officers and recruits for psionic capabilities; having several dozens of missions under their belt, the most vetted and elite operatives came forward, not a one below Colonel rank.. This was no ordinary squad however... each soldier had seen their whole squad wiped out before their eyes (being on ironman mode) and came out on top- from eagle-eyed Snipers to Heavy indirect fire support the team was solid.. or so I thought. Standard issue for this playthrough of XCOM, each soldier was outfitted with plasma weaponry and either Titan or Archangel armor (with 2 slots ofc for an added layer of protection by nano-fiber vest...) 

Operation Burning Sword, much akin to hellfire, Muspelheim, and the Angel that guardeth Eden, ended in f******* disaster. Not a single operative would make it back alive... Genetically modified supersoldiers, down to their secondary hearts (to prevent death on loss of all health) and Neural modifications to negate mind-controlling effects, they had never met an enemy they couldn't defeat... until the dark day.. until i realized that sending them in to be assessed by the Psi-Labs UNEQUIPPED their weapons... The snipers could only pew pew away with focused lethality and anticlimatic bullets worth 3 damage against relentless mutons with 10HP and flying mechanized enemies that always got that elevation hit bonus, shooting through the smoke cloud of my support with derision.. before he could make the extra blue-grid movement to stabilize the fallen Assault class, "Axle", the codename lovingly chosen by some higher power upon his promotion to SGT class, would be mowed down and left to bleed out as the flying enemies outflanked, harassed, and made lucky/skillful plays against my elites. Behind a door and away from the main conflict, the Snipers kept up their barrage with their pew pew S*** rifles instead of with the precision and power of their normally-issued heavy plasma sniper rifles.. Col Wilson emptied her clip in a checkers-esque use of killing enemies outside of cover (as drones are wont to do) only to switch to her pistol too late, as a Mechtoid hidden from view in a stairway not 10 feet away (it was the elevation difference that hid it from LOS) emptied it's clip in a friendly hello.. because that f****r had to be smiling sentient AI or no I felt it smile.. One by one, my 6-man elite squad, invested in, recruited, trained, and vetted in the fire and anvil of futuristic warfare, bled out TURN BY TURN with nobody to revive them. "Alpha", a soldier from Norway, was first to fall. "Axle", support from the US, got a faceful of mechtoid rounds for his efforts to stabilize his fallen comrade.. "Zulu" the aforementioned sniper that never got to return the hello, was the proverbial puddle in the rear.. the other sniper died as well.. panic sets in, I groan, and I watch with horror as "Mad Man" got taken out by a Sectopod from it's maximum range volley attack... the Heavy "Diesel" would shortly follow, her bonus dmg against robotics enemies being unmet potential as none of her shots failed to connect at a mere 55% hit chance.. but that was all I could really do. Again, I watched in horror as the massive cannon carved a giant hole in her stomach.. *Beep, Beep* the sound went as another operative lay bleeding out and dying.. Jesus Castillo AKA Desperado was the last one from the whole squad, and as much as I would like to say he died valiantly, like a man yet not quite the savior I hoped he would be, I can't blame him for it... When he got lasered to the brain, I couldn't weep, I couldn't angrily beat the desk holding the monitor in front of me.. I must've stared at that screen, my best 6 "guys" KIA in a routine mop-up mission against a downed UFO.. and when you get WIPE WIPED, the voice actor who plays Central (the only other one apart from the german chick and engineer dude that you can hear true soul in,) calls STATUS BLACK CONFIRMED.. and right then my heart broke and a little piece of me died inside...
10/10 would pew pew again and watch the world burn before I'd have let "Prophet" die... my extensive use of skipping missions until I had scouted a full Psionic party gave me a horrific call from the Council I'm not likely to forget D:

My background: heavy XCOM fan. Played and loved original UFO: Enemy Unknown (1994) , X-COM: Terror from the Deep (1995) and X-COM: Apocalypse (1997)  remember that one? That one was awesome!

I recommend this game because it IS a good game. And it actually is a very good remake of the original 1994 game. I was actually hit with nostalgic blast from the past when reading some of research information. Some of those lines were took directly from the original. Very nice touch.
However I'm a tad disappointed by some of the changes to game mechanics. 
1.	One base. In original game I setup numerous bases. Some with radar and interceptors. Other purely for storage. This allowed for more freedom of choice and. Here you are restricted to just one location based on continent.
2.	One assault craft. In original you could research advanced assault craft with bigger troop capacity. This allowed for bigger battles with more soldiers.
3.	No more action points. In original each soldier had a number of Aps determined by his stats. This allowed for precise planning: move 2 spaces, pick up plasma rifle, take aimed shot. Here you just have 2 actions. This feels like a restriction rather than improvement.
4.	Soldiers don’t have inventory. This one is tragic. A soldier is given a scope and therefore cannot have a grenade? Oh come on!!
5.	Unlimited ammo. Oh come on!! In original you needed to have ammo in your inventory. You had to manage it. That was much more realistic and deep. Here you can reload as much as you want. Too much simplification!

In summary: while I enjoy playing this game I feel its too scripted for a proper strategy and too simplified for a proper tactical combat game.

[i]XCOM: Enemy Unknown[/i] is a disaster to the strategy genre that tries to hide its lack of any mechanical complexity with flashy animations and soldier customization.

Gameplay missions are boring to play. Early-game is a matter of stat checking your squad, with their guns and explosives, against the aliens, and late-game encourages you to fight as uninteractively as possible by thinning the aliens with snipers, then finishing them off with assaults.

Once you finish the mission, you can rank up your soldiers to give them skills, but there is no decision-making involved. One of the two skills is better than the other.

Research has a clear, ideal research path, removing it as an outlet for the player to make decisions. No game situation can alter the ideal research path.

Engineering is done well. Resources are scarce enough so you need to choose who you want to equip with the newest equipment first, however, once you equip your soldiers, it becomes a non-mechanic.

Creating the base in a grid is a well-designed system, but there aren't enough buildings to make base design something of much consideration past the very early game.

The difficulty curve of the game is highly early game weighted, which makes no sense. People installing the game will experience 1-2 months in game of difficult (stat checking) encounters, followed by 4 months of boring repetitive gameplay.

The story is non-existent, or unclear at best. Somehow the developers managed to go to [i]XCOM: 2[/i] without retconning any of the “story”, but all of the “story” is just shoehorned in on literally the last mission.

The one redeeming feature is the animations. It’s hard to not cheer on your soldiers when they take a shot against the aliens, but this novelty eventually becomes tedious, as there’s no way to skip the animation. Additionally, the customization available to your soldiers does matter, and you can have unique soldiers who may be named after your friends (though, maybe don’t tell them that).

Overall, [i]XCOM: Enemy Unknown[/i] and its accompanying expansion [i]Enemy Within[/i] abstracts away too much of the strategy in this “strategy game” in favor of admittedly flashy animations and customizable characters. I don’t recommend you play this game. If you want a better experience play [i]XCOM: 2[/i] which expands on every mechanic.

Not a fan of tactical/strategy games but think you have the potential to be? Play XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It's a masterfully simplified re-imagining of a classic turn-based strategy game with an engaging gameplay loop that is very well tutorialized and easy to understand. Maybe you've never touched a game like this in your life, but you may just discover your new favorite time sink here.

Fan of tactical/strategy games? You've probably played XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but if you haven't then you should. Its simplified interface and tactical systems belie a surprising amount of strategic depth both in missions and in the long term base management game. And if that's not enough for you, a bevy of unlockable Second Wave options and the developer recommended Long War mod can add thousands of hours to a game that can already easily steal 400 hours from you.


Positives

- Stimulating gameplay loop: Go out on missions, kill aliens, get better materials, build better weapons, kill bigger aliens. It's the stuff dreams are made of, and it's addictive as all get-out.

- Tactical depth: An easy-to-learn, difficult-to-master turn-based movement and combat system, combined with ruthless enemy AI and a decent variety of maps make for hundreds and thousands of hours of alien killing fun

- Enemy unknown: An interesting enemy force to face and learn about through the research tree along with a decent story will spice up your first playthrough at the very least, although the cutscenes leave a lot to be desired


Negatives

- Jankiness: No game works perfectly, and this game is no exception. After 500 hours with it, I've encountered a lot of glitches related to line of sight and a few related to critical wound stabilization that killed a particularly important Ironman run for me. I've had to reinstall it a couple of times as well.

- Difficulty: I like my hard games, but difficulty can be a double-edged sword and XCOM seems to enjoy straddling the razor. An XCOM campaign's first couple of months are the most challenging, followed by a nice breezy middle few months, and wrapped up with a moderately challenging final stretch of missions, and this wonky difficulty curve is only further exaggerated on higher difficulty levels.

- Story execution: This is a minor nitpick, but the attempts to characterize your three main helper people in the cutscenes as part of a larger story were, I don't know... misguided maybe?

[h1]Highly Recommended for anybody liking Turn Based Tactics![/h1]

This was my first game from the X-Com/UFO Franchise, but certainly not my first Turn Based Tactics Game. And it ticked all the right boxes! Although not being exactly beginner friendly, once you get a grip at everything, it's very satisfying. It kind of strikes a perfect balance between challenging you to the point of frustration, then makes it up to you by being very rewarding if you succeed. An admittedly delicate balance, but they pulled it off. It keeps you on your toes most of the time and the moments of victory are so satisfying, since you've really earned them! Clever tactics really pay off and high-risk manoeuvres provide high rewards, IF they succeed. Very well done.
The RTS part of base building is a nice addition but could have been more transparent in the beginning. It's fun, has a huge impact on your success and really adds to the game. But early mistakes can spoil it a bit. Also, they really managed to grow a connection with your team. You choose them, you develop them, you don’t want to lose them! Weapons-, Mod- and Skill systems also work very well and lets you create a team after your taste, whatever that may be.

The only drawback in terms of balancing is, when you stay patient and try to complete as much as you can on the world map, before progressing the main story parts, you will reach a tipping point where you become a bit OP. The game has some mechanics, that’ll push you, make you hurry and rush… if you can manage to not give in, you’ll become quite strong in the second half or late game.

Overall, a fantastic Turn Based Tactics Game! One of the best in my opinion.

 [u]Pros:[/u]

- very good, but borderline balance between challenge and reward
- nice story, actually (no, really…yes, alien invasion and the likes, seen a hundred times, but this is actually ok)
- the constant change between combat missions and base building / research adds welcome variety
- good design, at least I personally like it
- good balance between turn based tactics combat and real-time base building
- individual team members really grow on you
- base building is fun, once you get a grip on it
- mostly good and reliable combat mechanics

 [u]Cons:[/u]

-  can be very challenging & frustrating at times
- patience required, you need to like this sort of game
- base building could be better explained
- hit chances sometimes feel a bit off, not according to the numbers (just bad luck?)

 [u]Tipps:[/u]

-although it is designed to lose people in combat, I played without a single lost team member (except for the tutorial, which is impossible to avoid), so it’s possible and very rewarding to never loose anybody. It requires a lot of repetition and patience but is possible. Try at least, as it will make your team stronger and save resources no needing to recruit, develop and teach new members for it!
- resist the pressing urge, the game creates in base building mode. Be quick, when necessary, but take your time when possible. It’s worth it in the second half!

I was a big fan of the original X-Com and of similar tactical games in general, so I was looking forward to this release well in advance.

When it actually came out, I found it to be really disappointing. Rather than using the power of modern computing to create a deeper game-play experience, they spent all of those development hours creating a graphically advanced (but still quite ugly), vastly dumbed down reboot of the original that plays in a deeply repetitive way. If you want a tactical game, I'd suggest skipping it in favour of a more robust gameplay experience like licking a flagpole on a cold winter day. If you want to play some kind of janky gun chess where cover only covers if you have your gigantic side of beef chest pressed against it and concealment doesn't meaningfully exist, maybe get it on a deeply discounted Steam sale.

A beautiful, well balanced, graphically compelling turn-based strategy game, though much easier compared to its predecessors from the 90's, such as Terror from the Deep. Hardened players will find even the Classic difficulty unchallenging, so they might try Impossible difficulty and Ironman mode on the condition that they will not rush things, or they might lose their squad in as little as a few consecutive turns. Out of the two paths to upgrade the soldiers, genetic modifications seem to be the more rewarding ones as MECs will usually have a sloppy targeting mechanism. Adaptive Bone Marrow and Mimetic Skin are two modifications that provide the player with substantial advantages over the enemy. Two snipers with both of these modifications and Plasma Sniper Rifles are going to take out most of the aliens with a single critical hit, and bring down a Mechtoid or even the toughest Sectopod in one turn with the help of a well positioned team. One thing I've missed was something close to TFTD's enthralling soundtrack, but I guess the nostalgia is a common problem with us millennials who have witnessed the origins of these new iterations. All in all, if you're familiar with the XCOM franchise or just getting acquainted with the TBS genre, this is where to start.

It's fun, it's addictive, it's frustrating, it's punishing. Yes, all of those statements are true.

When everything works and your squad actually hits their targets, your plan works and you have enough money and resources to upgrade... that's when you get into the flow of just one more round, one more mission, one more research project. And to be fair, that's the majority of the time - depending on the difficulty you select of course and potentially a lot more punishing in 'Iron Man' mode where you only have one save game!

But there is also the,more frustrating side of the game. It's when you trigger a swarm of enemies by just moving your character one tile too far. Or, my 'favorite', when the game spawns opponents behind your position out of thin air. And speaking of favorites, those panic missions where you need to rescue civilians, are by far my least fun part of the game.

As far as content goes, the base game 'Enemy Unknown' is already plenty long but you really want to get the 'Enemy Within' DLC as it easily doubles the size and adds a ton of new research and upgrade options to the game. Not to mention another faction, new mission types and all in all a lot more depth to an already great game.

XCOM is basically two underlying games:

1) Fighting - The core of this game is turn-based tactical strategy.  With the right set of abilities and load-outs, you can build squads that are virtually unstoppable.  As long as you're good with turn-based games, this one is excellent and engaging.

2) Base management - The rest of this game is researching and planning your base, deploying satellites, hiring and training soldiers to go into fights.  Honestly this part is a bit tedious, and you always have that nagging feeling that you're not doing it optimally.  However, as long as you focus on not losing countries, always shooting down UFOs, and don't neglect fighter research, you will be fine.

Overall this game is very addicting and has a lot of replay-ability.  Highly recommend.

Played the original Xcom: Apocolypse back in the 90's.   I waited a long time for this game to come out again.  Game play is very familiar, reminiscent of the old game.  Playing the game again, I remember why I loved the 90's version -- strategy and alien opponents.  Xcom:Apocolypse was better in some ways;  there was a sense of real mystery as the maps were huge and you never knew if you really had gotten rid of the aliens on maps.  This open-endedness continued in later maps when you could eventually travel to the alien's realm.   In Xcom: Enemy Unknown, the missions are more clearly defined in the sense that it's urgent that you eliminate or capture aliens at each encounter.   Because if you don't eliminate or capture, there are serious "political" consequences that directly effect your ability to advance and build your technology and resources.  I find this geo-political aspect of the game interesting, but I would have preferred that the programmers concentrate on alien AI, richer alien technologies, and a wider range of possibilities to ending a map/mission.  Overall, I'd give it a solid "B".

XCOM is one of the best turn-based strategy game to pick and even more with Enemy Within which covers most of its flaw: repetition but obviously it adds more content to the game as well. There are 2 big key components to the game, the first one is the management of the base and the second is the tactical combat. 

The management of the base is simple but offers enough to be interesting and rewarding with research, crafting items, upgrading items, building rooms, recruit and train units and augmenting and enhancing units both added with Enemy Within. Early on, the higher the difficulty the more important the decisions on where to spend the limited resources available making a significant difference during missions which is important for an engaging experience in my opinion. Something about this game makes character customisation compelling, it's not very in-depth unfortunately the more characters the easier it gets to see that they start to look the same but creating your own squad of characters is fun nonetheless to make the experience that much more unique.

For the tactical combat, the gameplay is fun and doesn't over-complicate itself remaining on an easy to understand level mechanically while requiring more on the strategy side. I feared the RNG would be rough but thankfully It's exaggerated and while the occasional streaks of bad luck do feel like everything is going wrong the amount of good hits landed vastly overshadow the missed hits. I believe my overall accuracy was around 75% so it's fair to say the RNG is actually player-favoured and simply having a good strategy will make the biggest difference at the end of the day. When it comes down to the camera I have a small problem with it in closed spaces with elevation when moving units sometimes it's necessary to rotate the camera at the right angle to get the desired tile highlighted which in the early hours made things a bit annoying since I had to reload a few times. The auto-save system is a bit buggy, it randomly stopped working at times and did overwrite some recently made auto-saves when reloading resulting in frustration and some lost time so I simply went back to my habit of manually saving a lot. Those are minor issues however, repetition is probably the flaw I can see some people disliking and it comes from the maps and enemies thankfully with Enemy Within more maps and mission types are added. The enemies are not bad but it's simply that most of them can be handled the same and all of their variants are essentially the same but with better stats so the strategy is kind of identical throughout the course of the game. I can't say it made the game any less enjoyable but I did notice how I wouldn't think much anymore when I was mid-game because I already met the first iteration of every alien so the rest weren't much different to handle. Aside from those small flaws which may not affect most players it's satisfying to do missions as they give off this uneasy feeling of exploring the unknown with the creepy ambient sounds and atmosphere it suits really well the theme of an alien invasion with the saucers and the aliens with the big eyes and slender body in a space suit so well done on overall.

To conclude, pretty good game for someone looking for a turn-based strategy game with some base management on the side and the setting was surprisingly more interesting to me than I anticipated given how simple it looks I did expect that, it was probably helped a lot by the atmosphere of the unknown alien threat that was well executed. 9/10 I also highly recommend to get Enemy Within as well for the added content to make for a great experience.

I really wanted to like XCOM: Enemy Unknown. I didn't hate it, but I can't even bring myself to feel mediocre about it. My main problem with XCOM is repetition. The battles are decent fun at first but they lack variety in both terrain and enemies. The tactical level was far shallower than I was expecting. You'd think destructible terrain and a versatile cover/flanking system would lead to interesting battles but often they just... don't. Your soldiers are slow, fragile, and inconsistent fighters at best, especially in the early game when you're learning the ropes. This encourages careful, conservative strategies which never really lose their effectiveness despite being mind-numbingly tedious. Luring aliens into ambushes loses its luster rather quickly. Don't get me wrong, fun and surprising things can happen, but so many of my battles were one-sided slaughters (not always in my favor, of course). This would all be fine if XCOM was a much shorter game, but in a 20-30 hour campaign its gameplay wears thin rather quickly. Seen one crashed UFO in a forest, seen 'em all.

I've heard plenty about the famous XCOM rng over the years. I didn't have much of a problem with it tbh. I had a few moments where I missed 95% chance shots or hit 10% shots, so it balanced itself out. Thankfully the aliens are just as vulnerable to bad rng. It does contribute to the conservative playstyle I mentioned above, however. Why bother with close combat when I can lure enemies into my sniper's line of sight for guaranteed hits and massive damage? Taking risks feels too, well, *risky* in most scenarios.

The base-building and strategy components feel pretty good. You research technology, construct upgrades, facilities, and weapons, and you manage XCOM's funding and diplomatic relationships. None of this is especially deep but it's enough to be engaging. I really enjoyed the feeling of mastering the alien tech and gaining intel on my enemies -- the journey from Enemy Unknown to Enemy Known Inside and Out is XCOM's strongest aspect by far. The actual story is pretty straightforward. "Understand the aliens, kill the aliens" works perfectly well for a game like this, so I have no complaints here.

Overall, as I've said, I don't hate XCOM: Enemy Unknown. But its pitfalls ultimately outweigh the things I like, so I can't recommend it. I understand why so many people like it so much but it's just not for me. I've heard XCOM 2 fixes a lot of issues, but frankly I'm not interested in continuing the series.

There aren't enough combat-focused games out there which demand caution and tactical security from the player. XCOM:EU is one such title. 

If you units move too fast into uncharted territory, if you don't mind cover and lines of sight judiciously, if you spread your squads too thin across too many theaters of a firefight, you will lose units. These units are easily replaceable, but their skills not so much, and the time invested in developing them - as well as the emergent stories of their role in the campaign, which aren't narrated but can easily grow on the player - are not at all. Cultivating a squad of veterans, particularly in the higher difficulties, requires caution, temperance, and luck. 

At the same time, the game is quite good at stimulating tension and impelling the player forward despite the risks here. Managing the global politics of the XCOM project often forces the player to take on tougher missions than ideal for the circumstances in order to prevent panic from spiraling out of control and the withdrawal of nations from XCOM. The Enemy Within expansion (which I fully recommend) adds a valuable resource needed for advanced soldier augmentations, Meld, which must be found on the map before it expires in a random number of turns. Saving civilians in terror missions, and doing any good at it, means getting to them before the aliens do and using your own troops to draw their focus instead. 

Purely as a strategy and tactics experience, XCOM is quite nice. It also has an excellent story, graphical aesthetic, and soundtrack to boot - and while the game is (visibly) nearing on ten years old, that experience remains quite a trip. If you are fond of tactics, squad-building, unpredictable challenges, and shadowy organizations dealing with aliens, XCOM is a game for you.

When it first came out, I expected to hate this game.  I'm generally very wary of reboots because they're usually terrible, and most of the current wave of reboots of classic 90s games have been abysmal cash grabs.  This game is the exception.  This game does NOT play like the original X-COM: UFO Defense from the 90s, but it is a very good game in its own right.  It's a reimagining and modernization of the core concept in the best possible way, coming up with a very different game from the original.  I was so pleased that my initial impressions from the pre-launch trailers were wrong.  This has become one of my favorite games of all time and there are very good reasons I've put 1000 hours into it.

If you've never heard of the original and are wondering why you should play this game, well, this franchise is the benchmark for the turn-based squad tactics genre.  All other games in the genre get compared to the XCOM franchise, and for good reason.  XCOM has a solid balance of squad management, RPG progression, and fun and challenging tactical missions.  You'll bemoan every failure and celebrate every success.  Victory is hard-earned and this game is not easy, but it does reward the player who learns from their mistakes and improves their tactics.

Warning though: this game was made for console and ported to PC, and it shows.  The UI is really not optimized for PC and there are some occasional frustrating bugs in combat.  Save early, save often, don't be afraid to reload when you encounter a bug.

In XCOM: Enemy Unknown, victory is sweet--but it's so much sweeter when it arrives after a heart-wrenching standoff. With each turn, the newest entry in this beloved strategy series heightens the sense of tension, and each defeat of a hovering alien craft thus becomes cause for celebration. But don't get too intoxicated by the faint scent of triumph: nothing is certain until you've ripped your last enemy to shreds. Getting cocky and rushing ahead is a fool's strategy, and until the alien threat is eliminated, your guard must remain up.

Enemy Unknown isn't a simple remake of the original X-COM: UFO Defense, but like that game, it cannily instills a sense of fear. Earth is under attack by aliens, and the game makes no attempts to humanize the attackers. This isn't District 9--it's The War of the Worlds, and extraterrestrial invaders are to be annihilated, not welcomed or bargained with. This might be a modern rendition of an older game, but developer Firaxis relies on old-fashioned fears to drive its narrative. Almond-eyed greys and floating saucers ripped from popular culture need no explanation: they're clearly not of this world, and they're clearly out to destroy us. And so it's up to you, the commander of the super-secretive XCOM organization, to make Earth a safe haven once again.

Gameplay is divided into two portions: base management and combat scenarios. Near the beginning of the game, you select a location for your base of operations from one of several possibilities. The choices are more limited than the ones in the original X-COM, and this is the only base you manage through the course of the game. If you're a fan of the original, being limited to a single base might seem cause for concern, as might the subsequent loss of the oft-challenging base invasions. It may not share the full breadth of the game that spawned the franchise, but it would be difficult to accuse Enemy Unknown of "dumbing down" the core gameplay. Nevertheless, if you crave a relentless challenge (if not quite as relentless as the nail-biting X-COM: Terror From the Deep), you should play on classic difficulty, rather than the default difficulty level.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a wonderful and worthy strategy game with a layer of campy charm that makes the stone-faced seriousness of the game's characters all the more endearing. It's also remarkably accessible, thanks to a great interface that feels comfortable whether you're using a keyboard and mouse or have a controller in your hand. Enemy Unknown packs dense amounts of dramatic tension into each turn. And so it's time to eliminate the alien threat, commander. Select a location, build your base…and save humanity.

Verdict: 10/10

This is probably my favorite turn-based combat game of all time. Having played through XCOM:EU/EW and XCOM 2 multiple times, I still think XCOM:EW is the better game overall. Enemy Unknown, while still a great game, allowed for too much passiveness during combat. Enemy Within tries to add a level of urgency during battles so you can't just turtle. The reward for that urgency is the ability to modify your soldiers with incredible, game-changing upgrades: like giving your soldiers the ability to turn invisible at times or chopping off all their arms and legs to put them into a giant anime mec (cause why not?). XCOM 2, I feel, they went a bit overboard with the urgency mechanics. To the point where the game just felt stressful to play all the time. 

XCOM:EW strikes the almost perfect balance. It still allows for a bit too much passiveness which can make combat slow. The reverse difficulty curve is also something to know about going in: the early game is definitely more difficult than the late game by far, even on classic difficulty. There is also no procedural map generation like XCOM2, so you will see the same maps multiple times. 

Still, I've played through this game at least 5 times now on every difficulty up to classic and I still want to go back and play it again. So, it must be doing something right.

This was a great gaming experience!

Truth be told I had to start over and over again several times, untill I was able to find the strategy that suited me best.

There are moments when a 98% chance to hit the enemy is more like 40% chance and vice versa... Aside all the negative stuff you could attribute to the games AI or chance to hit engine, this is a real jewel of a game. This is a remake of the old XCOM for those who didn't know.

You get Four Classes from the base game, plus gene modifications and Cyber upgrades later on greatly improoving your tactical choises in the field. The gameplay works fine, there are very few bugs and overall it is a great investment. It is guaranteed that it will keep you busy for many days!

Graphics and sound are good, the story is preety basic, yet it makes you feel like your troops are real heroes and saviors of Earth.

My advice for new players? Buy full package for starters, once you begin the game play on classic difficulty 4 members only, it might seem hard at first but it is a cost effective gearwise plus you get to upgrade troops a lot faster since the kill rewards are concentrated on fewer members. Finally regardless of what you think, go all out for satellte coverage! Once 3/4 of the planets countries are under your protection you get tons of money for buying proper gear, aircrats, weapons etc. Infrastracture brings mid and late game benefits which outweight the early game hard difficulty... Also I used to play with a roullete where the skills of each soldier were randomized... Yeah it might seem cool, but using the vanila setting offer more specialized troopers who end up being a lot more efficient. Random stats are good, you need them to have as high as possible aim the rest are useless more or less.

A definetly buy!

[b]In Short:[/b] [i]This game marked the beginning of my exposure to strategy turn-based industry with tactical gameplay elements. Modern gaming industry owes an appreciation to this game specifically for popularizing this genre and bringing attention to it, which was how I learned about this awesome series. This game has aged when compared to its sequel, XCOM 2. If you are considering purchasing this game in 2021+ for the narrative before playing the sequel, I do not recommend spending your money. Purchase it only if you genuinely enjoy the genre of turn-based strategy, but do be warned this game can be harder and more punishing than XCOM 2. More challenging![/i]

The review is organized by categories with additional notes if I have something to add.

[b]Game's Visuals (Graphics)[/b]
[ ] Beautiful
[x] Good
[ ] Decent

[ ] Poor

Personal Note: I love cartoony style! I'm biased. That's all I have to say. To most, it may look decent, but it's definitely not bad. I find this artstyle pleasing to the eye without ruining the immersion, atmosphere or feeling of [i]realism[/i].

[b]Game's Sound Design[/b]
[ ] Beautiful
[ ] Good
[x] Decent
[ ] Bad
[ ] Poor

Personal Note: Solid sound design. Not a masterpiece, but it gets the job done. Weapons sound fitting, the alien sounds match, voice-actors are fair, and so on. Plus, this game provides voice-acting for soldiers on multiple languages, including Russian! [i]The language the second installment didn't include...[/i]

[b]Gameplay Mechanics[/b]
[ ] Beautiful
[x] Good
[ ] Decent
[ ] Bad
[ ] Poor

Personal Note: For its time, this was a [i]one-of-a-kind[/i] turn-based strategy. There were not many options on the market with similar gameplay to XCOM. Now, it's a different story. However, if you wish to experience one of the [i]Founding Fathers[/i] of the strategy turn-based games, you will definitely hear about XCOM!

[b]Story/Narrative[/b]
[x] Beautiful
[ ] Good
[ ] Decent
[ ] Bad
[ ] Poor

Personal Note: If [i]taking charge of an international organization, that is similar to the real life U.N., in response to an alien invasion in order to combat the foreign and unknown enemy as humanity unites in its darkest hour[/i] doesn't sound EPIC to you, I don't know what could impress you! Personally, I've really enjoyed the narrative and story. I felt engaged and curious about the intentions of the alien invasion. In some cases, it was even brutal. Again, it's not a masterpiece, but I really enjoyed the story this game told me as I, the player, progressed it forward.

[b]Replayability[/b]
[x]Yes!
[ ] Kinda
[ ] None

Personal Note: Definitely! The story never changes, it ultimately comes down to your victory or your defeat. However, the journey to the end of game in each campaign will be different. The nature of this game will never have the exactly same experience, with an exception of few scripted mission. There is no direct Steam Workshop for this game, but there is a well-known mod for this game known as "Long War." Recommended if you wish to change up the gameplay.

[b]Final Note:[/b]

So, this is a great game.  A game that's been around for forever....but that's the thing, if a game's been around for years upon years, there's no reason for it to have as many bugs as it does.  The bugs range from long pauses during attacks on your troops, and on the enemy, to clear graphic corruption during maps.  I've had issues launching the game a few times.  Even when the game is running smoothly, you'll see that each map is kinda tedious - it takes 2-3 and even 4 turns to find enemies.  Your turn is always followed by an Alien turn, where you're forced to watch and hear off-screen aliens move about.....which is highly irrelevant if you're nowhere your Alien opponents.  Even when you're actively fighting the aliens, you can't skip/fast-forward through their turn.  Sometimes you'll be putting the finishing touches on one enemy (and you know it's the last enemy on the map)....and you'll still be forced to watch.  If you've played alot like me, you've seen this kind of scene 1000+ times, and you'd rather just skip it.  As you can see, I've played alot (109 hours).  Great game, but I can't say it's solid.  I'm not sure if there's ever been updates since launch, but I can say that I've never seen any update since I've owned this (2 years), and there's still loads of bugs. PROS:
This game has a great premise. Unique mechanics, cool environments. I spent hours and hours building my roster, customizing and upgrading the team, and using them to smash the enemy. It's really a fun game and worth playing, very satisfying despite the slower pace. It's a turn based squad tactics game.

It's extremely addictive, and a really unique version of the alien invasion theme. It deals with body horror, and evolution. Cool. If you can get past the huge learning curve, winning this game is extremely rewarding.

CONS:
It's frustrating; the physics and imbalance issues are at times too much to take. In the early game you can expect your soldiers to literally cry like babies when they're shot at, and kill each other in a panic. Also, guns are almost useless in higher difficulties; the soldiers miss almost always, and barely do any damage. You are at an unfair disadvantage early on, to the point where it IS comical, if not pathetic and infuriating.

I'd say buy it on sale. It's fun, but might test your patience too much if you plan to finish it.

Update: I tried this game again, and eventually beat it. VERY REWARDING. But the physics are still nonsense. I recommend it, mostly.

I'm normally not that into strategy games, especially when they're turn based. Somehow they feel slow, and I just want to unwind without thinking about things too much. But Xcom managed to pull me right in. It succesfully mixes turn based strategy with a bit of management, and,... guess what ? It's great fun !

Xcom uses a certain graphical style, which reminded me a bit of Team Fortress 2. It's not super detailed by any means, but I still liked the clean look of things.

The combat is brilliant, with the camera zooming in when a certain action is taken. It makes the combat feel exciting. Completing missions and killing enemies will level up your soldiers. You'll learn to take care of them, because when they're a higher level some of their abilities might just save you and your squad.

The story is nothing special, but the way the whole game is executed is just amazing. You'll have to make some difficult choices (concerning building certain items/facilities and the missions you choose to accept), none of which are right or wrong.

The sounds and music also add to the atmosphere of the entire game.

Also, for a single-player game it's surprisingly lenghty as well. It should take most players well over 20 hours to complete, especially if you mess up your first few games (like me). 

Highly recommended !

Do you like punishingly challenging turn-based strategy games? How about a bit of base management as a cherry on top? I don't even remember what it was that got me to pick up XCOM: EU however many years ago, but I can say this much: as a person who would reply "holy hell, yes" to both of the above questions, it has been WELL worth the purchase.

This game has an incredibly dedicated mod fanbase which helps keep it fresh and interesting (i.e. increasingly brutal). If you've never done a single hex edit in your life, the how-to guides make it totally doable for a dedicated neophyte.

The game play curve is severely front-loaded. Getting the hang of the early game can be frustrating but made me feel like Sun Tzu and Rain Man's biologically and temporally improbable offspring once I made it through a whole playthrough without losing a single country. Consequentially, a front-loaded game tends to have a bit of a boring or repetitive late game, and XCOM is no exception. You know it's good when ... everything clicks.

WARNING: This game has technical difficulties!
If you start having problems saving your game (probably about 10-15 hours into the game), just delete most of your previous saved games. You can delete them from within the game (no need to find folders and files).
If you can manage to have a max of around 10 saved games at any one time, saving shouldn't be a problem.
At least this worked for me.

TIP: If you buy this game in a bundle with the expansion DLC "XCOM - Enemy Within", just skip to the expansion immediately. You'll be playing the base game, just with more variety (more stuff to research, additional different maps, additional types of enemies etc.).

Oh, and the game is really good!
It's basically 50% a resource management game and 50% tactical combat. Both parts are well done.
Sure, the game doesn't have much depth and is pretty repetitive - but what it does, it does very well.

If you can live with some technical issues (crashes, problems with saved games) and you like turn-based tactical games, this might very well be up your alley.


EDIT: originally I gave this game a "not recommended" review because of the issues with saving the game. Once I got around that problem, however, I changed my review.

[b]X-COM: Enemy Unknown / Enemy Within[/b] is a timeless classic. Perfect, in nearly every single way. Just the right mix of depth and approachable, EW is a tactical game that makes you feel smart and powerless at the same time.

There are areas where the game could have stood to have [i]more[/i] -- more character customization, more resolution, more shaders. This game has a sequel that builds on it. But this game is where it began again. It's a good-ass game, which I recommend buying at any price.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is the very successful remake of UFO: Enemy Unknonwd, hit released on Amiga and Pc in the 90s, it was hard to be able to equal it or surpass it. Many XCOM or UFO stamped games have since been released, but many have not proven to be better or similar to this mythical ancestor.

Then Fireaxys the studio of Sid "Civilization" Meier's it is leaning on a title which will be the worthy heir of UFO. The background is now commonplace (this was not the case with UFO at the time), an alien invasion that threatens humanity, a para-military organization funded by a small group made up of many countries around the world.

Two big changes are noted all the same, which seem abused on paper but ultimately not so useless given the hardcore difficulty of the title at its highest levels.

Firstly, the management of the xcom base, in UFO we could manage several tactical bases, there a single main base like HQ, that may not seem like much but it is largely sufficient, because over the course of the game several bases would be very difficult to manage. For the rest it is similar to the other xcom and ufo games, with military buildings and other scientific complexes, everything is there to counter this invasion.

Second point and not insignificant (at the beginning of course), the composition of the squads for ground operations. Fireaxys wanted to make the game more tactical than its predecessors with squads made up of 6 soldiers maximum as opposed to 24 on UFO. At first glance really too little but in the long term it is judicious, it allows to better prepare its strategies, 24 soldiers would be too heavy to manage.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is epic, very cinematic and incredibly violent in terms of urban combat, it shoots at all costs for nervous and stressful gunfight, it panics, it dies and there are moments of bravery worthy of the greatest war movies, pure happiness. Served by many scenaristically successful cinematics but less design level (unlike the whole game).

There are side missions that are well entrenched in the original storyline, like the board missions, which gives the game a bit of a revival, and the recent enemy within DLC adds even more side missions and gameplay.

You want epic, listen to the soundtrack during the travel, preparation and mission phases, this is the orgy.

Count 30 hours of easy play but multiply that by 10 in impossible or marathon mode.

It was entertaining for a while, but after some time it didn't feel strategic at all. I felt the fog of war disruptive to gameplay, for 2 reasons.

First, since I want to find the aliens as fast as possible, I fan out my units. This means that when I do find enemies most of the units are far away, and for the next few turns I spend half my commands telling them to move closer to the battle.

Second, It feels like it forces me to be less strategic, as my desire to keep troops in good cover conflicts with the incentive to find and kill the aliens as fast as possible. For example, I might either move my unit twice and uncover enemies, who will shoot that unit, and I cannot do anything to protect that unit since I have used all moves. On the other hand, If I keep my troops in cover, I move much slower, and find out 6 turns later that I could have just rushed it in 4 turns, and now won't finish the mission fast enough.

To avoid these problems I reload the save and move with the benefit of hindsight. Following this gameplay cycle felt boring and repetitive after a while. This really took out the tension and atmosphere of the fear of ambush, but not reloading saves meant I would never find and kill the aliens fast enough to salvage the bonus resources, and spend half my turn just telling my units to get closer to the fight. Essentially, the game incentivised me to more or less kill immersion, which is a real shame, cause the music and the sound effects really made me feel anxious for when I would encounter the aliens. To fix this I would make it so such that the aliens are alerted when you drop your troops in, if you don't find them they will find you, and once contact is made with aliens, they communicate to the other aliens to come and help them. This way I would spend a lot less time trying to find aliens and more time fighting aliens instead. It also would be entirely realistic. These guys figured out space travel but didn't figure out calling their army buddies for help when attacked? We use radio, surely they at very least use radio!

Moving on, the combat was also boring, again due to the fog of war. When the aliens are attacked they don't communicate to the other aliens in the building to help, so they mostly fight you in small groups at a time. This meant that much of combat was simply overwhelming the small group with my firepower.

Comparatively, enjoyed the combat in Great Little War Game far more, simply because there was much greater variety. You had to worry about certain armour being better penetrated by certain ammunition types, so you would want to ensure specific types of troops would want to fight specific other types of troops to maximise the matchup advantage, but there's no such concept in this game. There aren't enemies weaker to laser beams than bullets, or weaker to a melee weapon that a ranged weapon, so when I encounter small groups I only need to consider which enemies are in whose range. I don't have to consider shooting this type of alien with a laser instead of bullets, this type of alien with a grenade instead of lasers, this type of alien with a melee weapon rather that ranged weapons.

Now when I encounter large groups of enemies I do have to be strategic, and then the game becomes much more fun, but overall the amount of time I spend being strategic in a combat mission was small enough that I got bored and stopped playing. This is not the case in Great Little War Game, where I have to be strategic even when wiping out a small group when I have superior firepower, so I feel like the game would have been far more enjoyable if they had added something like this.

Other than field operations being somewhat boring due to how little time I spend on strategic thinking compared to just moving units around and autopilot combat, the rest of the game is great. Building a base, maintaining finances, strategically equipping gadgets and weapons, choosing research priorities, I did find these very fun. But at the end of the day all these activities are meant to enhance your ability to fight aliens, and for most part I don't find alien fighting fun.

Now perhaps you might enjoy the combat in spite of what I wrote, and also enjoy the rest of the gameplay, then you'll probably enjoy this. Given how acclaimed this game is it probably isn't a bad game, but it's not something I'm enjoying much sadly. And I went in really hoping and expecting I would enjoy this, since I loved Great Little War Game, another turn based strategy shooter. Truth be told if not for all the great praise this game had received I would have quit far sooner. That I got bored of it is a real shame. When it's fun it's fun, but it just isn't fun for me often enough.

FINAL UPDATE:
I finally completed the game after 170+ hours.  This was on normal difficulty.  The game's difficulty curve is quite erratic, and sometimes unfair things happen just randomly.  But the rule seems to be, in almost every area that is not time constrained (95% of the time this is the case), then the slower you go the better.  Make sure there is cover and use overwatch mode frequently.  I finally didn't mind zombies so much - but the first time I saw them they were a bit too cliché.  Not everything in the technology tree is important, and some items are must-have, and once this all makes sense, the game goes fairly smoothly.  The first hour or so of a game seems to be the hardest part, and it seems worth letting countries leave to avoid losing troops early on.


UPDATE:
I forgot all about the zombies.  There's something about zombies in a science fiction game that just breaks my immersion.  It's like the game stops taking itself seriously at that point.


ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I played this heavily when I first got it.  It does get a little repetitive even though it unfolds new content excellently.

The learning curve can take a long time, which was why I put the game down after hitting yet another level that felt like a wall.  [That's just my personality - if I notice I'm going to lose a bunch of units in a hopeless battle, I don't want to play much more.]  But the fault was that I hadn't understood what research needed to be done early and how to balance the economy - learning how to do this can take some time and it's less intuitive than many other games, because income doesn't flow in as much as every month there is a larger payoff.

Tactics is excellent in this game - well just watch some youtube videos and you'll have an idea if that is your cup of tea.

There is a linearity to the game in contrast other Sid Meier's titles - a story is unfolding as you play, and there's not very much parallelism other than unit levelling.

All the tactical maps are pre-written, so once you understand the layout, it gets just slightly redundant - but it's not bad.

The technology tree is quite blind - all you know is the duration of what you're about to research, but no details about how that new thing will compare to what you're currently using.

As a personal preference this game is not my favorite, but it's good enough to come back to and get right back in and try out some new ideas.

Will I buy XCOM2?  Almost certainly.  I might wait for a sale price, but XCOM: Enemy Unknown has sold me on the franchise.

I want to love XCOM.

But its got some SERIOUS flaws that keep me from giving it a perfect score.

Overall, its a solid game. A simple turn based squad tactics game.
Most of its flaws seem to originate from the utterly stupid idea that console players would be interested in a hardcore tactical strategy game. And the even stupider notion, that the game's controls and design need to be crippled to support playing with a gamepad over KBM.

Lets get the nice out of the way, the tactics are good. Balance is nice. Being able to design my own troops and customising their load outs with bad ass alien kit is just awesome. I really can't stress just how well this game nails combat, its fun and balanced such that if you actually have a brain pulling off flawless missions is entirely a test of your abilities. 
Yes RNG is a component, but unlike other games I could *Mordheim* I mean mention. The deck never feels stacked against you. Yes their are objective missions, but they don't just throw infinite hordes at you. And never once in all my hours of XCOM did I get hit with a -200% hit chance debuff. 

You also have to build and design the XCOM HQ. Which honestly, feels a bit Fallout Shelter. Not just in appearance but also design. Almost nothing is done instantly, its all done on an in-game timer. Which feels VERY Fallout Shelter. 
The difference is Fallout Shelter makes you wait just to torture you. At least here in XCOM the waiting is balanced such to make you think through all your building decisions and try to lay things out nice and neatly. Sadly since optimisation is key you can't really build your base however you want. Eventually you're going to gravitate towards efficiency and since the only way to pass time is to stare at a big hologram of Earth you can't even enjoy it like an ant-farm, watching your little minions run around your base. Doing tasks here and there. Not that I think they even animated much to look at anyway.

The music is also solid, it really puts me in the right mindset of being stressed but not overwhelmed, it's not something I can listen to outside the game. But it does a good job getting and keeping the player engaged.

Visually the game is a mixed bag. The enemy aliens are very distinct and each design carries a great a mount of visual information. You look at a Muton and you know it's going to wreck havock. Then the support characters chime in and give you the inevitable baby's first explanation of what a big scary monster is and does. While the armour and vehicle designs look cool, the guns look like something out of a bad anime. I swear the starting rifle is 4 feet long but the average weapon is bigger than the torso of the guy/girl using it.

So the bad?

Well, I have a lot of nit picks that don't mean much. 
But where else can I talk about them? 
I wish Central would stop babying me with tutorials. 
I wish Raymond and Valhen would shut up and stop telling me how to think and feel about things. 
The graphics aren't ugly, but the weapon designs are straight from a cartoon world. (seriously, every gun must be 5-6 feet long.) 
Being able to customise your soldiers is nice but whats the point of having them be from different countries if they all speak perfect English with heavy American accents? (Unless you buy the Enemy Within expansion)

But then there is the real issues.
The game is still incredibly buggy. 
On most missions the camera is a bigger threat than the enemy. Its in this weird-semi fixed state that was clearly designed around a controller. So you can't freely rotate it. Only move by quarters and pan across the map. Your zoom is also fixed by only letting you control what floor/layer of the map your looking at. Being fixed like that makes it very hard to get an idea of the battle field at any kind of speed. And often leads to having to click at odd angles that make it very difficult to tell exactly what a new position for your units will entail. 

Since the camera is always shifting around to show case animations, the game never knows where to render icons like status effects or damage numbers. So often those things get layered on top of each other and then you can't read them.
Both player units and enemy animations will often just fail completely, causing them to fire bullets in every direction. Side ways, angular, even completely backwards. 
Hits often don't render properly and bullets will take bazzar paths vaguely in the direction of the target but get stopped by a wall or something. 

Also nothing is displayed by numbers, units don't have an HP number. They have a little pile of blocks which are very tiny and hard to count in the heat of things. I don't want to have to count how many blocks my guy has and figure out if a grenade will kill him or not. Just tell me a number and I can compare that in my head much faster.



I admit these sound like minor faults but they all add up to make the game very unreadable at times. 
When one of my units dies, I prefer it to be because I made a bad move. Not cause the camera snapped in some unpredictable way that caused me to miss-input and move my unit out onto uncovered ground.

The game also completely lacks any sort of comprehensive inventory. 
Sure you can go to the foundry and look at how many you have built/purchased over your campaign. But it doesn't tell you if those items are in use or who by or anything like that. 

Lastly abilities and upgrading your soldiers.
Every time a soldier gains a rank, you can choose between two abilities.
These are in my opinion, utterly false choices, as often its a choice between either a highly situational ability that might maybe benefit you on a percent chance. Or a guaranteed upgrade that confers increased stats or a massive boost to damage.
(Seriously, combine Rapid Fire and Close Combat Specialist on an Assault and they can fire 3 15 damage shots in one turn. Or put heat rounds on your Heavy Weapons Guys and watch them one shot almost every mechanical enemy in the game.)

Honestly, in the end.
I'm really not sure how I feel about XCOM.

I enjoy the combat, and the base building. 
But I hate the waiting for new missions to appear.

I love customising my units.
But I hate that a Irish alien hunter will speak like a Californian and yell "OORAH" like a cliche US Marine.

Getting a soldier to max rank feels rewarding as hell.
But the perks are so poorly balanced that every single one plays exactly the same.

I think your millage with XCOM is entirely dependant on how hardcore of a strategy gamer you are. Its probably best for people who enjoy Starcraft, or like me just suck at anything more complex.
Buy it on sale, don't bother playing Enemy Unknown. Stick to the much better Enemy Within expansion since that's where the REAL customisation and unit verity lies.

Oh, such a guilty, guilty pleasure. There are a number of features about the original XCOM: Enemy Unknown (and the expansion, Enemy Within) that I consider unfair and even broken. Sometimes my troops miss shots with 90%-chances, or activate two alien nests in one move, or one bad enemy round costs the life of my only leveled medic on the team. There's an odd duality to XCOM where it is the title I'm both most likely to rage quit after a run of bad luck and also the title that I'll rebound back to afterwards - it is both enthralling and infuriating at once.

The plot is described in many places, but I'll cover it briefly by describing your character as the Commander of an elite force that protects the Earth from an ongoing alien invasion. If that sounds to you like a trope that's been done before in movies and games that's because it has, and the game itself is not shy about offering even more B-movie cliches to this already familiar premise. The alien physical forms resemble the typical "grey" aliens from abductee descriptions, they pilot actual UFO saucers, and they abduct persons to experiment upon. The XCOM project is also led by a council of World Nations represented by a certain Illusive Man (?) who has humanity's best interests at heart (Mass Effect 2, anyone?)

To be clear, I am not making any complaint about the title lacking originality and, even if I were, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a remake of the original Microprose title so the design team can only exercise so much creative flexibility compared to the original material. XCOM is an interpretation of a modern-day UFO invasion with the alien models, objectives and ethos taken right out of 1950's cinema (or even H.G. Wells literature from the 19th-century.) The player should not expect the soaring philosophical inquiry and introspection that usually comes from contemporary titles where 'Man's Place In The Universe' is an open question - your job is to go kill aliens, Commander. The objective is survival and peace was never an option.

In addition to the several deployable soldiers supporting you in this task, the XCOM project also includes a German scientist and Japanese engineer (?) who provide the upgraded equipment and facilities that will be needed as the game difficulty inevitably ramps up over time. The raw material required for this is taken from both successful missions and currency paid by protecting countries from rising panic levels, both of which you can only indirectly control. For nearly all decisions that occur during the base-building half of the game, the Commander will need to economize decisions to get the most value out of finite money and inventory.

This is an important point about the intersection of the 'Gameplay' vs. the 'Plot'. Given a choice between the two, XCOM chooses 'Gameplay' absolutely every single time. That's the right choice I think but it leads to peculiar outcomes if you are playing for immersion. My logical brain tells me that if the combined forces of the World were truly invested in their own survival, they would fund XCOM with infinite support and an army of Heavy Infantry. Instead, the XCOM project is operated on a shoestring budget that is 'earned' by protecting wealthier countries (sorry, Egypt) and selling looted alien tech onto a Grey Market of interested buyers. While creating a great sense of strategic depth, it's hard to explain how you failed to save the planet because XCOM couldn't afford to build a sub-basement and went over it's budget buying soldiers (and who is profiting from XCOM 'buying' soldiers?)

But the turn-based battlefield is XCOM's bread-and-butter. This is where the men are separated from boys and heroes are molded. The strategy and complexity are the single best feature of the whole game and both the level design and tactics required to win are Dead Solid Perfect. As Commander, you can perfectly feel both the benefits of upgrading soldiers and the threat of new and dangerous alien forces. Sometimes there will be only open ground between Point A and Point B and only a swift dash will protect your character. Other times, the cover is only partial or at odd angles that hardly protect the soldiers at all (especially on alien ships) and soldiers will need to advance forward heedless of their own safety. It's all very stimulating and both a game of strategy and chance.

While I approve of most the battlefield mechanics, it also drives me absolutely nuts sometimes how desperate things can sometimes feel even with good strategy, and how far you can fall when you hit a run of bad luck. There is a strict cap of 6 soldiers (after Officer upgrades) in any engagement no matter how difficult or how many enemies (sometimes 20 or more) can be deployed. Every (presumably Elite) soldier to join XCOM starts as a Rookie with no abilities and no specialty - these are earned only through combat and specialties are assigned randomly so your team (like mine) could have up to 1/3 Snipers and only 1 or 2 Supports. The experience costs to obtain good soldiers are obtained over many missions but it takes only a single mission for an irreplaceable soldier to be lost from enemy fire. A single moment like this could cost a multi-hour playthrough as it becomes harder to persevere without specialist troops against alien elites.

Other complaints include soldiers who jeopardize a mission by missing near-perfect shots, characters who can shoot through walls with relatively high accuracy, and closely placed alien nests that can activate high numbers of nearby enemies. For an example of the last, Mutons and Chrysalids in later levels can be activated by moving into their observation zone, but they immediately approach the player and can even surround an XCOM soldier immediately after being visible. This is when you know that you are going to lose your scout today. Sometimes the game seems badly balanced and, if you are playing on Ironman mode, there is no going back to an earlier save - you own every bad decision even if they happened by chance.

When XCOM works, it is a beautiful work of art and absolutely perfect in it's design and execution. I've spent hours and will probably spend more (then quit in frustration and start over) defending against the growing threat of the aliens. I wish there wasn't such awful finality when a misplaced step can fail a mission, cost lives and imperil the whole campaign. But the game is worth the investment of time for those moments when you are successfully pushing back the alien threat, feeling like the Avatar of Humanity defending the human race against the approaching apocalypse.

This is a nice game. Nevertheless it has many annoying things:
1- You will spend less time playing than watching slow animations over which you have no control in the settings nor can you stop/skip them.

3- The probabilities of hitting/missing are totally randomized. I am not sure how they coded and how they seed but it feels stupid and gives you a bad experience at times. In any case I don't like the idea of having random stuff all over the place, better give damage adjustments based on offense/defense/cover...

4- When there is an enemy next to a wall, but you and the enemy are on the same side, basically the wall is not covering him from you, don't celebrate that you flanked him. The game tells you he is in High Cover because reasons. In contrast, I never felt it worked the same way for my troops.

5- If you get spot by the enemy (or you step on some trigger) they get to play twice once during your turn and another during their turn, which is stupid. This gives you incentives to reload and move less (even if one square less) just for the sake of playing around that dumb design. In contrast the game becomes stupidly easy when you realize that enemies don't really push toward you if you don't rush them, allowing you to exploit the design (groups of enemies have separate triggers of when it is time to attack)

6- Very early into the game you will realize the best thing is to rush getting more satellites (and normally you will screw up because you don't in advance that it takes forever to build them and that you won't be able to enjoy early research while still keeping all countries financing you). For example you see a country say UK at a panic level 3 ( a fresh 3) and Russia at 4 and has been at 4 for long, you might think Russia is more urgent, you play a mission that affects neither but guess what after you finish all of the sudden the 3 becomes 5 then they stop giving  you any mission that could help reduce it and you will probably not be able to send a satellite in time. So you better delay research and rush engineers and satellites for the sake of saving countries meaning making yourself play with weaker weapons and have less fun.

7- Lack of an important Quality of life Feature such as showing line of sight in a clear way.

8- For no reason, you may not pick all 5 continents then you google to find out that you are supposed to start a new game and that you have to disable the tutorial otherwise you will get screwed again and won't be able to pick (really? why can't choose any continent in the first playthrough?)

I would not recommend this game to players looking for a turn based strategy game for three reasons:
[olist]
[*]In the beginning there is only one strategy that works and it's painfully tedious. See [b][u]Details[/u][/b] below.
[*]By the mid game the challenge becomes a joke, on any difficulty and there is nothing left driving the game.
[*]The maps are way too small, which severely limits your tactical strategic options. See [b][u]Details[/u][/b] below.
[/olist]

[b][u]Details[/u][/b]
In the beginning game there is only one strategy that works because the way the game mechanics work and because the maps are way too small. When you start a new map you must move three soldiers to immediate cover and place them in overwatch. Then move your last soldier to cover which reveals a little of the map.

If you encounter any aliens they will react by moving to cover, which will trigger your first three soldiers in overwatch to take reaction shots. [u]This is the only time the aliens are vulnerable to your soldiers fire[/u]. Once they get to cover ([u]even half cover[/u]) your newbie soldiers will never hit them and the aliens will tear your squad apart [b]([u]even if your squad is in full cover[/u])[/b].

If you don't encounter any aliens then you repeat the process (move 3 to cover and overwatch then move the last to cover that reveals a bit more of the map). 

If this sounds painfully tedious, YOU ARE RIGHT, IT IS... But that is the only strategy that works. I have tried everything and nothing works.

Once your soldiers find the first aliens:
[list]
[*]If you try to rush the aliens you run into 1 to 3 more groups immediately behind them, because the maps are way too small. The battle just went from [u]4 vs 3[/u] to [u]4 vs 6[/u], [u]4 vs 9[/u] or [u]4 vs 12[/u]. All your soldiers die.
[*]If you try to flank the aliens the same thing happens. Your soldiers run into 1 to 3 more groups, it's now 4 vs 12 and your soldiers all die.
[*]If you retreat to full cover and put your soldiers in overwatch to shoot when the aliens advance, the aliens will just pick your squad off from long range [b][u]EVEN IN FULL COVER[/u][/b]. All your soldiers die.
[/list]

Once you get to the mid game you have a couple more options tactically. Some of your soldiers can choose abilities to destroy cover to expose aliens. Some of your soldiers can choose the suppression ability to pin down (neutralize) the most dangerous aliens giving you trouble.

However all tactics become moot mid game once you unlock psychic powers and the difficulty becomes a joke. Just mind control the strongest alien and use it to decimate the rest. Then the challenge becomes a joke and there is nothing left driving the game. Just keep doing the same missions, grooming your stable of soldiers until you decide to take the final mission. The final mission was a huge let down BTW. It's just a long hallway of chambers and each chamber has a progressively "challenging" group of aliens.

The game is not terrible, it's moderately enjoyable on normal difficulty, but normal difficulty should actually say VERY EASY. And Hard difficulty should actually say UN-ENJOYABLE PAIN IN THE ASS.

The only original aspect to the game is freaking your soldiers by splicing them with alien genes or cyborg-ing them into robo abominations. But it doesn't make up for the fatal flaws, which again are severely limited tactical options and ridiculously tiny maps.

This is not a run-and-gun style game. Unlike some RTS games this one requires a lot of patience and some thought. If you rush into battle you will get one or more of your team killed. Save often because this game does not autosave. Keep your sniper alive no matter what.

Firaxis's reboot of turn-based tactical classic XCOM is a great example of how to successfully modernize an old property. While its mechanics are undeniably simplified in some areas and its battles are smaller in scale, Enemy Unknown uses that smaller scale to make every soldier and every decision count, demanding you think and plan before making a move. It keeps XCOM's spirit intact rather than the letter of its laws, even if it came at the expense of pleasing purists. While XCOM 2 offers more content and a modding community, I still consider Enemy Unknown's story more interesting and its gameplay more flexible.

Let me preface by saying that I do see the appeal of this game. I like the RTS elements, the turn-based gameplay, the managing of resources, and the art style. This game is also well optimized, which is always a great thing to see.

However, there are some elements you have no control over and I can't accept: 
1) You only get one squad of up to 6 soldiers at a time, which means you can't tend to multiple countries being abducted at once.
2) Skirmishes are VERY dependent on RNG. Percentages of hitting might as well be rolling D20s. I've had encounters where multiple 65%+ chances miss and one 25% chance passes on the same enemy.
3) When your squad lands in an area, you don't see where the enemies are. If you send one soldier ahead to scout the area and you happen to get surrounded by 6+ enemies, there is nothing you can do about it.

This game really is like fighting with one hand tied behind your back. You can certainly survive for a while, but not for very long unless Lady Luck lands in your lap.

Base game is a good, enjoyable turn-base tactical game. Even if it simplifies the original formula of X-Com (1995), it still catches an entertaining tactical combat with great atmospheres, a wonderful soundtrack and some degrees of customization of the squad. Unfortunately, the challenge becomes too much easier as new technologies and weapons are discovered. The worst thing compared to the original is that XCOM lacks strategical depth (the geoscape is almost non existant and base building is poor) and everything is too railroaded, the aliens don't have an agenda and simply periodically send cannon fodder. All while you for some reason can only have one Skyranger and one base, which I understand is a design choice to bring in a specific type of challenge, but I would have preferred something akin to the classic game (or to Xenonauts).
However, the acclaimed mod Long War gives XCOM new life making it a masterpiece for the ages.

Not being a console player, and not keeping up with the times. I had no knowledge of this game ever coming out in 2012 although Ive played the original game "XCOM UFO DEFENSE" on my old pentium 1 computer back in 96. 

So knowing that there were several titles that following the original game, I was surprised to find out that this was a reboot of the original. (I did not follow the entirety of the original)  I ended up liking it since it was updated and better graphics. But instantly I knew it was programed specifically more for consoles due to its style of playing. (but these days, the money makers are in console games not PC's)

The original was more PC based with many screens for management (I would say keyboard and mouse, but on my PC it was  MSDOS under Windows 95 and that was all keyboard only).  If I remember correctly, the original was much more harder to play. I remember many hours of play on the original and having to restart to relearn everything just to get to a certain point. Sometimes to the point of actually getting pissed and slamming the keyboard. 

After playing this version, I found it a little easier. Maybe cause Ive played the orignial and expected most of the circumstances OR, maybe the game was tailored to be a bit easier for console players. Im not sure, maybe Im getting too old and its just an old mans ranting of "Back in my day..."

Still though, I found it hard in the begining since alot of my troops kept dying, but later in the game after you research and build your troops get better tech and start dying less.

Beat the game in about 60 hours compared to the original game which took years of replaying to get somewhere.

All in all, a very good reboot of the original and worth playing.

This game is by far my favorite I've played on Steam, and for good reason.

After looking for some fun and cosmeticly appealing real-time management games, I happened to stumble across the XCOM series, and specifically: Enemy Unknown.

The game offers brilliant strategic gameplay, that emphasizes trial and error, and luck. Shots you take will be thrown into a probability calculator to determine how likely your shot will hit, and how much damage it will actually do. This mechanism is not only an incredibly fun way to play, but can as well become incredibly frustrating on some missions.

If you've played this game, you cannot tell me truthfully that you haven't reloaded a save file in the middle of a mission after 4 of your soldiers missed 90% shots and all ended up critically injured or dead.

The game has a fun gameplay system that mirrors a real life game of chess, which offers a fresh take on the strategy genre of games. Mixed with the very fun progression system of upgrading your soldiers armor, weapons, and abilities; Enemy Unknown will offer endless fun and frustration in every run!
