While for the longest time I was skeptical of the newer generation of XCOM I decided to give it a chance, and I was pleasantly surprised. It expands on the lore of the original. I do still recommend playing the original DOS XCOM and also this one - you'll see there is fun to be had in both and both are equally challenging in different ways. If you play close attention you'll notice the devs have probably read the notes of Bob Lazar about area 51 , and some of the Dulce alien base conspiracy theories. I didn't really like at first how the newer generation XCOM deviated so much from the original appearance of the "Sectoids," which originally are based off the "Zeta Reticulans" or "Greys" that so many people report in UFO sightings on MUFON and search but I'm able to forgive it, it's all artistic interpretation. I have the highest respect for the amount of effort that went into the design concepts and art, and I think it really gives a lot of insight to how humanity would actually respond to a hostile extraterrestrial invasion. The difficulty can be ramped up to make you pull your hair out or to be fair and comfortable - so it has something for everyone. I'll most definitely be buying XCOM 2 next.  I also highly recommend getting Enemy Within expansion DLC because it adds so many more maps and quality features to the experience.

turn based strategy rules

1. You will miss.
2. You will hit, sometimes.
3. You will get your soldiers killed. 
4. You will take your time for thinking the best possible name for your favourite soldier.
5. You will get your favourite soldier killed by being impatient.
6. You will lose your whole squad because you couldn't kept your impatience in check.
7. You will use Arc Thrower for free alien weaponry, mostly leading to the facts 1. and 3.
8. You will learn to hate Thin Men, respect Sectopods and fear Chryssalids to death.
9. You will forget to build satellites and uplinks on time.
10. You will fuck things up despite of careful planning.
11. You will lose your game and get frustrated.
12. You will try again and pay back in spades.

--- with XCOM: Enemy Within ---

13. You will play Newfoundland mission and be diagnosed with PTSD.
I remember playing this a while back, good times.

The game is interesting, but get ready for a buggy ride!

- doors that cannot be opened
- unselectable units
- random crashes
- units that stay wounded forever
- buggy menus that will force you to close the game

Otherwise the game is OK.

The tactical side is interesting, but the game doesn't explain well the cover system. Sometimes you'll move your unit thinking that they'll be able to fire, only to find out that you wasted an action for nothing.

Glancing at the units you cannot really know their current state (is that enemy on overwatch?).

You also need to manage your base, build facilities, launch surveillance satellites and intercept UFOs. It adds a bit of management tasks to the game but they're not very complex.

The first missions are really difficult but afterwards the game gets progressively easier.

The music is ok and fits the mood but gets a bit repetitive, there's not a lot of variety.

MY FINAL ADVICE: SAVE YOUR GAME BEFORE AND AFTER EACH MISSION.

It's almost entirely luck and random BS. I have more than enough time in this game to prove this ain't just raging cause I wiped in my first couple missions cause I suck. Here's the thing, even with all this time and beating the game 5+ times, I have never played a game above classic difficulty or on ironman mode. This is because the game at that point becomes entirely luck and doesn't work.So what you end up with is the game is either WAY to easy or you end up having an entire party wipe beacuse an enemy cyberdisk (high dps enemy) phases out of existance and can shoot at your people no matter where they are, but there is no unit there, but you can't end win because the game thinks there's an enemy left. I've seen 100% chance to hit miss, same with 100% crit. I've seen it where I clicked for a unit to go to one tile, then they went to some random ass one a mile away. I've seen overwatchs and CCS (triggers a reaction when an enemy moves within range) just not trigger so you end up getting destroyed by the person charging at you who your units just decided not to shoot even when they should. Not to mention, on top of all this the LOS system is complete shit, sometimes in your favor, sometimes not. So all I can say is expect to have no challenge because you have to play on an easier difficulty to make up for random BS getting you killed, or play the game on a higher difficulty where no amount of strategy can savev you from the some divine being deciding it doesn't like you and making you lose via a bug or a unit doing exactly the opposite of what you tell it.

I myself, a very small-brained individual who prefers FPS and action games, over something very methodical and small like this. But still, XCOM was an intriguing game for me, and even me with my stupidity really got into this game. Of course I never played the classics, and probably never will, since it's even more brutal than this one, but EU, and more specifically its expansion Enemy Within, is a very interesting and deep game, that can be entry for the genre that most people can enjoy.

The story is simple, aliens are real, but they are very evil and cruel. Their next step in the galactic conquest is Earth. To stop them, the collective government of the world launch the XCOM project, to combat alien threat. You are the Commander of the XCOm and you ahve full control of what is going on in this project. With the help of team of talented scientists and engieneers, and a batallion of soldiers, you will have to find a way to stop this menace once and for all, and save the Earth. 
The overall presentation of the story here most of the time tries to go for this action-horror vibe, your enemies are disgusting and vile in their nature, going as low as possible to achieve their goals, while your soldiers trying overcome their limits and fears for the greater good.
I feel like there was geniuine effort to make this game something more than "Alines bad, go kill them" with the deep lore and stuff, especially at the last mission, but everything leads to suvh an anti-climactic ending, that you don't even understand what's going on. Did we win? What happened to my squad on the ship? But overall the story is not the reason you are going to play this game.

The graphics of the game are solid for their time, but it shows its age. Everything looks simple and smooth, but lacks certain details. The fact that camera is so zoomed out from the action really helps to mask imperfections of the visuals, but try to zoom in and you will see some stuff must've been sacrificed for more stable performace. The soldier models look especially bad up-close. In some cutscenes, if your soldier is not a unique unit, saved on a special mission, will look like a total mess. The best part are the alien designs. they all unique and interesting, but some of the later stage aliens I'm not a fan of.
OST is actually pretty good, but lacks variety and hearing same songs over and over during the course of 20-60 hour campaign can get really tiring.
Also the game has some bugs. My saves got corrupted couple of times, and the would crash. Sometimes the game won't load certain textures, or sometimes units on the field. So probably use auto saves, and hope that your Ironman run won't be ruined by something like this.

The game is split into two parts, management of your XCOM base, and actual on the field missions controlling the squad of soldiers. And there is A LOT of mechanics with each of them. With the base you have to manage your resources, control panic levels of each country, assign research projects for the science team, build new rooms and facilities within the base, and there is so much of all of this that you will probably be overwhelmed at first and you very first run will definentely be a disaster. As someone who tried to play all this, my first 3 runs failed simply because I didn't understand the importance of satellites and your aircraft. A couple of guides an d abandoned attmpts later I got almost perfect game on Normal difficulty, which is perfect for a low IQ individual like me, don't judge.

On the ground you control the squad of 4-6 soldiers, each with their own unique abilities. At first the only diffrence are the classes but later, with the expansion, you can change them even more by introducing genetic modifications and mechanical augmentations into the equation. But still, your soldiers are just people, and they are prone to fail. Something that the game makes very clear at the start, and even in the tutorial, your soldiers will die here, you can't save everyone. You will lose people in fights and you have to come to terms with that. That being said, no one is indispensible. If you play right, you will have plenty of capable soldiers that can the place of the lost unit and help you win this war. Just try to have a rotation of soldiers that will attempt different missions and have them at hand in case you need to replace wounded/dead unit.
The game is really hard at first. You have awful weapons, aim of your people sucks, they panic at the sight of their own blood, you have limited funding with no resources, and you don't even know what enemies are capable of. Eventually, with a lot of careful planning and preparation, you will get stronger and start actually getting somewhere, and the endgame actually will be pretty easy despite enemies introducing more powerful units. Just be patient and smart, and everything will pay out at  the end, when all of your squad being outfitted in most powerful armor, armed with plasma weapons that will one-shot most enemies in the game.

So yeah, this game is hard as hell, but rewarding and satisfying. If you never played turn-based strategies and want to give genre a shot, this is a perfect start. 
Also veterans of the genre seem to like this game as well, so if some dumb idiot that struggled with this game on Normal is not a good enough recommendation, look at the loyal and vast community that this game garnered and incredible mod support it has.

I was hungry for more unfair turn-based combat after nearly 6 years of 3.5 D&D, and he recommended XCOM, with little knowledge of the deep dive I was about to take. Not to split hairs here, I ate this **** up. Funny enough I had played The Bureau 3 years before, and had known about the series through that lens. Disregarding my poor misconceptions, I gave this game a try. Thinking I was a real gamer, I ticked off ironman and impossible, and started my first game. If you have read the other reviews, you'd figure this ended very quickly. This is not the kind of game that many of us are used to. You don't need to play the hardest difficulty for a challenge, you need to play rookie so you can scrape by while a superior military tells you who is boss. In more ways than one, this is a challenge the likes of which you will not be prepared for, which is not unlike what the Earth might face against a legitimate alien threat. In fact, the next game assumes you lost this one, and is in many ways, harder than this one. But when you do win, you will feel an amount of pride and satisfaction that is hard to emulate or describe. There is a point where these games turn around, where you get the game, where your soldiers give the aliens a run for their money and you win, and win hard. 
If you're like me, have played a ton of grid-based D&D, and have a thirst for giving your character's more options for cleaning house, you'll like this one, I promise. 
Also, get Enemy Within, if only for the MEC soldiers.

This review is a truncated version based on the upper character limit for Steam reviews. For the full version, watch the video.

A few months ago, I played a game where I compared its turn-based tactical gameplay to XCOM’s. At the time, I didn’t think much about making this comparison, but it soon dawned on me that I only knew the gameplay of XCOM: Enemy Unknown through second hand experience and pop culture osmosis and that I’ve never actually experienced the game I was using as a point of comparison.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown puts the player in the role of the commander of the titular XCOM organization, a military and research outfit created by a global council tasked with defending earth from alien attacks. Since the title of the game is Enemy Unknown, this is exactly what the player is up against over the course of the campaign.

You have to figure out who the alien menace is, how they operate, what their goals are, research their physiology, biology and technology and most importantly to stop them from reaching said goal by involving them in the previously outlined tactical combat missions. During those missions, you control up to six units and are usually tasked with killing all the alien units on the map. There are a few other missions thrown in there where you have different objectives, such as rescuing civilians, escorting VIPs or capturing an alien specimen alive for further study, but mostly it’s about combat.

The gameplay of those missions is fairly simplistic, the actions you can take range from firing on enemies with in range to using items like explosive or smoke grenades or replenishing health with medkits and you can also just hunker down behind cover and put your units into a state called overwatch, where they basically wait and ambush any enemy unit that happens to cross their line of sight. The game rewards cautious play over recklessly charging in guns blazing. This is doubly true because of the fact that soldiers can get injured or killed during these missions. Injured soldiers will need to recuperate for a few in-game days. Soldiers killed in action will permanently stay dead, meaning you’ll lose all the abilities you’ve unlocked with them and you’ll have to train with a new rookie to get them levelled up again.

I think a missed opportunity here is the fact that losing soldiers is only seen as a downside regarding gameplay. Because even though every soldier gets a randomized name, face and country of origin and they can even be further customized by the player, they don’t actually feature into the narrative in the slightest, they’re little more than literal canon fodder.

The only characters in this narrative are the people at your XCOM HQ, who talk at you from time to time. But the thing is that all of these interactions are mostly expository in nature. Your character can’t talk, so these people either talk at you or amongst themselves, but there’s very little characterization given to them, beyond very basic archetypal traits. Every piece of dialogue is always about the current task at hand and nothing else and as such, the whole affair seems kind of lifeless. 

I mean, the basic gist of this game is that it’s supposed to put you into a desperate role where you have to fight for the survival of humanity against a technologically superior alien menace with very limited resources. And this is only compounded by the fact that many missions are structured in a way that have three missions happen around the world simultaneously and you can only choose to engage in one of them. The catch is that every country has a panic indicator that rises when something happens and you don’t address it. If the panic level rises too high, the country will pull support from the XCOM project entirely, therefore taking away all their funding from it. This retreat is treated entirely as a financial consequence for later operations, not in terms of how humanity actually reacts and deals with this on a civilian level. I mean, it’s not like the fact that aliens are invading is some kind of secret operation, this is clearly public knowledge. How does humanity adapt to this scenario? And why would it choose to only give limited funds to an organization tasked with protecting the planet against such a threat? This is never really addressed, the alien menace is treated purely as a generic foe for gameplay to happen, not to explore any themes, which I think is a bit of a missed opportunity.

Outside of missions, you can research and manufacture equipment at your HQ, customize soldiers and their loadouts and excavate and build additional facilities to generate enough energy for future installations needed to research and build stuff faster. There’s also a grey market where you can sell alien tech and corpses to generate additional revenue in order to pay for all those gadgets. 

This constant repetition with very little in the way of narrative flourishes means that the game largely looks and feels identical for vast stretches of playing and as such I eventually lost interest in continuing on after around 15 hours without completing the campaign. I mean, even though the game is called Enemy Unknown, there doesn’t seem to be a lot to learn about said enemy in the first place, and if there is, it takes way too long to actually get to those parts. At some point it just kind of ran out of steam for me, even though for a few hours it did have that addictive quality of doing just one more mission or just one more turn.

But eventually, this feeling faded away and it also gave way to a few annoyances that kept cropping up. I’m not really a fan of the fact that enemies seem to be able to do way more during their turn than you. You seem to be severely disadvantaged on pretty much every front, be it either by enemies having abilities that seem to hit 100% of the time or even just enemies having way more health than even your most advanced soldiers. And again, I get that the game intends to put you in a defensive role where you’re forced to react to an overly powerful enemy, but sometimes the playing field seems too much stacked in the enemy's favor.

It also doesn’t help that for some reason, unless you have a specific upgrade, firing your guns means ending your turn regardless of the fact that you still have unspent action points. I’m really not sure why this is, why can’t my soldier fire off a shotgun blast while they’re right next to an enemy that has walked up to them during their turn and then retreat behind some more distant cover, rather than first having to fall back and then attempt the shot with a now way lower chance of hitting the intended target?

Another constant annoyance was the rate of missing shots. I’m aware how percentages work and that a 90% chance of a hit still means that it can miss. And I also know that these percentages aren’t cumulative, so you can have a 90% hit chance and still miss 9 out of 10 shots, because that’s how statistics work. But regardless of how statistics work, it feels terrible as a player.

I’m not sure how to conclude this review. On the one hand, the core gameplay loop is fun, even when considering the frequent misses. It really does have an addictive quality to it. But the previously mentioned annoyances regarding frequent misses and the bewildering design decision of not allowing movement after weapon discharge, the lack of any strong narrative throughline, the random and very repetitive nature of the missions mean that I’m not sure if I can unequivocally recommend this game. Maybe it’s just me. Strategy and tactics games aren’t my preferred genres to begin with and it’s a miracle that XCOM: Enemy Unknown managed to draw me in with its core gameplay loop, so you might want to take my opinion with a massive mountain of salt. But unfortunately, after everything is said and done, I have to conclude that XCOM: Enemy Unknown is at best slightly above average.
For all turn-based strategy lovers this is a must and if you are a Xcom/UFO/Xenonauts fan, a double must.

Being a turn-based strategy game, I expected more from the gameplay strategy options. The combat is so simple that the only difficulty stems from acts of randomness (like aliens spawning randomly over the map, soldiers randomly missing or hitting) and one alien type being invisible. That results in a simple strategy to always win - keep your soldiers together, so they can protect each other, and hope that you hit. If a soldier tries to flank, they'll get punished or even die, so just don't do it. Also, equip each soldier with a leg transplant, which regenerates health every round, and you're soldiers will basically be invincible. I could be braindead and win with this strategy every single time...

Also, I find working with the base extremely silly, it's way more complicated than it really should be (from UI perspective), and it doesn't really add anything to the game (at least for me). Most of the time, I'm just waiting there and hoping to finally get some action.

I don't recommend this to anyone looking for a strategy game, which is not dumbed down.

Xcom Enemy Unkown/Enemy within may be the greatest game of all time. Now, to preface, I must say I absolutely loved the original X-com UFO defense, having a hundred hours on the steam version and probably a couple hundred in open X-com. The original X-com is an absolute masterpiece. It captures its intended vibe so effectively. With that said, this reboot is somehow even better. It streamlines things (in a good way) and adds a whole heaping dose of new content. Furthermore, the campaign actually has some semblance of a story. The original one kinda just had a loose amalgamation of objectives that would eventually result in the final assault on mars. This game, on the other hand, has a full-blown story with a good amount of cutscenes. From this point forward, there are some light spoilers ahead: The first time I saw the base defense cutscene, I was blown away. In the original UFO defense and terror from the deep, the assault just happens if you don’t shoot down lurking battleships. In this game, it’s a full-blown assault from the aliens rather than just a group of sectoids with rocket launchers. On top of that, your supervisor friend dude in the green fleece sweater provides ample entertainment throughout the entire game. He’s cheesy as hell, and I wouldn’t have it any other way. The rest of the cast isn’t as fun, but they’re still rounded out enough to get the job down. Gameplay-wise, the game is amazing. Long gone are the days of being physonicaly attacked from across the map or facing the line of site bug. Everything just makes sense. Just like its predecessor, the late game is pretty much just your squad absolutely destroying everything in their path, and its absolutely marvelous. Seeing a squad of decked-out cyborgs and op soldiers just melt the shit that had given you trouble at the early game is just so satisfying. Granted, it may get boring if you’ve done multiple runs, or you’re doing a playthrough where you purposely never finish the game, but damn is seeing a cyberdisc get one shot o-so satisfying. The only real complaint i have about this game is that some of the animations aren’t properly sinked, and the rigging on the particle cannon is wrong, so it does this weird movement thing after you fire. I played this game on release back in 2012 but wanted to revisit it before playing XCOM 2. I personally recommend this game with the caveat that you also purchase the complete pack containing all DLC, as I did this time around. More clarification on the DLC further in this review for now I’ll start with the pros/cons of this game:

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list][*]Easy to follow alien invasion plot containing familiar science fiction elements
[*]Substantial & compelling campaign enhanced by DLC missions
[*]Missions take place within a variety of detailed, visually appealing environments
[*]Incredible atmospheric soundtrack/SFX
[*]5 distinct soldier classes to choose from with unique abilities depending on their specialization
[*]Surprisingly robust character customization for soldiers (using presets)
[*]Diverse roster of enemies requires appropriate tactics & keeps the player carefully planning their next move
[*]4 difficulty levels allow for accessible or challenging gameplay & offers replayability when paired with ‘second wave options’ included in the DLC
[*]As the game progresses, the player is forced to make more difficult & impactful decisions in order to advance
[*]Strong sense of progression as you complete missions & steadily upgrade your soldiers[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list][*]Key objectives to story progression are not always clear
[*]Most maps lack complexity resulting in repetitious linear advancement towards the objective
[*]Reliance on fog of war where enemies typically remain in place instead of actively seeking out the player
[*]Unnecessary, awkward initial encounter animations (e.g. witnessing a sectoid doing the whole deer in headlights act for the umpteenth time)
[*]The fact that you will inexplicably get fu**** over at some point playing this game, like getting shot through solid cover or missing a shot at point-blank range (I’m definitely not salty I lost my ironman progress). To be clear this has nothing to do with the RNG elements of the game, I’m referring to instances where the actual mechanics were never explained or clear to begin with.[/list]

[b]Review:[/b]
8 years on and XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within is still able to deliver a fun and engaging turn-based strategy experience on par with the vast majority of alternatives out there. It’s a testament to developer Firaxis successfully rebooting and modernizing XCOM as a series. Pioneering isn’t the right term, but this game was definitely at the forefront of the genre on release and the gameplay still holds its weight to this day.

In terms of story the alien invasion trope has been handled well here, while playing through it struck me in terms of how likely this scenario is IRL. Just imagine aliens are invading and instead of humanity banding together to face this new unknown threat you have a single decentralized organization being funded by 16 individual nations. All of a sudden Argentina is butthurt (typical) wants to pull funding and drop out because they didn’t have their request for satellite coverage fulfilled. Jeez I’m sorry Argentina but what the actual f*** are you going to do after you drop out? FINE THEN LEAVE, I’M SURE THE ALIENS WILL HAPPILY USE TANGO TO REFER TO YOU AND NOT YOUR STUPID FU***** DANCE!

Politics aside though, as the game progresses you will feel a sense of urgency to fulfil council requests and maintain panic levels, keeping individual nations happy is important because it can lead to continent bonuses which are quite the incentive. Aside from that managing resources isn’t too much of a challenge if you’re sensible about things, just focus on how you play the missions and you’ll do fine.

In XCOM the real adversity you’ll need to overcome is the loss of a good soldier, not only does it tend to be a setback in terms of progression, you’ll also find yourself becoming attached to your battle-hardened veterans. Without telling you how to have fun, my suggestion would be not to save scum if you get the urge, at least not on your first playthrough. I feel like part of the intended experience is learning the hard way from your mistakes, evidenced by the presence of the memorial facility which commemorates fallen soldiers.

The final thing I need to mention is the DLC, let me break it down for you:
[list][*]Enemy Within: Must have expansion that adds so much content to the game
[*]Operation Slingshot: Bonus Missions
[*]Elite Solider Pack: Cosmetics[/list]
If you must choose between them then you should prioritize getting Enemy Within, however make sure you buy it on sale, full price is not worth it.

Overall I enjoyed every aspect of this game in some capacity and it served its purpose priming me for XCOM 2, which I’m looking forward to playing in the near future. Definitely glad I took the time to revisit it and if you haven’t played this game yet add it to your wishlist and buy it next time it goes on sale for a more reasonable price.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
An absolute classic that is a must play for turn-based strategy fans. XCOM is brilliant because it separates your victory conditions (kill aliens) from your defeat conditions (worldwide panic), making it possible to win the battle but lose the war. Combat is very challenging, but careful tactics will nearly always give you an edge. Replayability is high due to several different soldier builds, multiple victory strategies, well scaled difficulties, and expansions with more development paths. While XCOM is one of the best games I have played, it is not perfect. Satellites trump all other developments; labs are next to useless; soldier panic during combat is maddening; and pacing in the expansion is really off.
[hr][/hr]
XCOM is a true classic. Back in the Paleolithic era – when people were actually [b]good[/b] at giving directions and 64 MB of RAM was hot shit – turn-based strategy games were everywhere. Once FPS and RTS titles took over the market, turn-based strategy games (that were not also 4X) had a stigma of being too simple and boring. XCOM proved that turn-based strategy could be challenging and fun, and it literally rebooted the genre. Very few games have had as much impact on their genre as XCOM, and that is why it is a must play for turn-based fans.

XCOM is brilliant because they completely separated the victory conditions from the loss conditions. You win by building a team of soldiers to kick the aliens into next Tuesday, but you lose by not managing strategic assets that prevent the world from falling into panic. In all senses, you really can win the battle, but lose the war.

Deep management strategies are required, and you will be pushed to the limit. You have to balance base logistics with technology advancement/production with soldier support with soldier advancement with support personnel with worldwide panic. You can’t just pick the mission with the best reward; you might have to pick the mission to Brazil to prevent Argentina from falling into panic. You will run out of money; you will run out of alien alloys needed to build tech; you will have to pick which country goes into panic; you will not have enough power in your base; you will not have enough engineers to build the satellites that will keep Russia from falling to panic; and you will do all of this when you are doing it right. Then, with the spare change you got from sifting through the couch, you can pick a couple ways to make your team better. 

Eventually you do hit a turning point where the war of attrition is over and you can start taking the fight to the aliens. Making it that far is the challenge.

The tactical part of the game is also very challenging and well done. Aliens are better equipped and have better stats than you. They can rock your world until your first armor upgrade…and then you can [i]usually[/i] take [b]a[/b] hit. You will have casualties, make peace with that. 

The good news is that if you play the tactics carefully, you will always get 1 turn worth of actions before the aliens. From there, squad combat is all about making good use of basic tactics and your soldier’s abilities. Advance under cover and with fire support…but don’t open up fog of war where more aliens could be hiding. Grenades and other explosives are your friend. Smoke grenades and suppression are much more useful than a shot with a 40% to hit. Etc.

Most class abilities are balanced (except for you, Flush shot). Some abilities will be very easy to use effectively (Lightning Reflexes), while others are individually weak but strong when combined with related abilities (Suppression oriented abilities). This gives you a lot of choice to build a very diverse team that suits your playstyle.

Replayability is high because you can choose different builds and tech development for your soldiers, and higher difficulties kick up the challenge enough to make the game play differently. Normal is soft enough that you can afford to do several things inefficiently. On Classic you need to keep your eye on the ball…assuming you know what the ball looks like. And then there is Impossible…even if you do everything correctly, you will frequently loose early due to random chance. Ironman helps you to resist the temptation of loading after a really bad turn…well, ok, the temptation is still there, you just can’t do it.

Despite how much I love this game, it isn’t perfect. I hate the “panic” mechanic…especially when your team starts shooting at each other. It both breaks my immersion (how are these Earth’s “best”), and it creates a completely random way to screw you (which is counter to the entire concept of a great strategy game). Fortunately, someone on the dev team knew how stupid it was and made it virtually impossible to fail the check once your soldier hits level 3.

There are also a few strategies that are much more important and effective (satellites, satellites, satellites), and a few that are next to useless (laboratories). This makes your strategic options more limited on a replay. While you still get some choice on how to develop your team, you will probably feel like 90% of your grand strategy is the same.

Line of sight rules, weapon ranges, and explosive zones can also get squirrelly at times. At some point you will move a soldier up only to find you can no longer "see" your  intended target. Most people condone save scumming at times like these.

I enjoyed the pacing of the original game. The Enemy Within expansion adds two super cool soldier development options and new mission objectives. This adds a lot of fun for veterans, but it really screws up the game pacing. You get tougher aliens and missions much, much earlier. This creates a higher probability for a tough mission success (wounded soldiers) leading to a tough follow-up mission with nearly all Rookies (who are essentially dead without experienced soldiers supporting them). So, if you are actually new to XCOM, I highly recommend that you turn off both “Operations” in the options menu (if you have them) and not playing Enemy Within on your first playthrough.

What about XCOM2 you say? Yes, I think XCOM2 is better. It cleaned up a lot of the more subtle, clunky aspects of XCOM. But if you haven’t played either, my vote is for you to play the one that revived an entire genre first. Plus, the XCOM2 story is much more fun if you’ve experienced XCOM first.

XCOM is a dumbed down version of the original X-COM, the so called turn-based ground battle is just a tabletop game, where too frequently your best moves betrayed by the terrible random generator.

Most examples from the beginning of the game, later game features lessening most problems, but that just shows this problems are created, the game designed this way.

What is good:
- As a tabletop game, it is excellent. If you fine with it then forget my review, go and buy it.
- Soldier classes are fun. They are very different and soon you will love their abilities.
- Game is very narrative, in base management the team leaders has their own perceptions and opinions.

What is bad (because it is just a tabletop game):
- From the multiple alien attack sites you can send help only to one, angering everyone else. In X-COM you can send multiple squads all over the world.
- The "do what you want" Action Points system replaced with a "move and action" system. You move closer then shoot at the alien and now it their turn, bad luck if they survived your attack! In the old version you can shoot again or just retreat and hide behind a cover, before they can react. This deadly hide and seek was fun and the aliens use it as well!
- Only four soldiers in a squad (later six), that limits your tactics and losing one of them can be crippling. In the old version, you can have more than a dozen soldiers in a squad.
- Forced tactical rules, camping is punished by lower accuracy, flanking is rewarded by extra critical.
- Most of the time aliens do nothing until contact, but will spot you immediately and move behind cover in "your" turn. It is like placing figures on a tabletop, because your soldier figure stepped on an "encounter happens" tile. In X-COM aliens moving around, resulting unexpected contacts where the badly positioned side could die quickly.
- No inventory management, there are few equipment slots to place equipment into them. For example you could choose an extra armor, an aim system for your weapons, one grenade or one medikit. But you can choose one only of them, because they are all "item slot" types. In X-COM you can overload your soldiers with various equipment, if you see that fit. That gives a lot of possibilities, like frag buildings because that was less dangerous than walk in to fight the aliens room by room.
- You can't pick up items. The fallen Nurse Betty will die with a medkit on her belt, because others can't access it. Private Brave can't pick up the dead heavy soldier's rocket launcher to send that dangerous alien robot to hell. Meanwhile in X-COM several soldier was saved and battles was win, because soldiers can pick up items.
- You can't shoot objects on the map, in X-COM making entrances through walls was a valid strategy.
- While all of the above problems could be overlooked as a tabletop game rules, the worst one ruin it all. It seems - too frequently  - your soldiers miss the aliens while the aliens can kill your soldiers unexpectedly. You can't win a battle with your best moves when all of your soldiers miss their targets from few steps away and the aliens kills your fully covered soldiers from far away.

I know that this is an older game, but I just really want to talk about how awesome this game is. If you are a fan of strategy games like I am, I cannot recommend XCOM enough. Every combat encounter feels super intense, due to the music, and the fact that permadeath is a major feature of this game. After missions, your soldiers will often earn the opportunity to gain new abilities based on their class. Combine this with the fact that you can completely edit your soldiers' names and appearance, and you will be totally invested in their survival, making their deaths that much more tragic. Nothing is more painful than watching a soldier go from Rookie, all the way to Colonel, only to watch them get gunned down by a muton because you made the wrong move.

I will stress that this game can be very difficult and punishing at times. Every combat encounter involves a fog of war, limiting your view of the battlefield, obscuring the aliens from view, until one of your soldiers spots them. My advice is, do not rush into battles: be slow and methodical. Once the aliens are spotted, they essentially get a free turn to move, regardless of where you are in your turn. This might mean that sometimes you might find your soldier moving into good cover, only to discover that a couple of aliens you couldn't see a few seconds ago are now flanking that soldier, meaning that he/she will probably die.

While I really like this game, it is not perfect. The base building kind of slows the pacing a bit, since in order to advance the game, you need to build certain facilities, which means that you might have to wait a few in-game weeks in order to advance the story. All of your attacks are based on a percentage of hitting: for example, when you decide to attack an alien, the game will tell you that your shot has a "70%" chance of hitting. This percentage is decided by how good the enemy's cover is, as well as how close your soldier is to their target. In general, this works, but sometimes it feels like the game deliberately makes your soldiers miss when you need them to hit the most, causing you to lose a soldier. To be fair though, it sometimes works in reverse, where aliens will miss shots that they should have it.

In conclusion, I am a huge fan of XCOM, and I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of sci-fi or strategy games.

Sadly, I can't recommend this game based on it being sold as a modernised version of the outstanding original X-Com.

It's an OK game, but it seems after 20 years all that has been achieved is an incredibly dumbed down version,with a huge lack of playability... though the graphics are better.

For those that like reading, here is my list of issues with this poorly implemented game:
- Only a single base, meaning no base defence missions or task tailored bases.
- No way to sell old gear and equipment, even at a huge loss (picture tons of crap clogging inventory lists).
- Automatic troop class determination. What if I simply don't want five 'heavies'?
- Imposed restrictions on what troop classes can employ. Why can't a heavy use a standard pistol?
- Awful tactical engine. Where to start... this is so dumbed down that tactics don't really come into it. 
- Ridiculous inventory limitations. Seriously, a soldier can't wear/carry more than a single item along with his gun?
- No real "skill" progression. Skills basically just cover for lack of equipment variation (e.g. "heat ammo" skill), the limited inventory (e.g. "additional smoke grenade" skill) or unbelievably dumbed down tactical engine (e.g. "Bullet Swarm"... an entire skill just so you can shoot before you move)!?
- Expensive basic actions. Reload, turn over. Shoot once, turn over. Use medkit, turn over... and so on.
- Small squad size of only 4 (6 if you pay for it), with tiny gun clips and one item each (think of an alien base assault)!
- Bugs. Mostly minor irritants, but years after release the UI hit percentages still don't always display correctly.

I really wanted to play this and waited ages for the 16.7GB download to complete, only to be disappointed at how bad the developers, supposed "die-hard" X-com fans, had made it. They created a game that sounded great on paper, but is devoid of most choices, options and tactics present in the original all those years ago.

To me it seems like just another awesome PC game butchered to be a cash grab and appeal more to the console generation.

Now I see why almost every other turn-based game is compared to XCOM series. So I decided to start the XCOM series with XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It is my first XCOM experience so I played it on normal and the game was challenging enough for me. It has got a little bit of RPG elements thrown in. There is leveling system in terms of promotion. Whenever your team successfully returns from a mission, you can promote a soldier who's managed to score a kill. So level up is based on how many kills a certain soldier did. Oh and you can change his name, appearance, etc. The combat is classical turn-based and can be really fun. There are different classes available to hire, like assault, support, heavy and sniper. So each has it's own strengths and weaknesses, so there's a lot of variety.  If RNG doesn't spoil your gameplay experience this game can be tons of fun. And there's base building, which was fine I guess. Those who like to micro-manage stuff will like it. Well there's not much else to say, since most of the players here already know the series. If you like it, grab it while it's on sale, it's worth it.

Imagine that aliens are invading the Earth and you’ve been put in charge of the defense of the entire planet. 
That daunting proposition is at the heart of XCOM: Enemy Unknown

Strategy game from Firaxis and 2K. 
Players manage the paramilitary XCOM project, deciding what new projects to research and what new technology to produce so that the XCOM troopers go into battle with the best equipment possible.
Do well and the funding nations will pour even more money into the XCOM project.
 Do poorly and the nations will pull out, leaving the project with even fewer resources to fight back the alien invasion.

The absolute best aspect of XCOM is the sense that there’s never enough time or resources to do everything that needs to be done. 
Do you pull a trooper off of active duty to undergo psionic training or do you keep him out in the field where he can get better at his core skills? 
Do you spend your budget producing satellites to help locate UFOs or do you spend that same money producing interceptors to be sure you can shoot down the few UFOs you do locate?

Every moment of XCOM is defined by these either/or decisions where every move involves some sort of sacrifice or compromise. 
When you combine that with the overall tone of the game, which emphasizes a DEFCON style countdown to a complete alien takeover, the whole experience is fantastically tense and engaging.

Unfortunately, in order to create that tension XCOM ramps up the difficulty and leaves you in the dark about some pretty important goals. 
That doesn’t necessarily count that as a criticism, because the pressure of having to keep pace with the escalating threat and learning from your catastrophic mistakes is part of the game’s charm. Still, a few of the essential choices are presented in an either/or format and you may not realize the choice you ought to have made until it’s too late to do anything about it. 

Even your basic goals are largely open-ended at the beginning of the game, despite the presence of key research and infrastructure decisions that are vital to your early success. It’s best to think of your first game as a learning experience.
You want to make the right decisions because that’s what’s going to keep your soldiers alive. In between the strategic management phases, you’ll lead small squads of XCOM soldiers in turn-based tactical battles in a variety of locations – from cities to fields to highways to alien bases. 

As your soldiers gain experience, they also unlock valuable promotions that open up new abilities. 
It’s a great system, not only because it gives you a constant sense of progression as you open up new powers, but also because it allows you to tailor each soldier’s abilities to your own playstyle.
For the ultimate in personal attachment, you can even rename your soldiers and change their appearance to match your friends or co-workers. 
There’s nothing worse than seeing your best friend fall under a hail of plasma fire.

The missions are challenging, primarily because of the enemy AI and the way the individual enemies are designed. 
The thick-skinned Mutons, for instance, not only have thick armor, but can even become enraged and interrupt your turn with powerful cries that make your weaker-willed soldiers panic. 
The emaciated Ethereals can use psionic powers to shield themselves and even take control of your own units, forcing you into the terrible position of having to take down one of your own soldiers. 
Since each type of enemy has different abilities, you really have to adapt to each and every encounter, which is made even more challenging when more than one type of enemy gets involved in the battle. 
Choose poorly and you could be bringing home your soldiers in body bags.

Death is a big deal in XCOM and, by midway through the game, your Memorial to fallen soldiers, complete with bagpipe music, should have plenty of names on it. 
At harder difficulty levels, it can be tough to recover from the death of an experienced officer, but the tactical game virtually requires that death be a real and, more importantly, a recoverable error for you.
 It’s all part of that feeling of being two steps behind the aliens and frantically trying to catch up. 
Thankfully, later in the game, your new advancements and high-level recruiting options mean the project can still live on even if two of your best Majors suddenly die in the field.

Within the framework of what XCOM is trying to do, there are really only two serious missteps in the tactical game. 
The first is that the enemies don’t seem very mobile until they see or hear you, meaning they won’t ever really surprise you. They simply sit and wait for you to get into their line of sight before moving to attack. 
This makes most of the levels in the game feel a bit like haunted houses, where the scares just sit and wait for you to come by. 
You’re generally free to reload and heal up in between taking on these small groups, which lessens the mission’s tension. 
To cheat around the possible exploitation of the aliens’ immobility, XCOM actually gives them a free move phase the first time they’re discovered. I
t’s an inelegant solution to the problem of predictable enemy placement.

The lack of elbow room compounds that problem. 
Instead of letting players exercise their tactical muscle through maneuver and exploration, here the tactical decisions are heavily weighted towards just picking the right abilities and managing your cover. 
This tendency leaves you essentially playing an RPG that feels more like a cover-based shooter than a strategy game. 
To be fair, position matters and you can flank enemies and destroy their cover, but there’s never enough room to really get inventive with your tactical positioning.

That said, the sheer destructibility of those environments is phenomenal. 
By the time you and the aliens have finished shooting it out you’ll have set cars on fire with your laser fire, blown walls out of supermarkets with rockets, and exploded rows of gas pumps with an errant grenade. 
It really sells the power and intensity of the battle to see these buildings reduced to flaming rubble. 
Better still, the cover created or destroyed during the battle can quickly change the tactical situation, which adds a much needed unpredictability to the battlefield and slightly alleviates the predictability of the enemy placement and lack of maneuver space.

So far, this review has avoided direct comparisons between this game and the original 1994 Microprose classic, partly because the expectations of today’s gamers are slightly different, but mostly because this title deserves to be judged on its own merits. 
But for those of you who were fans of the original, you should know the remake shares many of the themes and mechanics of the original but it’s still not as deep, tactically speaking. 
The streamlining certainly makes for a more convenient overall experience, but some of the finer details and sense of control have been lost.

Recently Firaxis has been very willing to try new things with its franchises, and it’s great to see both the revival of the XCOM franchise and the extension of strategy games on the consoles. 
You’re still likely to want a bit more depth and surprise in the tactical game, but the campaign is full of tense moments that are sure to keep you coming back for more.

XCOM is a great addition to the strategy genre, complete with an engaging campaign full of tension and challenges. 
The characters grow in satisfying ways, but the tactical game doesn't ever quite give players enough room to make the most of their abilities.

The OG dev team is good enough to balance the game while modders, mostly, will only add distractions instead of making game funnier as they claimed. They make games ridiculously sophisticated and redundant. As an example, there are 3 RNG tests u need to pass for a normal shot: first is about if u can hit them, this is easy as it is always shown; second is about your weapon damage, which is likely to be very low if no critical hit is guaranteed, the last one is about the amour of alien. The amour ranges from 0-4 for a seeker, the second mechanical alien combatant you will meet. As a funny example, i have a squad(6 ppl), everyone with 60% hit or more, struggles to kill a 5 health seekers in a full turn. And also LW Xcom has their grenades and rocket launchers made in china, which will solidify your belief in RNG god. Vanilla game, on the contrary, made a good balance between RNG and tactics and enjoyable. I'd say the original game is not perfect, some classes are not balanced(support are not as strong) and some aspects are over simplified(psi ability for example). However, it is definitely better than falling into the hands of some sadistic modders and pretends to make fun unless you are a masochist for real.

[b]XCOM: Enemy Unknown[/b] is an example of a tactical turn based strategy game with a massive focus on Positioning, Resource management, and unfortunately, Random chance.

At its surface level, XCOM presents itself as a turn based strategy game where each one of your choices can make or break an entire game play segment. Good choices offer you satisfactory results, and poor choices will result in the death of one or more of your units quite quickly. During the normal difficulty of the game, this cycle allows for a great deal of creative thinking as you tackle the individual missions and progress through the campaign with your fully customised roster of soldiers.

With a vast array of research choices, unit abilities, and map sets, every encounter feels almost unique. The satisfaction of taking a mission on and seeing the fruits of your strategy come to fruition makes this a wonderful pick for any tactics lover, especially in the early stages of the game where you positioning is crucial to your success.

As you progress through the game, the different enemy types and grand level design in conjunction with your ever-evolving squad of alien hunters is enough to keep any strategy-lover entertained for hours on end. Once you hit the penultimate high point of the game however - a point less than 4 hours in - the difficulty drops severely, and with it, so to will your passionate urge to fashion strategies around a group of enemies with intellectual capabilities comparable to that of a grapefruit. Realistically, once you pass this breaking point, the game becomes a joke for any competent player.

To anyone who garners a great deal of entertainment from a challenge, Normal mode fails to deliver, and the higher difficulties simply lack anything of real substance. Rather than introducing unique improvemens to the A.I. that scale with your progress, or anything at all that would warrant praise, XCOM ramps up difficulty by cranking the influence of RNG to a ridiculous high, and effectively diminishing the player's options down to a very select series of viable strategies. 

All viable strategies for a successful Classic+ play through are quite straight-forward, mind-numbing, and make the game a sluggish mess. As with most games in this genre, once you determine the dominant strategy, the game becomes mundane and uninteresting. For those who fail to discover the viable strategies used to careen through the higher difficulties, all you're going to face is frustration, especially when the game encourages you to try out [b]useless[/b] tactics in its tutorial. Every single interesting mechanic in the game is undermined as the 'difficulty' continues to bloat.

Upon locking in 'classic' or 'impossible' difficulty, every single dice roll is over-zealously bloated to account for the pedestrian AI. If you find a great deal of enjoyment in unlocking a straightforward and mundane puzzle that forces you to play the game at a snail's pace, where your only viable options boil down to 'blitzkrieg' or 'retreat' in almost every situation, then you'll likely enjoy the chaotic, edge-of-seat dice rolls that these difficulties have to offer. Don't be too upset as all of your plans go to waste when a 3% chance at failure effectively destroys your chances of success in a matter of seconds, though.

Ultimately, [b]XCOM: Enemy Unknown[/b] is a fine strategy game that fails to achieve anything remarkable. The insane prominence of RNG takes something that could have been a masterpiece, and dumbs it down to a mind-numbing series of frustrating puzzles that all end up having the exact same solutions.

A game that is single-handedly responsible for bringing back the Tactics genre, it sets the bar in a way that most Firaxis games do. A sufficient story that neither gets in the way, nor annoys, gameplay that's intuitive and deep, and gut wrenchingly tense tactical moments create a one-of-a-kind game that all strategy fans must play. The difficulty levels offer different levels of intensity, depending on how you like to experience your games.

Admittedly, the game does have some problems. The fact that aliens always get a chance to move after you spot them makes ambushing difficult. The base management part of the game can come off as shallow if you're used to the old XCom: UFO Defense. 

Something to bear in mind is that the game is difficult to mod, but a dedicated community created Long War. This mod greatly extends the life of the game, but really should only be played after you experience XCom normally once. Also, the game is distinct from XCom 2 and plays totally differently. 

I would recommend this game for tactics fans who haven't experienced this amazing game, or for tactical FPS players who want to lean more heavily into squad management at the expense of the FPS aspect. Strategy game players might have a harder time with it, because the base management part of the game is a little on the shallow side. Additionally, there is not Real-Time function in the game, so players that chafe against turn based may have issues.

I don't recommend XCOM: Enemy Unkown.
The only thing this game does well is the fighting. Everything else is just underdeveloped. 
I truly do not understand how this game earns so much praise.

The story
In short, aliens attack earth and you are in command to defend. 
Hence, you shoot down your first UFO, catch your fist alien, understand it was the wrong alien, so next time you catch the right alien and after a while you've caught them all. Then you assault their base which in turn allows you to build a new facility to detect a very special alien craft that you shoot down at the next best occasion. You assault it and the loot allows you to build once again a new facility, which with all the psionic stuff that you have by now, is the key to the end game boss fight. 
The story line can't get more linear and more boring. There are no deviations, no side quests, no real story is told, actually, you don't even know to what end your doing the council missions like asset recovery or personnell protection. They could have at least spun a story around that, but nah, it'll be fine. 
Once you arrive at the last story line task, namely assaulting the temple ship, and you just don't do it then the game becomes really boring. The aliens never get pissed off and never put up a fight. You never ever have to defend neither your base nor your satellites. Except of winning the rare encounters you are not forced to do anything.

So, what is it that you do in this game?
You manage your single base by spending earned resources and you go out to fight aliens that obviously earns you the resources to spend. The base management comes down to building facilities, taking care of what some shady council wants, managing your soldiers, and managing science and engineering projects. Management takes about 1/5 of the play time and fighting about 4/5.

The fighting
The fighting and the AI are the single thing that do stand out. The AI does not really play stupid. Actually, it understands cover and it tries to play its troopers to their abilities. For instance, when the AI gets the chance it will frontally attack you with mutons, where 2 mutons search for cover and the berserker just rushes towards you to draw your fire. At the same time it tries to flank you with lighter units such as floaters. 
The AI realises when being outgunned and withdraws. 
It will try to kill your weakest trooper first when all of your troopers are spotted. 
To play without casualties you need to observe under what circumstances the AI will attack. It pays off to excessively use the overwatch mechanic and cover, or, ideally, to remain unspotted. It is wise to keep your troopers toghether and focus fire on selected enemies to reduce the number of enemy guns quickly.
While the AI plays well I do criticise other aspects of the fighting system: One, friendly fire only exists for explosive weapons such as rockets or grenades. This is bad if you must kill a mind controlled alien and you're out of explosives. You can't stun a mind controlled alien. The battle does not end if the last alien alive is mind controlled. Why not? Two, we cannot target specific body areas of an enemy and reduce mobility, aim, or anything such. Three, it is unclear what exactly critical hits do. Four, combining all of this it obviously became unnecessary the develop alien research more in-depth as it is not imporant to know where the alien's weaknesses are and yet the game's German scientist lady states at one point how urgent it is to understand the enemy. Without any doubt somebody at the dev studio thought about this, however, it seems the idea never made it further than to being outspoken. Earlier XCOM games did that. Certain aliens could be fought better with incendiary rounds, other better with explosives. There is no such distinction in this XCOM game. Five, when your own or enemy units are injured their fighting abilities remain normal. Why?
I don't know why the game lacks so many features in the fighting system. It is not fine like that! It is not fine because of how strong the imperative is set to fighting in this game!

The managing
I won't go too much into detail of the management of the base in terms of builing facilities or managing resources as this is underdevelopend and boring. Underdeveloped, as there is i.e. no storage required to store all the battlefield loot. 
The one management aspect that requires a bit more attention is the troopers. The trooper progession system consists of two distinct segments. One is health points, will and aim, the second are abilities. As you don't have much influence over the first segment, the second segment is better developed. Both are granted, or, unlocked, with battlefield promotions. Abilities split into aggressive or defensive skills, where always one of each can be unlocked per promotion. An aggressive skill would be 'run and gun' that you can use to finish off an enemy by rushing him, and a defensive would be  'tactical sense' that increases the trooper's defense for every enemy he can see. This is a very good idea that gives you more tactical options. 

Science and engineering
By building labs, a foundry and workshops you get more of the corresponding personnell. The number of employees also depends on how successful where in the world you do missions. The science texts are boring and meaningless. They would be meaningful if they gave a hint on the weaknesses of your enemy. Same goes with engineering. Worst of all, when developing and manufacturing better weapons you cannot look up how good they are until you build one. 
Summarized, the curcial information is missing while a lot of meaningless blah blah fills the text fields.

Conclusion
Although underdeveloped the fighting system nonetheless is good because of two elements. The AI and the aggressive/defensive abilities in the trooper progression system giving you more tactical choices. The rest of the game is heavily underdeveloped, be it the very poor story line, or the poor base management, or the poor science/engineering part. Why on earth did this game even hit the market?

XCOM 2012 was one of my first ventures into turn-based tactics games, and it's probably still my favorite. If you're reading this, you've likely already heard about the difficulty of the game, about the intense tactical experience, about the frustration of missed shots due to RNG, and about the general feeling of excitement that the game evokes. So I'll keep it simple: XCOM 2012, while not a flawless game, is still one of the most well-designed strategy games I've ever seen, because it sticks to its core design choices and executes them superbly. It's extremely easy to learn and understand, while inviting ample opportunity for growth through extended play. Even in the endgame, if you get there, with the increased resources that you probably have by then, it never loses its sense of smallness, of this being a small, elite team trying to hold on against a vast and terrifying enemy. From start to finish it allows the tension to ramp up with your own advancements and skills as the enemy is always throwing new things at you. And through aesthetics, bonuses, and story arcs, it always maintains its sense of internationalism, that this is truly a threat to humanity, and that humanity as a whole has to fight back together, or is at least try to [spoiler](indeed, Enemy Within's focus is on exploring what happens when this isn't the case, and how it has to be dealt with)[/spoiler]. The core principles, of being easy to learn while still having depth, of tactical intimacy and constant tension and fear, and of camaraderie, hold throughout and together deliver a fantastic game experience.

Enemy Unknown is still one of the best tactical experiences I've played, and I can't recommend it enough to anyone who likes the genre. You'll quickly find that it's worth your time.

Even today, the fact remains that XCOM: Enemy Unknown is an exemplary turn-based strategy game. The game's campaign begins as a global alien invasion begins. Prior to the start of the game, a group of countries called the Council of Nations has banded together to create XCOM (short for Extraterrestrial Combat Unit), the most elite military and scientific organization in human history, tasked with defending them from the alien attack. The player assumes the role of the commander of XCOM, and proceeds to engage in a war against an extraterrestrial enemy with overwhelming technological superiority. That's XCOM in nutshell.  Firaxis has deftly blended management, tactics and the sort of gut-level, throaty encounters usually reserved for fast-paced action games. The mixture is potent enough that you may occasionally forget that the most critical moments boil down to nothing more than a percentage and a choice. On any other day, betting on a 60 percent chance might seem like a no-brainer. When the fate of the world hangs in the balance, you'd better think twice. This game will test your mettle in a way that will make old fans tingle with a sense of unforgiving nostalgia, and will make clear to newcomers just exactly what XCOM is all about.

[h1]XCOM: Enemy Within[/h1]

XCOM: Enemy Within is literally an extension of the original and offers a lot of cool new content. These are not just superficial novelties, but new soldier types, upgrades and other possibilities that will make you ponder even more than the original already did. It's a reason for loyal fans to play their beloved game again, while offering newcomers the best version of the game. However, the latter group must be willing to master all the tactical details, as the deluge of possibilities can seem somewhat intimidating.

Considering that as of the time of this review, XCOM: Enemy Unknown is my third-most played title in my games library, I can safely say that this game is one of the best of all time. I will freely admit that I have little to no experience with classic X-COM, and so I cannot speak for the old-time fans of the property. However, the 2012 reboot is certainly a legendary game in its own right. 

As the commander of the eXtraterrastrial COMbat unit, or XCOM; you are tasked with defending the planet Earth against a full-on alien invasion. The game starts you off with a team of four rookies, clad in kevlar vests (which might as well be tissue paper as far as the aliens are concerned), and armed with puny assault rifles. Meanwhile, the aliens are packing plasma-pistol armed Sectoids, and will gradually deploy more deadly units as the game progresses. 

You won't be beaten back so easily, however, and as soon as you get the ball rolling; your troops will be equipped with increasingly more advanced weapons and technology. The game forces you into a desperate arms race, one which keeps you on the edge of your toes, and never hesitates to stomp on those toes if you get cocky. You will find yourself becoming attached to certain troops, and the joy of customising and personalising your squad is one of the best parts of the experience. 

As far as gameplay goes, XCOM: EU and the expansion Enemy Within feature some of the most streamlined and enjoyable gameplay of the strategy genre. Each troop has two action points that they can use to move, shoot, and perform certain actions. Your squad has infinite ammunition reserves, but will have to reload their weapons when they run dry. You and the alien AI take turns moving your troops, and the AI never felt stupid throughout my playthroughs. There were a few times that the melee AI for the Chryssalids and Muton Beserkers fucked up in certain situations, but I found those situations few and far between. 

Story is by far the weakest part of the game, although it's still carried by stellar voice acting, likeable characters, and is really only dolled out in snippets anyway; meaning that you're free to derive your own conclusions from certain events during the story. However, I do feel that certain bits and pieces (such as the motivation of the aliens) were rather weakly laid out and established, and were not adequately explained in both this game as well as the sequel, XCOM 2. 

In terms of more technical parts, the game runs decently on both Mac and PC; although it suffers performance issues and long wait times during some moments in the game. The score is amazing, although it is overshadowed by many other games. Graphics and textures are decent, but are dated by 2020 standards. Level design is nothing to write home about, but is at least navigable and looks good. There are a lot of bugs relating to clipping, a few issues with physics, and some occasional C2Ds after long periods of gameplay (at least on MacOS), but most of these won't disrupt the flow of your game. 

In any case, I wholeheartedly recommend XCOM: Enemy Unknown, as well as the expansion XCOM: Enemy Within. Taking the best lessons from the strategy genre, and adding in a healthy dose of challenging gameplay, high-tension combat, and streamlined mechanics; this game is certainly one you won't regret purchasing at full price.

Regarded as an important milestone in PC gaming and one of the most influential titles, the original X-COM mixed turned-based tactical strategy with resource management, to create a memorable experience that opened the gates for numerous spiritual succesors even to this day. I never had the chance to delve too deep into the original game so I cannot directly compare the two, but it seems Firaxis had huge shoes to fill and giant expectations to meet. Fortunately, I can say that they suceeded and XCOM is one of the best strategy/tactics game around.

Split into two main sections, the game pits you agains a global alien invasion. Taking the role of the military organizarion known as XCOM, you control a squad of soldiers with various roles and abilities, in classic turn based combat, traversing or taking cover in a variety of maps, investigating UFO crash landings, abducttion sites  or saving helpless citizens from the alien threat. 
Where things get really interesting is during the second portion of the game, where you have to  manage your base with actiuons such as: maintain world stability by launching satelites, researching new weapons, performing alien autopsies, expanding your defenses or the base itself with new research rooms etc. All while you struggle to maintain low costs, gain funding, use the available energy you have and all kinds of different management options that give an extra depth to your strategy more than having to simply rely on training your soldiers and fight random battles.

Graphics and sound serve the game well, while nothing mindblowing, the various cinematic camera angles during the battles give an additional layer of excitement to the already tough battles (the game can be pretty tough with some questionable accuracy issues! but there is plenty of difficulty options to choose from, from casual up to true hardcore stuff!) all while you hear some tense "Michael-Bay-ish" music whether you run through devris, or discussing your next step with your fellow scientists in the underground HQ as you look through the red zones on the world map.
The presentation is top notch.

If I have one and only one big gripe with  this game, that would be the actual story of it. It can get a bit repeptitive and is definitely as bland and generic as it can get, with the only characters having any sample of persoality are the three main colleagues you see on cutscenes (The base Commander, and the two main scientists). However i can understand that a deep story and characterization is not what this game aims for so I cannot fully blame it for my own personal preferences. With the way thegame works regarding your squad, obtaining nad training new solldiers, it was never the intention to add any depth on them, however sometimes I admit i wish they had soemthing to carry on the majority of the game, as the more I progressed I started getting the feeling that I was playing a collection of well designed but random tactical missions that a coherent central plot. 
That isn't to say there isn't one, and some pivotal plot points do happen throughout, but contrary to the deeper personal dramas and political machinations you see inother similar game sof the genre,  the main focus of the game is to deliver top notch strategy and resource management, and it passes with flying colors. 

I only encountered one bug throughout the game, that unfortunately it could lead to some major problems (one of my squad refused to move forward in the map and I could not get her moving) but apart from that mishap (that fortunately didn't stop me from finishing the stage!), the game had a stellar performance. Kudos for making it playable with both a traditional keyboard+mouse, and a gamepad (the game can be addictive, so being able to rest the wrist during long play hours did wonders!)

A DLC expansion called Enemy Within adds lots of extra fluff, like new missions and upgrades, and although from what I hear it' s not as different from the base game, extra additions are always welcome.

XCOM definitely succeeds in reviving and old classic and bringing it into the modern era, and I highly reccomend it for fans of the genre.

If you are the kind of person that thinks Civilization 5 is better than Civilization 4, or that Skyrim is better than Morrowwind or Daggerfall you will probably be fine with this game. 

If you are someone that was disappointed in Civ V and Skyrim for 'streamlining' the game, and enjoyed the original X-Com, you will be extremely disappointed in X-Com Enemy Unknown. You might even hate it, because it goes much much further than those two titles in 'streamlining' X-Com. 

It has a class system. Each class can't be chosen by you directly, though can be manipulated by what a 'rookie' soldier does in combat (IE running up to an enemy and shooting them point blank gets Assault, shooting them from far away gets Sniper, etc.)

Once your soldier has a class you can't reassign it and their weapon type is locked. What's that? You want them to start using an assault rifle again like they did when they were rookies? Sorry, Assault uses shotguns only now, Snipers can only use sniper rifles, Heavies can only use heavy machine guns and forget about giving them a pistol as a side arm it has to be a fucking bazooka now. You are too dumb, foolish player, to make that sort of call yourself. Your agency doesn't matter. 

Hey remember when you could put your base anywhere on the planet? No sorry that was too much choice, you can only put it in the middle of the United States, in western Brazil, in Eastern Europe, in the Congo, or in the middle of China now. Still too dumb, ignorant player. What difference does it make anyway, that is all the major continents right? Who cares if you are a weeb and want your base in Japan, or a proud Frenchman and want it in France. That is too much choice- and over such a silly thing. 

Hey, remember when you could build more bases in the original? You can't here, just assign satellites over more countries and interceptors to shoot down alien craft there. You don't get an additional transport and soldiers stationed elsewhere to react to problems closer to them. But hey, it isn't like the game makes you do something crazy like choose which country you are going to bail out where such a thing might be useful and logical. Except it does. Semi-frequently in fact. And the countries that you don't help get angry with you. 

There's more than this, more little annoying things that make this game feel like a step backwards in comparison to the original. No, Skyrim and Civ V felt like steps backwards. This one feels more like someone shoved you backwards down a flight of stairs. 

More things to slap you in the face and remind you as someone that likes doing things like that are no longer the norm and complexity is something your niche heart no longer requires because it might confuse someone. I won't lie, the original could have used a lot of streamlining- ACTUAL streamlining, a more intuitive UI and base operation for starters. 

Even there it kind of fails. Some of it is much cleaner, but actually trying to fire a rocket or throw a grenade sometimes has the mouse jumping all over the place and you have to try multiple times. If you lose your patience (I did two or three times) you might end up blowing up the wrong thing, wasting your turn, your ammo, and maybe killing someone you shouldn't have. Ironman mode is available but I would recommend against using it for this reason unless you are okay with 'freak accidents'. 

I do like myself some character customization and while you can't decide their class, stats, or weapon loadout you can pick their race, hair styles, a few faces, and armor colors. No swapping genders or heights or builds though, so it hardly goes far enough in that regard to make this at all that much of a positive. 

This isn't even getting into the story, with characters that will randomly start naval gazing over the most insipid and banal of subjects. "Y 4 aliens do this 2 us???" is something you are going to hear CONSTANTLY. So I dunno, maybe if you are one of those hipsters that die on the hill of gameplay being secondary to story because 'videogames are art! politics are inseparable from art!' you'll hate this one too.

A really fun and challenging turn based strategy. Easy to learn, incredibly hard to master. The story is moderately entertaining, but it's really the micromanagement that makes this game shine. You'll find yourself saving often, because small decisions can have big impacts. Outside of battle, should you have prioritized building the facility you did instead of the other one? Maybe you could have benefited more from researching a different technology, or selecting a different perk for one of your units. And in battle, a simple impatient move can result in casualties. Which unlike a lot of games, the little nicknames(which you can change if you don't like) and perks your units receive as they level up makes you grow attached to them, to where losing a single unit in a battle makes you want to reload your last save file and deny it ever happened. 
While the basics of the game are easy to learn, even on easier difficulties, this game with challenge and punish you without mercy for mistakes. All in all, a really fun addictive game, that can be hard to put down, and you can always come back to again and enjoy even after beating.
