Imagine that aliens are invading the Earth and you’ve been put in charge of the defense of the entire planet. That daunting proposition is at the heart of XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Players manage the paramilitary XCOM project, deciding what new projects to research and what new technology to produce so that the XCOM troopers go into battle with the best equipment possible. Do well and the funding nations will pour even more money into the XCOM project. Do poorly and the nations will pull out, leaving the project with even fewer resources to fight back the alien invasion.
The absolute best aspect of XCOM is the sense that there’s never enough time or resources to do everything that needs to be done. Do you pull a trooper off of active duty to undergo psionic training or do you keep him out in the field where he can get better at his core skills? Do you spend your budget producing satellites to help locate UFOs or do you spend that same money producing interceptors to be sure you can shoot down the few UFOs you do locate? Every moment of XCOM is defined by these either/or decisions where every move involves some sort of sacrifice or compromise. When you combine that with the overall tone of the game, which emphasizes a DEFCON style countdown to a complete alien takeover, the whole experience is fantastically tense and engaging.
XCOM is a great addition to the strategy genre, complete with an engaging campaign full of tension and challenges.

This review is primarily for the benefit of those who like me played XCom 2 first (and WOTC), then went back to play this in order to see the rest of the story, where Advent came from, characters mentioned in XCom 2 who don't appear in it...
To clarify I finished XCom 2 a few times and did so with some finesse in repeat playthroughs, so I knew the basic tactics at least going into playing XCom.
I'm liking the management side; planning, prioritising research and building facilities much like XCom 2.
Combat mechanics:
I knew from XCom 2 that the rookies and squaddies wouldn't be able to hit a barn door when stood inside a barn constructed from barn doors, but this is ridiculous.
I reached the stage where I was to assault the alien base but the hit chance of soldiers up to the rank of Captain was still really poor, as in 65% at best.
Unless the aliens run directly into their sights the snipers are nearly useless, their pistols when used once they've relocated to get a clear shot are pathetically weak, and that's if they hit their target at all.
The heavies have the same problem, they can't use their rocket launchers unless the aliens decide to cluster in front of them around a car, but at least if they have the holotargeting skill the aliens they likely miss with their LMG are a little easier for their squadmates to hit.
At the time where I had a squad of 5 and the opposition were exclusively mutons, 8 at once but I hadn't advanced far enough to trigger the arrival of so many, and Mutons with plasma grenades when your squad's cover is almost entirely cars has likely only one outcome...
At this stage it's not a game of skill and tactics, but of sheer dumb luck that the aliens miss and your soldiers don't especially when the hit chance is low even when flanking the enemy.
It means a lot of reloaded turns and going back to the last Geoscape save because a mission with absurd odds doesn't have an autosave to roll back to on mission commencement where all moves don't lead to the death of half the squad.
The combat system means I don't feel I can progress through skill as easily as with XCom 2.
However since I'm too stubborn to give in I pushed on and levelled up Colonels of various classes and in doing so improved their aim, but the key I found was being able to make it through a couple of months and use the reward funds to improve the armour so 1 or 2 shot deaths were less common.
Once PSI operatives were found amongst the squad the risk of being killed by an enemy at the point of death almost evaporated.

In summary, the combat mechanics are not as varied as XCom 2 (but how else would the sequel have been made as it was?) so that and the distinctly lower hit chance makes this very challenging, so I recommend this for those who are looking for a strategic challenge. 
Those who want to just bash buttons are in the wrong place.
There is nothing fun about having a soldier in full cover get hit by a unit halfway across the map and dying.
If you play this on Classic or Impossible difficulty and Ironman mode on, be prepared to wear out the Alt and F4 keys on your keyboard.

This is an excellent game and one of the best turn based tactical strategy games I've ever played. The game involves you leading an organization known as XCOM in defeating the alien invaders and defending humanity. A simple but engaging premise that is used to great effect in the gameplay, with different alien types having different abilities and strengths and your soldiers being able to capture and utilize the more advance alien technology to develop better weapons for your operatives. The game can be quite difficult at times and unforgiving as the aliens will often outnumber and outmaneuver your soldiers. One of the hardest parts of the game is seeing one of your soldiers go from a green recruit to a hardened badass only to die in a harsh battle, the death of your XCOM soldiers is permanent and helps give you a feeling of personal stakes in each engagement. If you love turn based strategy games, as well as hard and rewarding gameplay I highly recommend this game.

- It's not a fully polished game, or realistic.
- It's not a complex strategy game, either, but still somewhat difficult.
- Graphics sometimes make it difficult to move units.
- Trying to toss a grenade starts a see-saw of haphazard camera movement.
- Units sometimes miss near point-blank shots, or hit through obstacles, ie. the combat is unrealistic.
- Some of the cut scenes get repetitive and the combat needs a quick mode.

If you can live with this type of things, go for it.

I love this game. After playing it for hundreds of hours, I never get bored of it. My only complaint is how difficult it is, but even that is due to my own inability. 
XCOM is a great game of strategy with a lot of luck in it, but I love that about it. 
Sometimes you set everything up perfectly and things go wrong. 
Sometimes you make a horrible mistake and somehow things still work out. 
Why? Because luck is a factor in the game. 
But luck is not what defines the game. 
If you play the game right and persist in learning about tactics, and always ensure to have at least 6 backup plans in case that 90% chance shot misses for the 5th time in a row, then you should be fine. 
In the long run, you will lose soldiers. Sometimes, it will be due to things that are completely out of your control and not your fault. But at the same time, that is all part of the fun. After all, if you played perfectly and there was never any risk of losing, could you even really call that a game? The whole reason why there is a mental stress about which decision should be made is exactly because you don't know what the outcome will be. Should I take the risk? Should I play it safe? In XCOM, sometimes even playing it safe will lead to risks. If you don't kill the enemies and let hide under cover while they shoot at you over and over, you will eventually get hit and lose. You gotto put your men forward, sometimes putting them at risk, if you want to achieve any results. 

Anyways, I love the game. It's a whole lot of fun to build up a strong roster of people and defeat stronger and stronger aliens, even though it can be frustrating at times when you lose someone who you put so much effort into. 

But well, that's XCOM!

With a superb tonal presentation and ease of accessibility, the turn-based gameplay loop proves to be addictively entertaining. The modular nature of the game also allows for beginners to enjoy themselves, while strategy game veterans can enjoy the brutal, harder difficulties. While the game can go on for too long to some, it will keep players coming back for more throughout.

While story isn't of particular consequence in this title (aliens invade; you command a military squad to repel them and maintain order on Earth), tone is everything. The game functionally plays out like an arms race, demanding that your military team keep up with the ever-dominating, increasingly more dangerous alien menace. In this way, the game proves to have a flavor of horror to it, which creates an especially immersive experience.

Many gameplay ideas are derived from classic alien invasion tropes. Players may gun down aliens, capture and interrogate them, dissect their corpses, and shoot down their ships (some of which are designed with the classic flying saucer blueprint). The gameplay itself is divided into two formats; the first, and most prominent, is the turn-based combat, where players will command a squad of 4 to 6 soldiers with varying skills/abilities to eliminate small groups/regiments of hostile alien forces. The second is base management, where players will maintain the facility which houses the titular international military operation, repel alien spacecrafts, and respond to various events which occur around the world. This aspect of the game proves to be less immersive, but adds variety overall.

The only major issue of the game can be the lengthy playtime for a single playthrough, which can take anywhere from 15 to 30 hours, depending on player skill and priorities. This can prove to be a tad long due to the repetitive nature of the game after some time. This is especially felt by some enemies that appear in the latter half of the campaign who have inexplicably higher defense values. As such, many players may find themselves wanting to start a new playthrough more often than reaching their current playthrough's endgame.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown (And by extension Enemy Within) has proven to be hugely influential to turn-based video games, setting the standard for squad-based combat. Its rewarding and intuitive gameplay loop has caused players and critics alike to compare countless other titles with similar combat to be described as "Like XCOM, but..." It has its shortcomings, but its influence and quality can't be ignored.

[h1]Update (July 2020) - including all DLCs[/h1]

I have recently played [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/882100]XCOM: Chimera Squad[/url], that I was [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/jarcionek/recommended/882100]extremely disappointed[/url] with, so I decided to return to the first modern XCOM.

After putting another 60 hours into it and completing the campaign on impossible difficulty for the first time, I have to say that this game is great. And that's despite minor UI bugs and occasional corrupted saves. I have played this game in October 2012, July 2014, September 2015 and July 2020, each time completing the whole campaign. The number of choices is pretty large with all the expansion packs - 4 basic soldier classes, each of which can be PSI and augmented; you can convert your soldiers into powerful MECHs or build unmanned firing platforms to deploy instead of soldiers.

After completing the game you unlock Second Wave options, which allow to for example randomise the skills between classes - no two snipers will have the same skills available anymore. Or soldiers can have different mobility and be able to move between 7 and 9 tiles. All of this makes finding best soldiers very interesting.

[h1] Original review[/h1]

[list]
[*] low choice of weapons' types (conventional, laser, plasma)
[*] infinite ammo for primary weapon
[*] infinite mag in pistols
[*] no equipment management: armor does not define how much equipment soldier can take, every soldier has primary weapon (shotgun/assault rifle/machine gun/sniper rifle), secondary weapon (pistol/rocket launcher) and 1 utility slot for grenade or passive buff (2 slots after research)
[*] soldiers get extra equipment via skills, e.g. smoke grenades, extra rocket for the launcher or a utility slot holding 3 grenades instead of 1
[*] majority of story line missions are always the same every game
[*] small choice of maps
[*] panic management:
[list]
[*] if at the end of month panic in the country is at maximum, the country withdraws from the XCOM project
[*] deploying a satellite over the country reduces the panic so you have to wait until end of month to decide where to deploy satellites
[*] you have to calculate what and when to build to deploy satellites every month: excavate, build power plant, build satellite uplink, build workshop (building satellite requires certain amount of engineers that workshop provides), build a satellite, deploy it - each of the steps requires time and being late by one day can cause countries to withdraw from the project (loss of funding and continental bonus)
[*] one of the common events forces you to choose 1 out of 3 countries to help - in the 2 other countries (and whole continents) the panic will raise
[/list]
[*] no economy - you cannot build and sell equipment like in original [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/7760]X-COM: UFO Defense[/url] from 1994
[*] strategic map pretty much doesn't exist:
[list]
[*] a single base only
[*] intercepting UFOs is always 1v1 fight
[*] only two interceptor types available, both can equip a single weapon (of course infinite ammo)
[*] only one transport aircraft
[*] distance and travel time do not matter - your aircraft will always reach the object in time and no new event will occur when it's flying
[*] aircrafts don't have fuel
[*] the only way to detect UFOs is satellites, there is no such things like sending aircraft for patrol
[*] no enemy bases (except one unique story line mission)
[*] no base defense (except one unique story line mission where failure equals game over)
[/list]
[/list]

Despite all of these disadvantages, game is quite addicting. The story line is interesting. Building a base and promoting/equiping soldiers is somehow enjoyable. The missions are more dynamic than in original UFO due to 6 soldiers limit and 2 action points per soldier - there is no spending an hour on looking for a single alien that got stuck somewhere, enemies are rather easy to find on the map.

Very clear and responsive interface, you can issue the order and go to the next soldier while the previous one is still moving.

As a fan of the original XCOM game from the 90s, there are some small things I don't like about this game. Probably the most notable one is that I can't build two Skyrangers, and respond to two events at the same time -- I could accumulate enough people to crew them, so that always felt very arbitrary, designed to force you to lose some measure of support through an artificial mechanic. 

The shooting mechanics and combat in the original were more adaptive, too, where you could deliberately shoot away sections of terrain, or accidentally shoot your own team-mates if you picked a bad shot (or, if you were awful but lucky, miss one alien and hit another one). The pure strategy of the original game was probably its biggest strength.

However, one of the mistakes I first made with this XCOM was to *not* realise that it wasn't trying to emulate that original game's combat. Despite its similarities and obvious inspirations, this game is doing its own thing -- it's a cover-based squad strategy game, rather than a semi open map one, and that decision makes for some very interesting changes to combat, where you can position your whole squad to set up an ambush that will be triggered when the aliens try to run to cover after your opening attack, for example, which is something that works better here than it ever did in the original. Once you're used to it, you realise that this XCOM isn't better or worse than that 90s one, it's just something different.

The research process is fun, too, but it's the story of this XCOM that is the most notably superior to its ancestor. That's to be expected, of course -- games had less room to work with back then, and so story often took a back-seat to raw gameplay. But those story-driven elements also mean you also get some combat objectives that are more varied than those in the original, which can help to mix things up, and make this game, if not more engrossing, then perhaps more involving than the 90s version. 

It's easy to highly recommend this game -- I still prefer it to its sequel, and overall, despite my nostalgia, I may even like it a little better than that 90s classic. That being said, I'd definitely recommend that people should pick up both versions (and install the OpenXCom extension for the original, to let you add a few pleasant mods to make the old game a better modern experience) and give them a whirl.

I wonder how to describe my feelings well... I really want to like this game. In fact, I did like it for the majority of time I spent playing. I has some great, well--designed ideas, but...

Well, let's start from the beginning. XCOM is a game based on tactical, turn-based battles - we command a squad of soldiers to kill UFOs attacking our planet. Combat system is done well - each soldier, depending on class, has his individual set of skills which evolves when he gains new rank. There are heavy units specialized in brutal attacks, long-ranged snipers or helpful supports. Combat heavily depends on taking cover - without it, soldier will almost surely die or, at least, take heavy damage. Thus, we are forced to think before every step - even a simple mistake may mean death to our soldier, because the game heavily punished for these mistakes.

But XCOM is not only about tactical battles - in addition, we have to manage our base to make our squad more efficient in fight. We can research new technologies to upgrade weapons and armor, we can hire new soldiers, we manage aircrafts that interrupt UFOs attacks. Our moves are observe by the conucil - a set of countries that pay us for our work. Whenever country is not satisfied (e.g. we ignore alien abductions in this country), it leaves the council, and this may impact our resources. In addition, base management is definitely not trivial - it's extremly easy to screw something up, this part of the game is as important as raw combat.

Both combat and base management are kinda good, so... what's wrong? Well - problems are in the game flow. At some point, difficulty level rapidly increases - from kinda easy battles it suddenly goes to nearly impossible ones. This could be acceptable if difficulty was fair, but... well, it's not. By "unfair difficulty", I mean situation when map is nearly impossible to beat without knowledge of all enemy unit's positions. Aliens move in groups and if we do even one bad step, a whole group joins a battle. This is especially annoying when aliens group is found by soldier whose turn is the last one. Whenever it happeened, I was forced to load the last save and use newly gained knowledge to prepare another tactic.

From some point, this permanent and unavoidable save and load tactic just becomes frustrating. In addition, being forced to use an extremly defensive tactic makes battles too long. After more or less tries, I was capable of winning almost every combat - but after each one, I was rather exhausted than happy. In addition, at some point I had to win many hard fights one after another. That's why I had to take a long break and I have not finished the game yet.

I think I'll finish it earlier or later - XCOM is not that bad at all and I still want to know how the story will end. But the game flow is something that definitely needs polishing. And I played on normal difficulty - I tried on harder one first, but if it's your first time with this game, don't try it.

Xcom is a combination of turn-based-strategy and meta strategy wrapped into a single package. The base game takes about 20-30 hours for a single play-through with varying difficulties for replayability. The expansion adds another 5-10 hours along with various extra toys to play with. The icing on the cake is the Long War mod. The mod completely overhauls the game by adding more classes, more items, diverse enemy variety, etc for tons of replay-ability.

My only critique of the game is the chance to hit system making it RNG heavy. Long War addresses this to an extent by improving your options to disable aliens while you close in for better shots.

[u]TLDR: A good squad strategy game made better with the expansion and incredible with the mod.[/u]

I really like a lot of stuff about XCOM, but it did take a lot of effort to get in the right mindset. Right off the bat, you need to manage:

- Troop deployments
Finding the right balance between experienced troops and less experienced troops can be difficult. You don't want to just send out your rookies for each mission because they'll just get cut down, but you also can't rely on a single group of experienced troops to carry you throughout the game

- Research
Where will the tech tree lead you? Hell if I know!

- Facility Building
You need to decide how to allocate the limited space you have in your bunker. Do you use that free square for a new lab to speed up your research team? Or maybe you decide to build a psi lab to see if any of your troops have latent psychic ability? Or maybe you just need more cash and opt instead of a satellite array. Finding a winning combo of facilities can be difficult.

- Supply Lines
You get supplies from two primary sources - nations/regions donating to XCOM, and satellites. Satellites arrays are cash, but as I mentioned before, it can be daunting deciding if a sat array is really more important than any of the other facilities you can build.

- Panic Level
Each participating XCOM nation/region has it's own panic level, and if it gets too high, they're gone. You lose the valuable supplies they provided you, and there are occasions where you'll have to decide between damning one nation or another.

I'm sure there are a lot of players who didn't struggle with all of these points, and I'm stoked you were able to hop in so quickly. But for me at least, it took a fair amount of save scumming, campaign restarts, and reading guides before I felt like I was starting to understand how to manage all these mechanics.

I like this game, but God knows I had to take a few punches to the chin before I started to understand what I was meant to be doing.

I've heard a lot about this game over the years. I never gave it a shot, unfortunately, because I've always heard it is insanely hard. No, it's the right amount of challenge. The game has a story, but isn't setup like a typical story-based game -- it's setup a lot like the Civilization games where the end-of-the-game can be achieved depending on how quickly, slowly, poorly, or excellent your play may be.

The game's missions are the tactical part of the game, but the game has a much more macro scope when it comes to your base. You can customize individual soldiers, do research for better weapons, armor, and other fun things.

The game is challenging and you may lose -- meaning the aliens overrun the planet -- but that doesn't stop the game from being fun on the second or twenty-second play-through because each and every mission is fun, engaging, and tickles the brain in just the right way.

This is one of the greatest games I've ever played. The story is enjoyable, the sci-fi elements are interesting, the strategy is thoroughly satisfying, and the difficulty is unforgiving.

There are lots of comments surrounding X-COM's difficulty, so you should be aware of this before diving in. It's incredibly hard, and it's not in a Dark Souls kind of way, where you feel as though it was "fair", and that if you merely up your skill in the game, it won't happen again. That's not X-COM's difficulty. X-COM is hard in an unforgiving, the world is out to get you and you will suffer, kind of way. There are moments where it feels harsh, like you didn't "deserve" what you got. There's an expression in the community, "That's X-COM baby!" What it means is, you will experience the heartbreak of loss. All that said, I actually feel like it's done quite well in X-COM, and it made the experience more satisfying.

The reason the "unfair" difficulty is good, is that you don't just all of a sudden lose the whole game. You'll experience moments of deep loss, where a soldier you've become connected with gets into a tight spot, and ends up dying. You feel like there was nothing you could have done to save them. But you need to move on. The way the game works, you can lose soldiers, and even lose missions, and still be able to continue (albeit, it hurts your chances of survival overall). In fact, it's pretty much impossible to beat the game without ever having had some kind of loss. So it's not like games that create artificial difficulty by just one-shotting you. A unit might get one-shotted, but you still have a chance to pull yourself back together, and struggle forward.

This aspect of the game actually creates a new dimension in the gaming experience; mental fortitude. It's not purely just a "sit down and have a good time!" kind of game. You actually have to push forward, overcoming your grief, pick yourself up by your bootstraps, and continue fighting. That's the difficulty of the game. I had to put the game down, multiple times, as I tried to complete a Classic-Ironman game, but I finally did it, and it was one of the most satisfying gaming experiences I've ever had.

The game has a lot going for it, but sadly there are more annoying things than enjoyable things in total and most of my time with the game was very mediocre. I played without Enemy Within. 

TL; DR: 
XCOM: Enemy Unknown should rather be called "SAVE SCUM SIMULATOR WITH ALIENS: THE HIT PERCENTAGES ARE A LIE EDITION" 

First off, the good things:

- Different classes, even though you only get the absolute industry standard: Medic, Sniper, Explosives Guy and A CQB guy.
- Technology that you can research so you get stronger over time.
- You can capture enemies to question them 
- The alien-centered story is somewhat interesting, but don´t expect any Nebula awards
- Some feeling of urgency is generated through panic levels rising
- New enemy types are introduced frequently
- VIsuals and sounds are satisfying, especially the guns, violence or aircraft noises
- Basebuilding is fun
- SHIVs are a fun idea. 

Now let´s get to the awful stuff, and there is a lot in this game: 

- EXTREMELY repetitive missions, because there are like 4 mission types
- Rookie soldiers that are not snipers are complete shit at shooting anything that isn´t 3 metres away. How did they become soldiers in the first place? 
- Enemies are always great shooters and hit almost every time. 
- There should be a gym / sparring room / firing range / simulation chamber building to slowly level your soldiers up while they aren´t away on missions. 
- Ufo plane chases are very boring
- No auto unequip gear button
- Many problems with terrain visibility / seeing enemy line of sight because something is always not displayed properly or is blocking your view
- Why does questioning an enemy not also complete the autopsy since they are dead at the end of the questioning? 
- Money is always highly limited, why am I not drowning in cash as I am the only capable defender against an alien threat? 
- If countries drop out of XCOM, they are gone forever. Even if you maintain low panick for the rest of the game, they will never rejoin you. 
- Cutscenes can´t be skipped
- Enemy will randomly be dropped onto the map, basically falling from the sky. 
- Ethereal enemy type that can deflect all types of projectiles 
- Huge mechs that can shoot twice in a row
- You can only hire rookie soldiers. How about an option where I pay much more than 10 bucks, but get a higher level soldier? 
- Why are there no airstrike options in outdoor maps? That would be the obvious thing since you have fighter jets anyway. 
- Why does no one except the medic have more than one inventory slot? Backpacks are a thing, you know.
The last mission was also pretty bad, you only get to fight all enemy types again and get a totally obvious ending. 
- Why do I have to reload laser weapons and plasma weapons even if the research description states they do not require reloading? 
- Why do some missions not display difficulty?

--> Absolute gamebreakers:
- The game can not handle more than 100 saved games an will lag more and more the mor new save games you create. 
- Steam Cloud saving fucked up and overwrote three hours of progress once. 
- As soon as the turn is finished with 1 guy, the game will zoom away from that soldier even if I wanted to do something with his buddy who stood 3 metres away.
- No smart quick way to swap between soldiers.
- Hit percentages are complete BS. The game might as well not display them: I frequently had 75% shots miss against enemies about as tall as a van. WTF? If I repeatedly reload the game and still fail that 75% shot 6 times in a row, that means that it is predetermined that I will miss and the game doesn´t roll the dice every time, as 75% would indicate. So why bother with the percentages?  Also, how can you miss shots if you are literally poking your gun barrel in an enemies nostrils? (Yes, happened several times) 
- Enemy turns/ Own turns can´t be sped up / be completed instantly. I wasted so many hours of my life watching people shoot aliens in Slo-Mo or evade shots in Slo-Mo or run to cover in Slo-Mo or be struck with plasma in Slo-Mo, WTF? 
- There is no stealth option: As soon as you cross a trigger line / get into enemy FOV, the enemies will instantly activate and will get several move turns and will safely get to cover without you being able to interrupt them doing that unless you have someone in the back on overwatch AND within line of sight. 
- Enemies that you haven´t seen before because of some sort of fog of war will take potshots at your guys while they run for cover. 
- The difficulty is way too hard AND badly balanced most of the time. I am a sucker for hard, but fair games. I completed all Souls games and Bloodborne with relative ease and had a blast: These games are tough, but very rewarding. Sadly, this game is doing a horrible job at balancing the difficulty. The game simply isn´t rewarding enough to suffer through anything more than easy difficulty and not savescum like a MF. 
IF you don´t savescum the hell out of this game, your guys will die like flies, you will fail catastrophically and you will have a very, very frustating time with this game. I was glad when I finally finished it. 

I thought about playing the Long War mod, but the game simply isn´t interesting or enjoyable enough to spend more time on it as far as I am concerned. 
IF I should absolutely play Long War because it is more interesting than the base game or because it adresses some of the  flaws mentioned above, please leave a comment.

XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a game that will keep you awake at night. It's that good. I thought that I should give this a little update. I have played at least a dozen campaigns now. I think this title is better than XCOM 2. The alien interrogation, base construction, and story were all more compelling to me in this title. The combat feels similar, and I think it's well worth picking up this title for any turn based tactical combat fanatic. Because of it's age, there are great sales regularly.

I know some people hate the randomness of UFO encounters, the loss of support for XCOM because it's literally not possible to stop threat from increasing around the world, and the rapid scaling of enemies both from difficulty and their tech advances during a campaign, but really, you can manage it. I even enjoy the challenge.

Yes, there is a hero for XCOM that completes a noble sacrifice to save humanity, and no, it isn't you, the Commander. It's some random soldier you train and direct in the field. Someone you have grown to love having on your team because they were a total boss that time they killed that big alien monstrosity. That time they survived that ridiculous ambush. They have been there for you and the mission through months of ceaseless fighting, and they put a stop to it. Your plans got them there, and you will never see their like again. Unless you customized them to be your IRL best friend or something... then you will probably make them over and over again because your troops are customizable, and why not? Have fun with this one.

Yes the game is not always supposed to be fair, and I always play on harder difficulty levels. However there are times when it is just down right ridiculous, listed in order RAGE factor:
1) The Random number generator (RNG). A common problem for RNG implementations is clumping. That is returning a string of numbers in a similar number range. Now the problem with clumping in XCom is that a string of great numbers generally doesnt make much of a difference since taking low probability actions is dumb. Rather than take a 20% shot you are better off hunkering, repositioning, or going to overwatch. However a string of bad numbers makes a big difference. Ive lost count of the number of times every member of my squad has missed on high probability to hit odds, or the enemy hits with numerous successive crits at long range when Ive had full cover.
2) Enemy positioning. Ive loaded into missions and on turn one moved one unit a short distance forward to cover and triggered 10, yes 10, enemies. Complete wipe. No chance.
3) Turn limit missions which cannot possibly be completed because of the distances to travel and the placement of enemies.

You know a game has aged well if you can go back to it after playing the sequels. This is a game about putting aside pride, and accepting bad rolls. You control a squad of soldiers on a grid based map, using cover, and trading shots with the enemy. Firing shots in this game involves percentages, and you will miss those 90% chances. However, various abilities and tools can turn the tide in your favor, even allowing you to forego luck altogether for guaranteed effects. 

Outside of the tactical, grid-based combat, there's a base management game. There's not much here other than choosing priorities, but if you're not prepared to make sacrifices for the greater good, you could be in for a rude awakening.

And for those who master the game and want more, you could always mod the game (outside of Steam workshop) with the excellent and popular "Long War" mod.
For anyone who played the original, XCom:EU or EW will not disappoint. The replayability of this game is second to none, and with the mods available you'll never get tired of it!

This is the game that introduced me to the XCOM series (I was too young to have played the originals) and I must say I quite like it.

You star as the Commander, the leader of a military spec ops group whose objective is to protect the planet from unknown threats (thus, Enemy Unknown). Well, that threat has come to bear in the shape of an alien invasion that starts abducting people out of the blue so now you have to upgrade your base and gear and send your merry band of hapless soldiers to be murdered by the enemy.

XCOM. EU is a tactical, turn based strategy game. It can be gruesomely difficult and the random hit chance can and will make you want to tear your hair out in frustration some times but save often, keep calm, and bump the difficulty down if necessary and you will find yourselves with a good game and a good (partly self-created) story in your hands.

On the technical level I sometimes experience a crash but not too often. I think I only crashed twice in all my playtime, including with the expansion Enemy Within. The expansion, by the way, changes the gameplay, but not the story (not much anyway). So if you buy it do not expect new missions. Just new gear/objectives/gameplay. Which is fine.

I recommend this game for fans of the genre but also for newcomers looking to step into the franchise. Just don't be afraid to go for the lower difficulties if needed, this game is difficult.
